column2: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP)-- Right-hander Harry Dorish retired Catcher Mike Guerra with the tying runs on first and third in the ninth inning, to give the White Sox a 5-to-3 victory over the Senators tonight.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 21--On the second day of his visit to the North Atlantic Pact command, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower saw arms supplied by the American mutual assistance program used in mimic warfare staged for his benefit by a ...

A fall prospect for Broadway is a new play by Arthur Laurents called "The Time of the Cuckoo." Enthused over the script's possibilities, Walter Fried, who aims to put it on next season, asserts that it is, by far, "Mr. Laurents' best written play." The producer conceded, however, that the offering will require "some adroit casting."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Following is the censored transcript of testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees inquiring into the Administration foreign policy (denote censorship deletions):
An auction where two tickets to "The King and I" brought $150 and a pair of diamond earrings realized $4,400 was held for a good cause yesterday at the TwentyOne Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 21-- The successful use of a new type of respirator for correcting a condition known as "reversed breathing" in cerebral-palsied children was described here today by Dr. Robert V. Martin, medical director of the Nassau Cerebral Palsy Center.
Today is National Maritime Day. Shipping interests throughout this county and in Europe, Asia and Africa will join to make this, the eighteenth annual observance, the most successful yet.

BONN, Germany, May 21--The cautious and deliberate approach to German aspirations displayed by British Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison during his stay here has cooled German hopes that the visit would mark a warmer, more sympathetic British attitude toward this country.

JOE PAGE disappeared from the Yankee roster last week. His fade-out was complete. The Bronx Bombers shipped him to Kansas City in the hope that a change of scenery would restore the zing to his trusty left arm. Despite Joe's bold avowals that he would return soon, the consensus was that the last Page had been reached, the Cinderella story ended. Unfortunately, it has not ended on the usual optimistic note, the customary they-lived-happily-ever-after theme.
WINDSOR, Conn., May 21--The Loomis School announced today the establishment of an advisory council to promote greater alumni participation in the school's management.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21--John T. McIntyre, novelist and playwright, died today in Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.

GENOA, Italy, May 8 (By Airmail)--The almost completed hull of a modern 25,000-ton liner rises far above the coastal plain of one of Italy's main ports--an example of that country's desire to regain its traditional place among the world's maritime nations.

Joseph Perkins Chamberlain, who was professor of public law at Columbia University from 1923 until he retired last July with the title of emeritus, died last night at his home, 8 Sutton Square, after an illness of several months.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Supreme Court held today that state "fair trade" laws could not bind merchants who refused to sign no-price-cutting agreements.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 23 --Vice Admiral C. Turner Joy announced today that three American Navy men were killed and nine wounded Sunday when shore batteries at Wonsan, on the Korean east coast, struck the 45,000-ton battleship New Jersey and the destroyer Brinkley Bass.

Too few persons are volunteering for civil defense service, Joseph P. Piccirillo, First Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, reported yesterday to the American Women's Voluntary Services.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has taken a $2,500,000 twenty-year first mortgage bond issue on the Longacre Station Post Office being erected by Webb Knapp, Inc., at 340-46 West Forty-second Street. The Hammond, Harvey, Braxton ...
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The White Sox won their sixth straight game of an undefeated Eastern trip tonight, beating Washington, 9--8, with a fifteen hit barrage against four pitchers.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 12--There is little evidence, so far, of effective coordination of defense production in different Western European countries.

Mrs. Hall Braman of Woodmere, L,I., and Chester Alwyn Braman of 580 Park Avenue and Old Chatham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Roosevelt Braman, to Thomas Arthur McGraw, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Butler McGraw of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The wedding will take place late next month.
THE CHAIRMAN--The committee will come to order. Senator McMahon?

There is a feature of the dangerous Iranian oil issue that has to be faced with as clear a vision as we can apply. The sharp and aggrieved rebuff to the United States effort at mediation should cause no surprise. We must realize that we--meaning in this case the democratic West--are faced with an emotional and spiritual condition that cannot be solved on mere legalistic, political or economic grounds.

Considering the opposition, it may not mean too much, but the fact is that Allie Reynolds pitched his best game of the season yesterday at the Stadium. The veteran righthander, handicapped by an elbow injury throughout spring training, set down the eighth-place Browns with four hits as the Yankees romped to a 6-1 victory over Ned Garver.

Once-upon-a-time an industrialist from the Far West came to Wall Street to arrange some financing for his company. He prepared himself by bringing along his 30-30 hunting rifle. As he strode into the offices of First Boston Corporation, overlooking the Trinity Church cemetery, he declared he had, come to "talk price" and was "reads" to meet the banking house's top brass.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The United States banned today the export of any strategic materials to West German business concerns engaged in illegal trade with the Soviet Union or other countries under Communist domination.

CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., May 22 (AP)--Mrs. Anne M. Gannett, former president of the National Federation of Music Clubs and the wife of Guy P. Gannett, Maine newspaper publisher and radio chain owner, died here today at her home after a long illness. Her age was 68.

In order to meet the growing demands of defense production, the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago expects to spend approximately $450,000,000 over the next three years, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman of the board, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.

PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, May 23--The Dodgers started playing the Pirates last night but they didn't complete their 17-8 triumph until well after midnight this morning. Two interruptions by rain, the second one of fifty minutes in the third inning, helped drag out the affair.
Prices for commodities in the New York market, unless otherwise noted, were:

Lenygon Morant, Inc., decorators, who bought the two five-story buildings at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eightysecond Street in 1929 and converted them into apartments in 1940, have sold the property to Michael Newman, an investing ...

HISTORY may never repeat itself exactly; but history is rich with examples of men behaving in much the same way as other men behaved previously in similar circumstances. The strain and sacrifice of war are usually followed by the disillusionment, cynicism and demoralization of post-war periods.

A program for industrial relations to aid in prevention of a third world war was advocated yesterday by J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty and director of the industrial relations section of Princeton University.

CHICAGO, May 22 (UP)--Repeal of the rational Collegiate Athletic Association sanity code last January has influenced Big Ten opinion against renewal of the Rose Bowl pact with the Pacific Coast Conference, it was learned today.
DETROIT, May 22--The Hudson Motor Car Company shut down its assembly lines today, laying off 10,000 workers for two weeks.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 1 point higher to 35 points net lower.

BERLIN, May 22--The personal plane of Admiral Alan G. Kirk, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, remained grounded at Tempelhof Airport today for the fourth consecutive day as the Polish Government continued to refuse per nussion for its flight to Moscow to take the Ambassador to Paris. Clearance was obtained for the trip from Soviet authorities as routine procedure last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Jose Ferrer, 1950 motion picture Academy Award winner, blamed carelessness and ignorance today for his inclusion on the sponsorship and entertainment lists of many Communist "front" organizations through a half-dozen years.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, May 22 (UP)--Sam Urzetta, United States amateur champion from Rochester, N.Y., and Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, led an advance of thirteen Americans into the third round of the British amateur golf championship today with only one major defeat in the gale-force winds and rain sweeping in from the Irish Sea.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP)-- Right-hander Early Wynn scattered five hits--one in each of the middle innings--to give the Indians a 6-2 victory over the Athletics tonight before 8,541 fans.

Battlefield is ready for 1951. The George D. Widener colt, who was expected to be the standout 3-year-old of the current season, scored an impressive victory at Belmont Park yesterday before a crowd of 20,074.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22-- "The Halfbreed," an R.K.O. western starring Robert Young and Jack Buetel which was completed six weeks ago on a Class A budget, has been assembled in rough cut and found too short to release, it was learned today.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP)--Edward D. Stair, former publisher of The Detroit Free Press, died tonight at Bon Secours Hospital in suburban Grosse Pointe. He was 92 years old.

ST. PAUL, May 22 (AP)--Two Eastern bowling teams moved into the select group in the five-man event in the American Bowling Congress tournament last night. One team missed a tie for the lead by one pin.

The fighting in Korea can be kept in perspective only if three basic facts are kept in mind: (1) censorship of all reports is now exremely severe--in fact foolishly restrictive; (2) the United States battlefield, or combat intelligence, of enemy srengths and capabilities still leaves much to be desired;

A homely mongrel sat at a luncheon table in quiet dignity yesterday as officials of the East River Refinery of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., paid tribute to him for his five years of "devoted service."

The Oliver Corporation, farm equipment makers, attained a new high sales record in the six months ended with April and increased earnings over the previous year's period by $994,000 despite substantially larger taxes.

Thompson Street in Greenwich Village seems to have become the special domain, through a precedent established in 1947, of young art students of the Police Athletic League. Spring and fall, by invitation of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Show, youths from the growing number of art classes in league centers in the various boroughs have had their special place in the sprawling sidewalk show.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Opposition to the Administration's proposal to extend and strengthen the Defense Production Act of 1950 gathered force today as strong appeals were made to end existing credit curbs on automobile and real estate sale.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A 60 per cent increase in second class mail rates was approved today by the House Post Office Committee. The Administration had asked a 100 per cent increase.

The highly personalized chill of terror that comes from being denounced by name over the radio-- a form of terrorism hertofore considered a special weapon of Communist and Fascist nations--is being served back with interest toy at least one Iron Curtain country in Europe by Radio Free Europe.

Plans are being speeded by Mrs. William L. van Leer Jr., chairman, and Mrs. Pairie Fentress, co-chairman, for the block party and square dance for the benefit of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission to be held on Friday night from 7 to 11 o'clock in East Seventy-first Street between Park Avenue and Madison Avenue. They have been holding meetings recently with members of the junior committee at the Delmonico to complete arrangements.

Bacardi Imports, Inc., announces a 500-line national newspaper campaign backing its previous editorial ad campaign "Let the Buyer Beware!" The new campaign points out that quality rum drinks cost only three cents more than those made with the cheapest ...

Business concerns affected by the Supreme Court's decision on "fair trade" pricing studied possible major shifts in distribution and dealer relations yesterday. The court ruled on Monday that "fair trade" laws of forty-fire states could not bind all sellers of a product handled by some under voluntary minimum-price agreements.

CHICAGO, May 22--Stock market prices may decline 10 to 20 per cent in the next few months, but this should not be construed as the start of a major economic setback for the country, Harold E. Aul, vice president of Calvin Bullock, New York management investment firm, said today. He spoke at a meeting of securities dealers.

The High School Teachers Association declared yesterday that its members would adopt a policy of "passive resistance and non-cooperation" if the Board of Education compelled teachers to resume extra-curricular activities without granting them a satisfactory salary adjustment.

The names of six appointees to full ten-year terms on the Magistrate's Court bench were announced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri. In making the names public the Mayor insisted that political considerations were either minor or non-existent in his selections, and that bar approval carried the greatest weight.

The two-story factory building at 36-14 Thirty-fifth Street in Long Island City, Queens, formerly owned and occupied by Polak's Frutal Works, has been leased by the Reinitz Soap Corporation from the 50-18 Vernon Boulevard Corporation, which recently purchased it for investment. The lease was negotiated by Queens Industrials as broker.

The stock market was unable yesterday to snap out of its depression and gave more ground. The bulk of the pressure was directed against the motors. Early strength vanished before moderate selling in the afternoon which shaded prices major fractions in many cases, with wider losses in the automotives and rails.

The $75,000,000 calculating machine industry is continuing to expand despite material and manpower shortages, according to Edgar B. Jessttp, president of Marchant Calculating Machine Company. His own company, with headquarters in Oakland, Calif, ...

The soft goods retailer is having a hard time paying his bills and needs almost twice as long to pay as he did a year ago, according to s survey by the New York Credit and Financial Management Association.

THE Cape Cod striper fishing picked up almost overnight, and reports from several points along the cape indicate that the fish are increasing in numbers every day with several really big catches made during the past few days.

World and domestic sugar prices reached new highs for the season yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The domestic, or No. 6 contract finished at a net gain of 6 to 17 points on sales of 14,500 tons. The world, or No. 4 contract ended at a net advance of 4 to 26 points, with transactions amounting to 22,050 tons.

The armistice agreement between Syria and Israel in July of 1949 provided that Syrian troops should be withdrawn from certain small areas of Palestine they then occupied, that these areas should be demilitarized and that they then should be gradually restored to "normal civilian life."

WASHINGTON, May 22--Msgr. Fulton d. Sheen, widely known Roman Catholic writer and lecturer, has been appointed titular Bishop of Caesariana and auxiliary to Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, it was announced tonight by the Most Rev. Amleto Gioyanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

Marketing arrangements for two pending public utility equity financing deals were decided upon yesterday. At the same time, announcement was made of the private sale of 50,000 shares of new $100 par value $4.50 preferred stock of Florida Power and Light ...

HOUSTON, Tex., May 22--American cities were warned today to step up the tempo of their lagging civilian defense programs or face the possibility that their failure to act promptly might bring much higher casualties in case of bombing attack.

This city accorded National Maritime Day yesterday the largest peacetime observance in its history with crowds in Bowling Green Park and the surrounding streets witnessing the ceremony on the steps of the Custom House. With hundreds of others at windows of the near-by buildings the area took on the appearance of a giant amphitheatre.

Many of the folding chairs designed today are meant to be a part of a room's furnishings even though their presence there may be only temporary. The use of these chairs is manifold and almost every home, large or small, has need of chairs that can be offered unashamedly to an overflow of guests.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Senator Robert A. Taft told Government stabilization officials today that he believed wages ought to be adjusted wehn the cost of living went up. He added that if wade increases were held to 10 per cent a year the stabilizers would be doing a good job.

Brooklyn College celebrated its coming of age yesterday with a country fair. Though the strains of "Ki Yi Yippee" and "The Old Chisholm Trail" floated out over Flatbush, it was a country fair such as could be found only in the home borough of Coney Island.

MIAMI BEACH, May 22 (UP)-- A psychiatrist told the delegates to the National Congress of Parents and Teachers today that adults should listen to the "wisdom" of youth while instilling confidence in children.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., N.Y., May 22--A campaign to take "hotrods" drivers, "jalopy jerks" and other careless youths off the Westchester highways is about to shift into high gear. Police justices said today it would be the first test in the state of a county-wide approach to safety for teen-agars.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 22 --The United States and Britain intend to deprive the North German ports of Hamburg, Bremen and Luebeck of their ancient privileges as free ports as part of the widening campaign to halt the flow of illegal trade in strategic materials with the Soviet Union and its satellites.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A "mutual security program" of global proportions that will call for $8,500,000,000 in foreign military and economic aid in the 1952 fiscal year will be outlined by President Truman in a special message to Congress tomorrow or Thursday.

The percentage of drafts paid promptly by Latin-American countries rose to 67 per cent last month, according to the Latin-American export credit collection experience of reporting member banks published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure compares with 62 per cent in March.

Commission on Narcotic Drugs --drafted request to ask Italy to suspend manufacture of heroin. Economic, Employment and Development Commission--Discussed national action by devel oped countries in economic development of backward countries.

We quote from a brief news story in yesterday's TIMES: "The 689 firemen and maintenance employes on New York City Housing Authority projects who staged a 'demonstration' one-day walkout last Thursday were promised upgrading of salary ranges yesterday, pending approval by city officials."

WASHINGTON, May 22--Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican of New Hampshire, declined today to ask any questions at the Senate foreign policy hearings and urged his colleagues on the committees to "ring down the curtain" on the inquiry into the ouster of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur

ALBANY, May 22--Leo V. Lanning, State Veterans Affairs Director reported today that fewer than 2 per cent of New York's 1,700,000 World War II veterans had exhausted their educational or training entitlements under the G.I. Bill of Rights, although about 44 per cent entered training.

In this country, there are 1,800,000 mentally retarded persons under 21 who can be fitted for defense work, given a little "honest" special education, Richard H. Hungerford, president of the American Association on Mental Deficiency, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 22--After seven days of almost mid-summer weather as they traveled with varying fortunes through Pittsburgh, Cincinnati and St. Louis, the Giants arrived here today and found Chicago at its worst.

WASHINGTON, May 22--President Truman called upon the Senate today to remove from the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill a "crippling limitation" imposed by the House of Representatives. The limitation would reduce the ...
BOSTON, May 22 (AP)--Catcher Les Moss, acquired only a week ago, broke the spell that southpaw Ted Gray had cast on the Red Sox today with a grand slam homer that overcame the Tigers, 6--3.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Testimony before a tariff commission hearing on Swiss watch import duties was described by a witness today as "a lot of eyewash." Domestic manufacturers of jeweled watches want the commission to withdraw concessions on Swiss ...

With greatly increased production and the acquisition of a substantial stock pile, the crisis in rubber is over, it was asserted yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman of the Firestone Tire Rubber Company. He arrived here room Europe, where he ...

A formal protest against the tariff agreement on textiles between the United States and Cuba, negotiated at the Torquay Conference, was filed with the State Department yesterday by the Textile Export Association of the United States. The association urged that the tariff section of the ...

LONDON, May 22--The first relief over the removal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far Eastern command is giving way in Britain to new anxieties over the trend of United States policy.

WARSAW, May 22 (AP)--Poland and the Soviet Union have agreed on an exchange of small parcels of territory on Poland's eastern frontier, giving the Soviet Union a link in a rail line in exchange for a piece of Ukrainian territory including an oil and natural gas area.

SHARON, Conn., May 22--The Rev. Dr. Theodore Sedgwick, rector emeritus of Calvary Episcopal Church, New York, who was a clergyman of the Protestant Episcopal Church for sixty years and a member of the New York Diocese for forty years, died at his home here today after a long illness at the age of 87.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy pledged his support yesterday to the drive for expansion of the city's day care facilities for children of working mothers. However, he declared, the fight to get the necessary funds would require "the backing and pressure of all citizens groups interested in and concerned about children."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 22--Before General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower left this afternoon for Oslo for the second leg of his inspection tour of the North Atlantic Treaty Northern Command, he was told by the Danes this country, because of a lack of officers and barracking facilities, could not extend the military training period beyond twelve months.

Imaginative accessories, furniture with much storage space and clear, crisp color seem to be the major decorating requirements for small apartments. These findings are the result of a survey conducted by John Brice of Alfred Auerbach Associates, who studied reader mail compiled by a consumer magazine and floor plans of typical housing projects.

CHICAGO, May 22--The grain market showed a much stronger tone today, following recent big declines, substantial recoveries being made in wheat from the low spots of yesterday, with the other grains also showing strength after early irregularity.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22--Declaring that appliance salesmen have become "complacent" as the result of the seller's market of recent years, Charles A. Morrow, vice president in charge of sales for Mullins Manufacturing Corporation, Salem, Ohio, said here ...
ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP)--A fourrun rally in the fifth inning that included only one hit tonight enabled the Braves to defeat the Cardinals, 7--2, behind southpaw Warren Spahn.

Democratic party leaders in New York State have decided to resubmit to President Truman the name of Lloyd Paul Stryker as a nominee for Federal district judge in the Southern District, which includes Manhattan, the Bronx and a number of Hudson River countee.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The ranking military officer of the United States swore today that the Senate's prolonged investigation of the dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur was endangering this country.
The largest graduating class in the history of Union Theological Seminary attended the 115th annual commencement exercises last night in Riverside Church.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., May 22--Inwood won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team championship over the Fairview country club course today.

Thomas R. Lawson has been appointed assistant sales manager of industrial products for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, Pa. He formerly was assistant manager of the application engineering department for the company's motor and control division, Buffalo.

The traditional gloom of Eilis Island's dark chambers and corridors was brightened yesterday with the opening of a modern, sunlit school-playground for the children of a dozen nationalities whose parents are waiting for admission to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A straight 12 per cent increase in all individual income taxes was agreed upon at a secret caucus of Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee today for adoption by the full committee tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22--The Israeli Government announced tonight it would halt work temporarily on Arab-owned land affected by the Lake Huleh drainage project, but would continue operations on Jewish-owned property within the disputed demilitarized zone along the Syrian frontier.

One aspect of the Iranian oil dispate that has received little attention is its effect on the Point Four program. A plan for extending financial and technical aid to underdeveloped countries is the pet project of President Truman.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP)-- Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson ordered a delay today on a court ruling that would have sent the Secretary of Commerce, Charles Sawyer, to jail Thursday unless he relinguished control of the American President Lines.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 22 (UP)--Czechoslovakia accused the United States today of aiding anti-Czechoslovak spies and terrorists through "hostile" broadcasts and "violations of the Czech border."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 22-- Miss Rosemarie Crawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Crawley of Scarsdale and Hampton Bays, L.I., has completed plans for her marriage to William Charles Andre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Florian J. Andre of Hartsdale.

Last December some newspaper editors and publishers were asked, at Gracie Mansion, if they would support Mayor Impellitteri's administration in a "tough" approach to the problem of traffic congestion. A few weeks ago a somewhat similar group met with Police Commissioner Murphy and other city officials and the conferees were asked the same question.

CANOGA PARK, Calif., May 22 (UP)--Your Host, doomed to death by veterinarians after a fall at Santa Anita race track last January, is recovering and definitely will stand at stud, his handlers reported today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, May 22-- For the first time in Tongking, Communist-led Vietminh forces appear to be concentrating in considerable strength along the southern rim of the French-held Red River delta in northeastern IndoChina. An attack from the south may be planned.
LONDON, May 22--Britain has assured the United States that except in an extreme and sudden emergency she would not send troops to Iran without first consulting the Washington Government.
CHICAGO, May 22--Shipments of cattle to twenty principal markets in the United States increased to normal proportions today, but the two-day total for this week's marketing was well below normal.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a bill carrying an extra $6,438,996,000 for the armed forces and Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Following is the complete, censored transcript of today's session of the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees inquiring into the Administration foreign policy (censorship deletions noted parenthetically):
Dr. George Keith Funston, 40year-old president of Trinity College in Hartford, Conn., will become the next president of the New York Stock Exchange.
DUGWAY, Utah, May 22--Army engineers and civilian scientists blew a giant hole in the wastelands of Western Utah today.

NEWARK, May 22--Four hundred persons met tonight in the Weequahic High School auditorium here to honor Max J. Herzberg, the school's first principal. He will retire from that post in June at the age of 65 after forty-four years of service in the Newark public school system.
Despite the heat and humidity, 10,000 persons gathered at the steps of the Subtreasury Building yesterday for the annualy noontime Wall Street rally of the Greater New York Fund.

The National Shipping Authority announced yesterday that fifty ships carrying 484,924 tons of cargo had sailed from United States ports for Europe and India since March 13. All were Government-owned craft operated under General Agency agreement. The cargoes, principally coal and grain, were consigned by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Mayor Impellitteri made public yesterday a $15,000,000 program to provide air-raid shelters in the subway system and to make key stations easily accessible for pedestrians in an attack. He said the Federal Government would pay half the cost under legislation now pending in Congress, while the city and state would put up the rest.

American composers no longer need to be coddled. This opinion was expressed yesterday by the Music Critics Circle of New York, when it announced the results of its final meeting of the season. A new constitution was adopted and knew officers were elected.

The Mayfair Outfitting Company, 103-17 Northern Boulevard, Corona, Queens, will hold a public auction beginning tomorrow in the Brooklyn Academy of Music to dispose of a quantity of top brand television receivers, refrigerators, washers and other appliances ...
Five New Yorkers received City Fusion party Finickerbocker awards for outstanding service to the city last night at the party's dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel attended by 400 persons.

The constitutionality of the State Crime Commission and the validity of its subpoena power were upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Felix C. Benvenga. He had been designated by the Appellate Division to hear all motions arising out of legal challenges to Governor Dewey's appointment of the commission.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--A butter industry spokesman said today enough butter would be available to meet consumer demands this year "if production is not interfered with by (price) ceilings and black markets."

PARIS, May 17--The International Textile Exhibition at Lille has appeal for the woman in quest of beauty to whom new machinery and new production methods mean little. She probably passes by the 4,500 square yards of machinery it action to admire fabulous laces, silks, nylon fabrics, furs, gowns historical and modern and the way they are displayed.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 22--The Iranian Government's campaign to arouse popular feeling against the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company reached its zenith today with a big demonstration in Parliament Square.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Office of Price Stabilization ordered new price ceilings today established for futures trading in wool and wooltop futures at levels 9 per cent below those in effect since April 6, last, The order becomes effective next Monday.

ARDEN, N.Y., May 22--Dr. Grayson Kirk, vice president of Columbia University, warned the university's American Assembly today that the United States must consider whether it can afford to continue its policy-making in the open view of the Soviet Union.
HOBOKEN, N.J., May 22-- Seven men were being held tonight as witnesses in the fatal shooting of a longshoreman after the automobile used in the shooting was found abandoned earlier.

THE British amateur championship in the Scottish game of golf is being held in Wales this weelk. In order to complete the cycle it probably should be won by an Irishman-- from the forth of Ireland, naturally. But it undoubtedly will be won by an American and the ancient trophy again will be carted across the seas. The British are exporting far more than they normally prefer, particularly in sports.
Mayor Impellitteri shared a dais at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon with a one-monthold baby girl. His honor, by his own reckoning, came out second best in the speaking.

LONDON, May--22--The stock markets improved modestly today, small rises being accompanied by slightly stronger buying. British Government securities weakened, however, after a good start and some rises were more than lost.
TOKYO, Wednesday, May 23 (AP) --General Headquarters Communique 892, issued at 9:45 A.M. Wednesday (7:45 P.M., Eastern daylight time, Tuesday):

DENVER, May 21--William M. Boyle Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted today that the prospects of achieving lasting peace would influence President Truman greatly when he decided whether to run again in 1952.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 22-- A concentration camp "class" in the Soviet Union, already several million strong, is rapidly becoming self-perpetuating, according to sworn testimony delivered here today by survivors of Soviet prison camps.
WEST CENTRAL FRONT, in Korea, May 22--Chinese Communist field commanders hay a been using South Korean refugees to detonate mine fields laid in front of the allies lines.

WASHINGTON, May 22--This country should develop a new pattern for its rural school program, the Department of Rural Education of the National Education Association says in its 1951 yearbook, which was issued today.

Buffalo announced yesterday that it would offer for sale next Tuesday bonds totaling $6,460,000 to finance water facilities, schools and park improvements. The bonds will be dated June 15 and will come due June 15, 1952 to 1981.

PARIS, May 22--Western Europe's biggest post-war airshow will begin tomorrow when Air Force units of six nations launch maneuvers designed to test the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's air defenses in the Netherlands, Belgium and Northern France.

MADRID, May 22 (Reuters)-- Protests against the cost of living flared up anew today as thousands of Madrid workers obeyed a secret call to boycott public transport. Many workers in the Basque country went on strike.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 23-- United Nations forces drove ahead on the western and central fronts in Korea yesterday. Advance guards thrust to within five miles of the Thirty-eighth Parallel at one point. But in the east the Communists drove a penetration into the United Nations lines near Soksa, inland from the Sea of Japan.

At 8 o'clock this evening, Robert E. Sherwood's comedy, "Idiot's Delight," Rill be revived for the first time on Broadway at the City Center. Winner of the 1936 Pulitzer Prize, the play, which will continue through June 3, is the final fortnightly bill in the six-week season.
A young male gorilla--"a lovely little fellow, very spunky and active," according to his guardian--arrived yesterday at the Bronx Zoo.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Administration bill to lend $190,000,000 to India for the purchase of feed grains for famine relief passed its first test of strength in the House of Representatives today by a vote of 211 to 13. The Senate passed a similar bill last week, but the House is considering its own version.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 22--Efforts of the New York Civil Rights Congress to obtain a list of the 265,147 enrolled voters in Westchester County failed temporarily today after the Board of Elections had been informed the organization was on the Attorney General's list of "subversive organizations."

King George VI of England has an unfortunate memory. Visiting the London Stock Exchange yesterday, he remarked that his last previous visit had been on the occasion of the 1929 market collapse. WASHINGTON, May 23--The Office of Price Stabilization in an order tonight granted extensions until July 2 for filing reports under the agency's three general price orders covering manufacturers in general, machinery manufacturers and textile manufacturers. The Central Building of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street had an ordinary Wednesday afternoon crowd yesterday. The new 1,000-passenger luxury liner Constitution will be tested off the Massachusetts coast tomorrow in a "company trial" observed by officials of the American Export Lines, Inc., L.S. Andrews, its vice president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, opposed today a bill to permit the Marine Corps to expand to more than double its present size, but conceded that the corps' commandant might legally have some voice in the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

To prevent a wave of price-cuting in the book industry, the American Booksellers' Association took a pledge yesterday to do everything legally within its power to obtain reinstatement of the nonsigner clause in state "fair trade" contracts.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Budd Schulberg, novelist, testified voluntarily before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he became a Communist during the late Nineteen Thirties but quit the party when it tried to dictate what he should write.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 23-- Two Russian witnesses testifying today before the unofficial tribunal set up to expose the concentration camp system declared that the Russian system of forced labor was uneconomic and a liability on the economic system of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Dr. W. Palmer Dearing, acting Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, said in a report today that a "trial run" had demonstrated that any future virulent influenza epidemic could be met speedily by mass-immunization.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor departed for Europe yesterday aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. The former British monarch said they would be abroad at least five or six months during which time they hoped to purchase a "small country home" in the suburbs of Paris.

The Consolidated Grocers Corporation, tanner, processor and distributor of about $175,000,000 of foodstuffs annually, is dividing its operations into two parts. Nathan Cummings, chairman, said one will handle the canning and processing activities and the other will distribute food products.

Casey Stengel may have found his long-sought fourth starting pitcher. Whaley of 1867 Seventh Avenue, the first Negro woman to engage in active law practice in the State of New York.

TOKYO, Friday, May 25--United Nations patrols thrust across the Thirty-eighth Parallel into North Korea yesterday, hard on the heels of the Chinese and North Korean Communists retreating rapidly after the second round of their vaunted spring offensive had ended in costly defeat.

A partial recovery followed a violent plunge on the stock market yester day during which prices slumped to the worst levels since January. Top losses during the day in the general run of stocks were 3 points and even more in the higher price issues, but at the close the net decline was 0.99 point.
TOMORROW 10 A. M.: Opening meet, Police Athletic League Outdoor Track Championship series, Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx.

Mongolism, which has long been a mystery because the term has misled people to think of mongoloids as "monstrosities" or victims of racial regression, is a result of fetal growth deficiency, Dr. Clemens E. Benda, internationally known authority in the field of mental deficiency, reported yesterday.

Lutheran World Action has supervised the resettlement in this country of 23,000 displaced persons, delegates to the annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York heard yesterday. The world group is an arm

BOZEMAN, Mont., May 24-- Defense demands for electric power are skyrocketing so amazingly that estimates of six months ago, on which many of the nation's construction speed-up schedules are based, were declared out of date today by Willian E. Warne, Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

The nation's natural gas pipeline industry will spend a record total of $630,000,000 this year for the expansion and extension of facilities in order to bring natural gas to an additional 125 cities of 50,000,, or more population. A current construction program involving 7,618 miles additional pipeline for 1950 is well under way.

The millinery industry should accord deep bows to the American Hat Block Company for sending designer Florence Reichman to select Paris designs to be reproduced in blocks that would have not only the newest trends but a custom feeling.

BEAU JACK is a little fellow with a big heart. His courage and his eternal hustle carried him much farther than his physical equipment had any right to carry him. The Beau became the lightweight champion of the world. He pulled into Madison Square Garden alone more-than a million dollars at the gate.

Seven corporations and six individuals were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury for conspiracy to fix prices in Eastern United States for the manufacture and sale of printers' rollers in violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Act.
Perhaps the greatest difference between the New York Stock Exchange and the smaller exchanges operating in other parts of the country is in the specialist system. The specialist, even when pub

G. Wallace Jarman of Port-auPeck, N. J., and Mrs. V. Tyson Jarman of 49 East Ninety-sixth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia, of Washington, to William Reynolds Fearey of 137 East Thirty-fifth Street, son of Mrs. Malcolm Shiland Fearey of Albany, and the late Mr. Fearey.

A 21-year-old man was stabbed to death last night and at least two other persons were wounded in a gang fight in Queens Village, Queens, involving more than thirty youths. The police rounded up most of the combatants and were questioning them early this morning at the Queens Village station house.

The plan recommended by the Board of Transportation's engineering consultants for a forty-hour work week on the city transit lines was vetoed yesterday by Michael J. Quill's Transport 'Workers Union, C.I.O. The union, which was primarily responsible for having the survey made, charged that the eningeers' plan for reducing service and

Chuck beef steak, for which the city-wide price average is not up to ceiling levels, has advanced 3 cents to 78 a pound. The City Department of Markets in its weekly survey of retail food costs also noted a 3-cent increase on plate and navel of beef, now 46 cents a pound. But except for a penny decline on oxtails, all other meats are unchanged in price.
LONDON, May 24--The head of Britain's biggest newsprint company disagreed with the contention, frequently voiced here, that the United States was "hogging" available supplies of newsprint.
Dr. Luther Gulick explained yesterday why the city isn't buying any new steel filing cabinets this year.

LONDON, May-- 24--British Government securities were progressively weaker on the stock markets today. Further falls of about onehalf point reduced gilt edge securities almost to their level of November, 1949, before the Government intervened to bolster the market.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Beef slaughter quotas for June were fixed by the Office of Price Stabilization today at 80 per cent of the June, 1950, figures. This month's quota is 90 per cent of that for May a year ago.
JERSEY CITY, May 24--This city's waterfront will be "out of bounds" in the future to gangsters, racketeers and others with long police records, city officials announced today.

BERLIN, May 24--Bishop designate Fulton J. Sheen expressed tonight his conviction that the Russian people would survive the present totalitarian regime and be reunited with other peoples of the civilized world.
Within two to seven weeks the New York Stock Exchange will hold a referendum to determine whether it should close on Saturdays throughout the year.
Willie Mays, 20-year-old Negro outfielder, will start in center field for the Giants in the game with the Phillies in Shibe Park tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) The White Sox did something today no other American League club from the Windy City has been able to accomplish in modern times when they completed an unbeaten Eastern invasion with a 5-2 victory over the Athletics.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Georgia Power Company of Atlanta received today permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer for sale, at competitive bidding, its $20,000,000 first mortgage bond issue, series 1981. Proceeds of the financing are to be used for construction purposes.

A considerable mail received by this newspaper in the last few days testifies to widespread interest in the problem of improving the troop-information program of the armed services. These letters of comment on the series of articles by Benjamin Fine on the services' Information and Education Program make numerous suggestions; they

EVANSTON, Ill., May 24 (UP)-- Illinois and Michigan State paced the qualifying trials today of the Big Ten's fifty-first track championships, sending thirteen and eleven men respectively into tomorrow's finals at twilight.
WASHINGTON, May 24--The National Association of Real Estate Boards called today for ending all Federal rent regulation on June 30.

PARIS, May 24--The French National Assembly that "faded away" today at what was in effect the end of its five-year term had often appeared futile and even ridiculous. It sometimes seemed so immersed in local politics that it almost ignored the developing world crisis.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 24 (AP)-- An official Israeli report charged today that Jordanian National Guardsmen twice invaded Israel this week in the Southern Judean mountains. They were reported driven back by Israeli troops.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24-- Clarence G. Meeks, president of the New Jersey Banker's Association, told the nearly 1,300 bankers at the opening session of the fortyseventh annual convention of the association today at Haddon Hall Hotel that "there should be no compromise with inflation."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Friday, May 25--The United States Army and High Commissioner's office announced late last night they had been ordered by the State Department to stay the execution of seven German war criminals for at least five days. The hangings of the seven men in Landsberg prison had been expected shortly after midnight.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, May 24 (UP)--Sam Urzetta, the United States champion from Rochester, N. Y., led two former American titleholders into the quarter-finals of the British amateur golf championship with a pair of victories over tenacious foes from Scotland today after the defending champion, Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, was soundly beaten in the fourth round.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 24--The Iranian Government today gave the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company one week in which to begin arrangements for effective nationalization of the company's southern oil concession.
The Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that it had received $3,270,941 in contributions to date from business and employe groups toward its 1951 goal of $9,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 24--A Republican effort to break off military testimony in the investigation of the ouster of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and to proceed at once to Secretary tary of State Dean Acheson was defeated today by 14 to 11.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., MAY 24--Sven Grafstrom, Swedish representative to the United Nations, said today that the General Assembly's Good Offices Committee recently received a message in which "a Russian source" conveyed the Willingness of the Soviet Government to negotiate a settlement in Korea.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 24--Dr. Albert Lightbody, chief of the chemistry division of the United States Navy Ordnance Laboratory, told members of the Society of the Plastics Industry here today that "the day of steel ships and steel men is rapidly passing," while the day of "plastic men in plastic ships" is dawning.

As soon as Trinity College can find a new president, Dr. George Keith Funston will become president of the New York Stock Exchange. The move may take place in the fall, but not later than next Jan. 1.

ALBANY, May 24--The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that Frank Erickson, the bookmaker, must serve out his two-year prison term and pay the $30,000 fine imposed on him by New York's City's Court of Special Sessions.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 24--The Communist propaganda campaign, aimed at softening up West Germany and reducing Soviet or satellite military problems in event of future aggression, is comparable, in resources and the direction of the effort by the Soviet Union, to active military aggression, John J. McCloy said today.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)-- Following is the text of President Truman's foreign-aid message to the Congress today:

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)-- Following is the censored testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees inquiring into the Administration Foreign Policy (censorship deletions noted parentheti

Charges of "stalling" and "lacK of good faith" in negotiations for an agreement covering East and Gulf Coast shipping were directed at vessel operators yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.

Awards for distinguished service in American journalism were given last night by Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity, to nineteen persons, a newspaper, a magazine and a radio station.

Action soon on a gigantic program for stimulating economic progress of underdeveloped areas was urged yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller as vital to the free world's aims of rearmament and lasting peace.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 24--Although a northeast storm was raging across Newport Harbor, scores of Navy men risked their lives early today to rescue all but two of at least 130 sailors cast into the choppy waters when a fifty-foot liberty launch capsized.
Completion of full automatic train-stop protection on the Atlantic Avenue branch of the Long Island Rail Road between Brooklyn and Jamaica was announced yesterday. The road said

WASHINGTON, May 24--The National Association of Manufacturers and one of its biggest duespaying members, the General Motors Corporation, argued contrary views on productivity wage increases before the Wage Stabilization Board today.

Bronze busts of Alexander Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone, and Dr. William Crawford Gorgas, who as an Army medical officer made possible the building of the Panama Canal by wiping out yellow fever in the zone, were unveiled yesterday at a ceremony in the library at the uptown campus of New York University.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 14--The economic repercussions of the Western defense effort are pretty much the same everywhere in Western Europe but they do not hit all countries in the same way or at the same time.
The crisis in Iran deepened yesterday but there was no sign that the drums had begun to roll.

A gasoline price war flared up yesterday along the entire Eastern seaboard when several major companies cut prices up to 2 cents a gallon to dealers. The reduction was initiated by the Sun Oil Company, which lowered the posted tank wagon price of gasoline 1...

Highly controversial bills that would drastically revamp the retirement procedures of the Police, Fire, Health and Sanitation Departments were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. Mayor Impellitteri refrained from voting, on the ground that these measures still must come before him for public hearings.
New highs for the movement in both world and domestic sugar futures contracts proved virtually the only strong spots in a day of declining commodity prices.

Copper may be the first big primary material on which the solidity of the price ceilings now generally imposed on industrial materials, Will be tested, it was reported here yesterday. Chilean copper has been sold here at 27 cents a pound, three cents higher than domestic copper which is marketed at 24 -cent ceiling price.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 24 --No limit has been set on the build-up of the North Atlantic pact forces to defend Germany and Europe against Soviet aggression, John Strachey, British Secretary of State for War, declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 24--President Truman, describing himself as confident but not "cocky," declared today that his domestic and foreign policies had the backing of the people of the United States and of the world "because they are right."

WASHINGTON, May 24 (U.P.)-- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. (Chesty) Puller of the Marine Corps, just home from Korea, cut loose with some tart comment on the United States Air Force today after leaving a cross-country trail of pungent remarks on ice cream-fed and undertrained troops.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., May 24 (AP)--A twenty-three member special grand jury, largest number possible, was organized today for the sweeping $100,000 investigation of political-racketeer ties with gambling in Saratoga County.
The facts of life in an apparently glutted market for television receivers began to come out into the open yesterday as the result of organized dealer protests against public "auctions" of the sets.

In a message outlining again the broad policies and aims of the United States, President Truman yesterday called upon Congress to appropriate an additional $8,500,000,000 for the military, economic and spiritual rearmament of the free world. This total,

Pontius Pilate was most decisive in his performance in the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday. Favored to win the $7,500 added event which served as the feature attraction, F. Ambrose Clark's 5-year-old son of Pilate upheld his role of choice by scoring by more than six lengths over the distance of about two miles.

With the noonday sun of late spring riding high in the sky and the tress in full leaf, the pattern of shade on the ground is often a delightful one. Winter's bare branches cast only a penumbral blur on the tree-lined sidewalks, but now heavy foliage spreads there a dark carpet spotted with patches of light. Some of these patches, made by

The American Fair Trade Council declared yesterday that the Supreme Court's decision of Monday did not actually invalidate fair trade laws. This was the group's first pronouncement on the ruling. After staff discussions with its board of directors the group released to its members a letter signed by John W. Anderson, its president, in which it set forth that the decision "clearly says that the Miller-Tydings Act can be

WASHINGTON, May 24--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley disclosed today that United States "non-battle casualties" in Korea totaled 72,679 since the start of the fighting, but defended the Defense Department's policy of not releasing such figures on the ground that they were "misleading."

WASHINGTON, May 24--President Truman told a group of United States Attorneys today that their job was to see that justice was done and to assure a fair trial to every accused person, making certain that "no innocent man gets punished for something he did not do."

PARIS, May 24--In an interesting midsummer showing, Alwynn introduces terry cloth, not only for the beach but for town and evening as well. Colors are derived from the sea: navy blue, Biarritz blue, golden sand, salmon pink and foam white.

WASHINGTON, May 24-- George E. Doying, retired public utilities editor of The United States News and World Report, died last night of cancer at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Martha Harrison, Rockville, Md., after an illness of many months. His age was 69.

Many boxes have been reserved for the fourth annual entertainment, known as the Salute to Summer, to be held this afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the building fund, clinic care, research and education at Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

Redelivery notices will be sent out by the National Shipping Authority within the next few weeks on Victory-type vessels that were bareboat chartered to private companies for urgent stop-gap operation in the movement of Economic Cooperation Administrationfinanced cargoes.

The invisible finger of radar stabbed through the harbor and waterway system of the city yesterday, locating scores of craft in the first official testing of the Port of New York Authority's experimental harbor radar information center.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, May 24--The Chinese and North Korean Commu nists are making "a precipitous withdrawal" after a severe defeat in round two of their spring offensive and troops of the United Nations are again taking the initiative in the Korean war, Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet said today.

The net earnings of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), in the first quarter of this year were about $48,000,000, or $1.86 a share, A. T. Proudfit, president, told the stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. He said the company's

PHILADELPHIA, May 24--The engineer of the Pennsylvania Railroad's Red Arrow was quoted today as saying that "something had gone wrong" with the signal panel in the cab of his locomotive just before the Detroit-to-New York flier ran into the rear of the stopped Philadelphia Night Express.

WASHINGTON, May 24--President Truman urged Congress in a special message today to appropriate $8,500,000,000 for military and economic foreign aid in a global mutual security program designed to end "Communist dreams of world conquest."

WASHINGTON, May 24--The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives reported today that the 12 per cent increase in personal income taxes, which it approved yesterday, would apply as well to the present maximum rate on capital gains of individuals.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active again yesterday. The market turned weak and closed 15 to 51 points net lower.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Sharp increases in the reserves of stainless steel products which steel mills must set aside for defense uses were ordered for the third quarter by the National Production Authority today.

Despite substantially larger tax charges, the Chain Belt Company increased its net profit in the six months ended with April to $1,098,020 from the $668,477 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year.
TOKYO, Friday, May 25 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 894, issued at 9:40 A.M., Friday (7:40 P.M., Thursday, Eastern daylight time):
ALBANY, May 24--The Public Service Commission refused today to accept a large block of evidence submitted by the New York Telephone Company to support its request for a $44,000,000 rate increase.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 24 (UP)-- Big Ten athletic directors today banned prior announcement of football officials' names next fall in a more that followed closely unfounded charges that a conference official was guilty of irregularities.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Frank Wright Tuttle, a $3,000-a-week director who made nearly seventy motion pictures, testified voluntarily before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that he was a member of the Communist party for ten years before he realized communism was an international conspiracy.
One of the maritime industry's outstanding authorities on North Atlantic passenger travel, George C. Gaede, has retired as vice president of American Export Lines, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, May 24 (UP)--Dick Savitt of Orange, N. J., led three other American men into the third round while two United States women tennis players gained the secand round in singles today at the French international championships.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24-- Stanley Kramer has concluded arrangements for Fredric March to star in the screen version of "Death of a Salesman," which Kramer will produce at Columbia, the studio announced today. Negotiations are

FREEPORT, L.I., May 24-- From Montauk to Freeport, and taking in such by-points as Peconic, Shinnecock and Moriches Bays, fishing boats lay at their docks today, and anglers sat around in bars, diners and boathouses bemoaning the faith that had led them to believe the weather forecast.
Intensified competition in television broadcasting was foreseen yesterday by industry officials as a result of the plan to merge the American Broadcasting Company and United Paramount Theatres, Inc.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 24--A "major advance" has been made by the National Cancer Institute in the "laboratory attack on problems of thyroid cancer," it was reported here today.
HOUSTON, May 24--The National Association of Building, Owners and Managers went on record today in strong opposition to proposed Federal control of commercial rents, even as a defense measure.

Bids have been asked of a dozen East Coast shipyards by George G. Sharp, naval architect, for the conversion of "one or two" C--4 type cargo ships to bulk ore carriers for service next year on the Great Lakes.

Loans to business by banks in this area reversed their upward movement last week, and declined $52,000,000, virtually canceling their recent advance. The decline, which brought business loans outstanding to a total of $6,716,000,000, cut the--net increase in such loans since the first of this year to $411,000,000, against a decline of $260,000,000 in the same period last year.

One of the few remaining private homes on Madison Avenue south of Seventy-second Street passed to new control yesterday when Frederick Brown resold the five-story dwelling at 837 Madison Avenue, between Sixty-ninth and Seventieth Streets, to Irving Kirschenbaum, an attorney. Louis

The marriage of Miss Eugenie Katherine Mullaney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene ,Liguri Mullaney of 131 East Sixty-sixth Street, to Harold Oakley Barker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barker of 765 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L. L, took place yesterday afternoon in the Friars' Chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP)-- The Kremlin's grip on the Soviet Union could be weakened severely, if not loosened completely, by American cooperation with "millions of Soviet dissidents" in that country, a Government survey reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (UP)-- Four individual defending champions and the relay team of New York University begin their bids to retain 1950 titles in the trials of the Seventy-fifth Diamond Jubilee I.C. 4-A track and field meet at Franklin Field tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Warning that the United States would be a "battlefront" if a third World War should occur, President Truman appealed today to all Americans to offer prayers for enduring peace at 11 A.M. (Eastern daylight time) on Memorial Day, next Wednesday.

The world's first fleet of jet airliners is expected to go into regular service on the London-RomeCairo route this winter. British Overseas Airways Corporation will switch from piston engine planes to 490-mile-an-hour De Havilland Comet Jets, of which fourteen have been ordered.

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP)--Rookie Joe Presko turned in a five-hit pitching job as the Cardinals walloped the Reds by 11-3 tonight before 9,443 fans. Presko pitched hitless ball for six and one-third innings and had a one-hitter going into the ninth.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Opposition to the extension of famine relief to India crumbled today as the House passed, 293 to 94, a bill to make a loan of $190,000,000 available to India for the purchase of grain and other foods in this country.

In the fall of 1943 a German journalist, whose current job as editor of a Berlin publishing house specializing in art books did not keep him busy, began to write a long novel about the life of the slaves on board the Nazi ship of state.

The owner of an old-law tenement on the Lower East Side paid a $250 fine yesterday and escaped a ten-day workhouse term on her guilty plea in Municipal Term Court to a charge of maintaining a nuisance by having a leaky gas refrigerator.

SAYVILLE, L.I., May 24--Suffolk County's Republican leadership battle was renewed today as Supervisor Charles H. Duryea coupled an announcement of his own retirement from public office at the end of his present term with a call for the replacement of W. Kingsland Macy as county chairman.

The New York Teachers Guild, A.F.L., will start action in New York Supreme Court to challenge the validity of the Board of Education's new by-laws that require teachers to perform extracurricular services under penalty of possible dismissal, it was disclosed yesterday.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 25--Mrs. Melvin Scharf of Glen Oaks scored 89--14--75 to win low net laurels in the first one-day tournament of the Women's CrossCountry Golf Association at Wheatley Hills today. Seventy-nine competed.

BUFFALO, May 25 (AP)--The chairman of the State Board of Regents' Committee on Television said today that the board "must not be misled by the acclaim" given to its plan for an educational television network.

CHICAGO, May 25--Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson declared in effect today that the Government's entire price control program would very nearly stand or fall on the fate of the Federal effort to reduce the price of beef. "Beef has become a symbol of the whole price control program," ...

A special exhibit of flower arrangements may be seen in the bookshop of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street, today and tomorrow. Although the flowers and foliage are typical of gardens in this part of the country in May, ...

Of the commodities with futures markets in New York, only cocoa followed the grains into higher ground. Even sugar, which had been running against the downward trend for a few days, broke abruptly on word that Philippine raw Sugars had been sold at 15 cents a hundredweight less than on Thursday.

Dedicated to the friendship and solidarity of the United States, Argentina, Peru and Chile, an equestrian statue of Gen. Jose de San Martin, a liberator of the South American republics, was unveiled yesterday on Central Park South near the Avenue of the Americas.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- A Congressional investigating subcommittee branded the defense loan and tax incentive program today "the biggest bonanza that ever came down the Government pike."

PARIS, May 25 (AP)--Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, fourth-ranked United States player, was upset in the third round of the French international tennis championships today by Vladimir Cernik, selfexiled Czechoslovak star, 6--3, 8--6, 6--3.
WASHINGTON, May 25--The Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the registration of a $5,400,000 issue of first mortgage bonds due 1971.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, May 25 --(UP)--Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N.C., and Charles Coe of Oklahoma City, two former U.S. amateur champions, fought their way into the final round of the British amateur golf championship today with two victories each and will meet tomorrow at thirtysix holes in the second straight All-American final.
RICHMOND, Va., May 25 (UP)-- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Puller of the Marine Corps made the following formal statement today at his home at Saluda, Va.:
A chain store's idea of the latest in "supermarketing" stands at 116th Street and Lexington Avenue--a Safeway that opened about three months ago, one of fortythree in Manhattan and 138 in the state.

Sales on the second day of Mayfair Outfitting Company's public auction sale to dispose of television receivers, refrigerators and other appliances were few. Gerard I. Nierenberg, attorney for the company, said yesterday attendance never exceeded 300 from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

Jews in Poland, Hungary and Rumania have been largely pauperized by the Communist regimes in those countries and are now being subjected to a reign of terror aimed at eradicating Zionist sentiment and discouraging emigration to Israel, the American Jewish Committee reports.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The Wage Stabilization Board, reversing an earlier ruling, decided today that wage increases made to comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act were not chargeable against the 10 per cent limit on wage rises. In fact, the wage and hour increase may go into the base rate before the 10 per cent is computed.

Assistant District Attorney Julius A. Helfand charged yesterday that Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh, while Commissioner of Investigation, hampered two Kings County grand juries that sought to inquire into alleged police laxity and corruption.

Formal approval of an agreement with about eighty East and Gulf Coast steamship operators which will provide guaranteed industry-wide vacation pay for members of the Seafarers International Union, A.F.L., was announced yesterday by Paul Hall, first vice president.

CHICAGO, May 25--Active buying of wheat was motivated today by the passage by the House in Washington of the Indian wheat bill and by concern over the situation in the Near East. Other grains were influenced by wheat, and, in the case of corn, the small receipts stimulated buying, especially of the July position.
Thirteen brown manila envelopes containing a total of $3,995 in cash were distributed yesterday in Brooklyn Police Headquarters as the final act in a strange bonanza case with a tragic background.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O., threatened today a strike of 51,000 Westinghouse employes unless the company agreed to submit a dispute to the Wage Stabilization Board and to accept its decision as binding.
WASHINGTON, May 25--Presi dent Truman said tonight that "Hitler and Mussolini never had anything to match the terrible secret police of the Kremlin."

Besides helping to clarify American policies, the Senate hearings on the dismissal of General MacArthur are making it possible for the nation to become more closely acquainted with the top men who preside over its destinies and make decisions that may involve life or death.

Stockholders of the General Motors Corporation at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday defeated proposals to rotate the place of the meeting and to impose a ceiling of $200,000 yearly on the amount of compensation paid to the corporation's officers. They also re-elected all directors.

LONDON, May 25--About 4,000 British paratroopers, who have been held in readiness for foreign service during London's dispute with Teheran over the British oil concession in Iran, will be sent to the Mediterranean in the near future. Their destination was announced by the Ministry of Defense today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25--Inspired by the presence of their flashy rookie star, Willie Mays, the Giants rallied for five runs in the eighth inning tonight to flatten Eddie Sawyer's Phillies, 8 to 5, before 21,082 spectators.
EVANSTON, Ill., May 25 (AP)-- The Big Ten voted today to extend the Rose Bowl football series in the manner proposed by the Pacific Coast Conference, which has lost five straight Pasadena classics.

Some of the biggest sellers of copper and brass throughout the country said yesterday that they have stopped accepting new orders or products based upon the domestic ceiling price for copper of 24 cents a pound, because Chilean copper is being sold here at 27 cents.
WASHINGTON, May 25--The House Ways and Means Committee completed tentative voting today on an omnibus tax bill calculated to add $7,100,000,000 or more in annual revenues to help finance rearmament.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 25-- Under warm, sunny skies, eightytwo women turned out for the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the hilly Echo Lake Country Club course today.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, told the House Agriculture Committee today that if beef cattlemen came to him and proved that the price rollback was causing serious hardship he would modify the order.
GLASGOW, Ky., May 25--Vice President Alben W. Barkley tonight urged young people to "shoulder greater responsibilities in this complex century."

LONDON, May 25--Signs of moderation in the Iranian situation and the successes of the United Nations troops in Korea stimulated most of the stock markets here today, including even that for British Government securities. Prices rose quietly although the usual week-end leveling off of the books caused some irregularity.

America means many things to many people. To the Chinese boy working eleven hours a day and six days a week in a cotton-weaving factory in Hong Kong, America was "Gum Sun" (the Gold Mountain), "a jewel in the horizon"--the proverbial land of freedom and opportunity.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Some 100,000 small retail establishments selling non-food items were given the right today to remain under controls imposed by the general price "freeze" of last January if they wish.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 25-- Students and faculty members of Rolling College here plunged into bitter debate over the recent dismissal of Dr. Paul A. Wagner, its 33-year-old president, were amaiting action by Gov. Fuller Warren today on a bill requiring that trustees of the school be Florida residents.
