ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, Korea, May 25 (AP)--Eighteen marines and one United States soldier, thin, dirty and hungry, returned today to United Nations lines after six months of Communist imprisonment and marches over most of North Korea.
CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)--Home runs by Ralph Kiner and George Metkovich, a five-run inning and five-hit pitching by Murry Dickson today gave the Pirates a 10-1 victory over the Cubs.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Grace of Brooklyn and Greenlawn, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Marea Edwina, to George Frederick Jurett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jurett of Spokane, Wash., and Woods Hole, Mass.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)--A House committee heard today that the General Motors Corporation's locomotive-building division got two steel allotments in March while four other concerns got none.

CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP)--The amazing Chicago White Sox ran their victory string to eight tonight by beating the Cleveland Indians, 6 to 4, Eddie Robinson and Phil Masi clouted homers for the White Sox off Bob Lemon, who went down to his fourth straight defeat.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 25-- Off on the first distance yacht race of the year in northern waters the fleet gathered by the Storm Trysail Club left tonight on the contest around Block Island. The course will be 175 miles with the finish off the Fairway bell buoy at the entrance to the harbor of Port Jefferson, L.I.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 10 points off to 3 points up.
DENVER, May 25--The Democratic National Committee decided unanimously today to hold its 1952 Presidential nominating convention in Chicago in the week beginning July 21.

Mayor Impellitteri decided yesterday to retain in office City Treasurer Spencer C. Young, whose removal was demanded last February by the Citizens Union. The demand came a few days after a New York County grand jury had accused Mr. Young's office of lack of "ordinary diligence" in failing to detect and prevent serious irregularities in connection with city sales of real estate tax liens.

John Golden's Broadway production plans for next season include "Home at Seven" a comic-melodrama by R.C. Sheriff, which closed recently in London. The veteran producer has arranged to have it tested this summer at the Berkshire Playhouse in ...

WASHINGTON, May 25--James F. Brownlee, widely known in business and Government circles, is reported to have been chosen to replace Sidney Weinberg as special assistant to Defense Mobilizer Charles E. Wilson.

James Carter, an unknown lightweight less than four months ago, became the world champion of his division last night. The sturdy Negro resident of the Bronx gained that eminence at Madison Square Garden by stopping Ike Williams of Trenton in the fourteenth round of a scheduled fifteen-round contest.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Vs., May 25--The manufacturing facilities for thermoplastics will increase 10 to 20 per cent this year, Mahlon G. Milliken, vice president of the Hercules Powder Company, said today.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist Area, American co-president of the World Council of Churches, has been named by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America to represent its 32,000,000 communicants next month at a festival in Greece celebrating the 1,900th anniversary of the arrival in that country of St. Paul, the Apostle.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25--A death toll of at least fifteen appeared likely tonight as a result of the capsizing of a crowded Navy liberty launch in the rough waters of Newport Harbor soon after dawn yesterday.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur emphatically denied last night that he ever had been "ordered" to keep United States troops from the Yalu River, separating Korea and Communist China.

Another work was added to the growing list of contemporary Jewish liturgical scores when David Diamond's Sacred Service fon the Sabbath Eve had its premiere last night at the Park Avenue Synagogue. The cantor was David J. Putterman, the synagogue choir was directed by Max Helfman, and Isidor Geller was at the organ.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 25-- The Israeli Army was reported here today to have moved artillery into Israel's defensive zone on the Israeli side of the demilitarized zone on the Syrian-Israeli frontier. As the caliber of artillery that can be placed in the defensive zone is restricted under the terms ...
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25--Opposition to the proposed withholding tax on bank interest and dividends was expressed here today by more than 1,200 New Jersey bankers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25--The Soviet Union charged today that the new United States proposal for merging the United Nations disarmament and atomic energy bodies into one commission was another move that had "war as its main purpose."
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 25 (UP)--The seventh in a series of anti-newspaper measures to be introduced in the Florida Legislature was aimed today at The Miami Herald and its publisher, John S. Knight.
A controlling interest in the Empire State Building, the world's tallest structure, is passing into new ownership, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The House Committee on Un-American Activities heard Jose Ferrer, 1950 Motion Picture Academy Award winner, reiterate today that he was not and had not been a member of the Communist party.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman said last night that the "great debate" over foreign policy has filled the free world with fear that we might "slip into" the policies advocated by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

ARDEN, N.Y., May 25--The first conference of the American Assembly of Columbia University ended tonight with a declaration that the strengthening of Western Europe was of first importance to the United States in the defense of the world freedom against Soviet aggression and slavery.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25-- The Board of Regents of the University of California took action today which, in effect, would eradicate the special loyalty oath it decreed for all faculty members and university employes two years ago.

An issue of $1,430,000 of bonds of Community High School District No. 155 of McHenry County, Ill., was posted for sale yesterday. Bids will be received on June 15. The bonds will be dated May 15, 1951, and will be due on Dec. 15, 1952 to 1970.

CHICAGO, May 25--Arthur A. Schuck of Short Hills, N.J., Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, said here today that boys of this generation would be expected to show more character and self-reliance than was expected of boys of the past.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 (AP)--Finnish fencer Ilmari Vartia, wounded in the opening round of the world championship men's epee competition here today, died while being taken to a hospital.

ST. LOUIS, May 25 (AP)--Connie Ryan whacked a grand-slam home run to the deep left centerfield seats in the eleventh inning to give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight before 11,922 fans. The big blow was off relief pitcher Red Munger.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 25-- The unofficial tribunal set up in Brussels to inquire into concentration camp systems ended today its "trial" of the Soviet Union's system with evidence of ill treatment and mass deaths even more damaging to the absent "defendant," the Soviet Government, than any given at previous hearings.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25--The Health Resources Advisory Committee Office of Defense Mobilization, has estimated a shortage of 22,200 physicians, 9,200 dentists and 49,200 nurses by 1954 for the task of meeting military and civilian demands for health manpower.

NEWARK, May 25--Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in an all-night round-up arrested five men in this area, one of them a bank branch manager, on charge of conspiracy to dispose of stolen Canadian bonds in interstate transportation.

A report calling for "great improvement" in the facilities and operations of the city's school lunch program, transmitted to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, earlier this year, was made public yesterday at the annual meeting of the Public Health Association of New York City.

From all reports, the interest of British investing institutions in the new issue of sterling bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development promises to be rivaled substantially by the interest of non-British investors, especially those whose blocked ...

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 25-- The child development program at Florida State University, believed to be the only one of its kind in the South, is now in its sixth year of compiling research material designed to "show ways of improving our society."

PANAMA, May 25--Panama's National Assembly sustained tonight by a unanimous vote the charge that former President Arnulfo Arias had violated the Constitution. He was barred for life from holding any office or public position.

Confidence men posing as Office of Price Stabilization special agents have defrauded several Brooklyn butchers, the storekeepers complained to the regional O.P.S. office yesterday. By using "high pressure" tactics, the racketeers induced the storekeepers to pay for unnecessary signs indicating they had met certain O.P.S. requirements.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 25--Miss Elizabeth Klugescheid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Klugescheid of Bronxville, was married here this evening to Ralph Henderson Alexander Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander of Charlotte, N.C., formerly of Bronxville, in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Wilmot. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond E. Brock. There was a reception at the American Yacht Club, Milton Point, Rye.
GENEVA, May 25--Western Germany has refused to submit a proposal for allocating Ruhr coal exports among the receiving countries for the third quarter of 1951.

BUENOS AIRES, May 25-- About 200,000 Argentines paraded through this capital's streets today while several hundred thousand more watched the celebration of the 141st anniversary of Argentina's Independence Day.

CHICAGO, May 25--Jewish women throughout the country have contributed $7,663,277 since Jan. 1 to the United Jewish Appeal, the principal agency in this country for support of immigration, settlement and rehabilitation programs in Israel and other parts of the world.

This morning's new film at the Globe is "Inside the Walls of Folsom Prison," a Warner Brothers melodrama, written and directed by Crane Wilbur and produced by Bryan Foy. Steve Cochran, David Brian, Philip Carey and Ted de Corsia head the cast.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 25 --Six Mount Vernon teen-agers, including a girl lookout were held in bail of $1,000 each today charged with stealing $2,400 cash and $400 worth of movie film Wednesday night in a well coordinated raid upon the Frederick S. Steinmann Drug Store at 52 Pondfield ...
HOMESTEAD, Fla., May 25 (UP) --A university freshman taking the last test in a fraternity "Hell Week" was crushed to death by a truck early today when he fell asleep on a lonely road.
Ed Lopat, the Yankees' undefeated southpaw, won his eighth straight game at the Stadium last night, but he missed the chance to equal an American League record.

The stock market made a feeble and somewhat unsuccessful effort yesterday to repair the damage suffered during the previous sessions this week. Although the composite rate showed a rise of 0.05 point on the day and the issues showing gains outnumbered ...

A total of 2,573 dogs and possibly ten times that many persons interested in them will be at Giralda Farms, Madison, N.J., today for the nation's foremost bench show outdoors. It's the twentyfirst event of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, whose chief personage is Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, owner of the farm.
CHICAGO, May 25 (U.P.)--A controversy boiled today between two National Guard generals about General MacArthur.

ALBANY, May 25--The cost of educating a public school pupil in New York City has increased 76.7 per cent in the last eleven years, a study made by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, Inc., a state-wide taxpayers group, revealed today.

Seven 3-year-olds, including George D. Widener's Battlefield and Hal Price Headley's Jumbo, are in today's seventy-sixth running of the Withers Stakes at Belmont Park. The record for the mile race is 1:35 4-5. There's a good chance, if the track stays fast, that a new mark will go into the books.
RIO DE JANIERO, May 25 (UP)--President Getulio Vargas asked Congress today for special powers over Brazil's economic life in an effort to arrest spiraling inflation and bring down the cost of living.

A contrast between youthful participants in local gang warfare and the efforts of embattled American youths in Korea was drawn sharply yesterday by Magistrate Peter M. Horn in Queens Felony Court, Ridgewood.

NEW DELHI, India, May 25-- In deference to the wishes of a large number of Congress party members in Parliament, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has substantially modified the Constitution amendment bill that seeks to place limitations on freedom of speech and expression.

The three top-ranking students in Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism received 1951 Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships yesterday. The awards, which are made annually on the nomination of the faculty of the school, are worth $1,500 each and enable the recipients to study the foreign press.

New York's young people are facing a prolonged crisis in life and work adjustment under the pressures of national mobilization, according to a report presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the Vocational Advisory Service's managing board.

The artist's responsibility and his role in a changing society was the theme of an address yesterday by Mark Van Doren, writer, poet and teacher, at the annual joint ceremonial of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

CINCINNATI, May 25--A ninepoint program of interchurch cooperation looking towards the eventual reunion of this country's three largest Presbyterian denominations was unanimously approved here today by the 163d General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The possibility that the United States has made at least the preparatory steps toward development and explosion of a hydrogen bomb was disclosed today by the Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Defense.

Net earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd. and its subsidiaries in the March quarter differed slightly from the previous three months, but were $6,402,375 above the first quarter of 1950.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 25 (AP)--Ben Hogan blew cool today but not enough to lose his lead in the $15,000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament as he scored a one-over-par 71 to make his 36-hole total 139.

Plans for converting the fivestory house at 61 East Seventyfifth Street, adjoining the corner of Park Avenue, into ten apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the property by Mrs. Celia S. Weinberg to Seymour Reich for investment.

LONDON, May 25--Military and diplomatic experts in London predict that in due course Greece and Turkey will become associated with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization either as members or as beneficiaries of a military guarantee from the United States and other powers.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 25--A field of sixty teams, one of the largest in Westchester P.G.A. history, turned out for the season's opening one-day lady and pro bestball handicap tournament today at the Innis Arden Golf Club.

ROME, May 25--Italian police today announced the discovery of a clandestine neo-fascist ring that had been responsible for many terrorist acts in the last six months. One of the principal fascist leaders and thirty-six other members were arrested.

Unrest among Arab refugees from the new state of Israel is increasing rapidly and constitutes a serious threat not only to the peace of the Near East but of the world, United States delegates to the Beirut refugee conference held earlier this month reported yesterday.

The joint announcement by the Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Defense that the latest test program on atomic weapons at Eniwetok "included experiments contributing to thermonuclear weapons research" definitely does not mean that an actual hydrogen bomb of any size has been exploded.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on May 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The all-commodity index, 182.4 per cent of the 1926 average, was 1.3 per cent above the level of Jan. 23, 1951; 16.3 per cent above the May ...

The engagement of Miss Lydia Thorne Taylor, daughter of Mrs. William J. Lippincott of 1040 Park Avenue and the late James Blackstone Taylor Jr. to Greame Elliott of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. william Elliott of East Hampton, L.I., has been announced by her mother.

The Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., warned yesterday that it would "not answer for the consequences" if the Board of Transportation did not scrap a plan prepared by two engineering concerns for a forty-hour work week on the city's transit lines.

Encountering light to stubborn enemy resistance, United Nations ground forces supported by air strikes advanced in all sectors of the Korean front Friday. Air sightings and ground observation indicate a general enemy withdrawal from forward areas under protection of a strong screening force.

A number of children are improperly diagnosed and put in institutions for the mentally deficient who are not mentally deficient but hard of hearing or unable to speak, Louis M. DiCarlo, associate Professor of Education at Syracuse University, declared yesterday.
Carmine G. DeSapio's position as leader of Tammany was strengthened yesterday when Michael Klein resigned as a leader of the Fourth Assembly District. He will be succeeded by a DeSapio supporter.

LONDON, Saturday, May 26 (AP) --The United States, Britain and France announced today they were forming a three-power commission to work for a fair and orderly settlement of West Germany's debts, estimated at $4,500,000,000.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., May 25 (UP) --Twelve fishermen were reported dead or missing in the Atlantic today after a French trawler had been sunk in a collision with another French ship off Newfoundland's Grand Banks.

An educational draft deferment test, the first of its kind in the history of the United States and the largest mass examination ever held, will take place this morning here and in several other cities.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 25 (AP)-- Don Laz' record-breaking polevault of 14 feet 10 inches, made indoors, paced Illinois to the team title in the rain-drench Big Ten outdoor track and field meet at Dyche Stadium tonight.
GENEVA, May 25--The fourth World Health Assembly unanimously adopted new international sanitary regulations at its concluding session today.

The conflict in Iran is rapidly approaching the point of no return. The Iranian Government, far from receding an inch as the crisis nears a climax, gives the oil company until May 30 to arrange for the transfer of the property.

We deeply regret the series of events that have finally led the Superintendent of Schools and the Board of Education to direct public school teachers to resume extracurricular activities under penalty of facing charges of insubordination and possible dismissal.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25--The Diamond jubilee track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America shaped up as a Cornell landslide tonight, although Manhattan cannot yet be altogether counted out of the race for the team title.

HONG KONG, May 25--Premier and Foreign Minister Chou En-lai has sent a note to Gen. N.V. Roschin, the Soviet Ambassador, registering Communist China's "full support" of the Soviet Union's views on an over-all Japanese peace treaty, Peiping radio reported tonight.

HONG KONG, May 25--Premier and Foreign Minister Chou En-lai has sent a note to Gen. N.V. Roschin, the Soviet Ambassador, registering Communist China's "full support" of the Soviet Union's views on an over-all Japanese peace treaty, Peiping radio reported tonight.

The world can be assured of peace only when the problems of colonialism "are well on their way to solution," Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations Trusteeship Division, said yesterday to 2,000 school children from the New York area.

WASHINGTON, May 25--The Army's Chief of Staff swore today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur sent United States troops to the China frontier region in Korea against the expressed warnings of the high command.

Industrial recovery in Western Germany has been paced by the reactivation of patents and trademarks, according to Dr. Edward Reimer, president of the German Patent Office in Munich. Inventors and business men filed applications during the last year for 52,000 patents and 24,000 trademarks, he said, and 6 per cent of this total came from the United States.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 26-- United Nations troops drove across the Thirty-eighth Parallel at two more points in Korea yesterday. Meanwhile, a task force of the United Nations Tenth Corps widened its bridgehead north of the old political boundary between North and South Korea, pushing toward Inje, in the peninsula's eastern mountains.

WASHINGTON, May 25--Representative Katharine St. George, Republican of New York, told the opening session of the National Woman's Party convention today that its Equal Rights amendment, of which she was sponsor in the House of Representatives, should be approved by this Congress.

It appears now that one more Chines a Communist offensive in Korea has failed disastrously. It is our proclaimed policy to inflict losses on the aggressor so grievous that he will become convinced that his course is the wrong one and will be willing to make a peace. The losses in the latest attack have been heavy, even for a foe that has shown a callous attitude toward the sacrifice of troops.

LONDON, May 25--Following two years of discussions, twelve North Atlantic Treaty countries have agreed on the outline of a plan for pooling their combined merchant shipping in the event of war and allocating it thereafter on a world-wide basis.

A week-end reduction averaging 2 cents a gallon in the retail price of gasoline was forecast yesterday as a result of the lowered wholesale rate put into effect by some of the major oil companies.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- John Maragon, former White House hanger-on, went to jail for perjury today despite his lawyer's plea that he was "only a scapegoat" in a Senate investigation of influence peddling.

ACCORDING to Bob Elliot, who has been skipping from one Maine waterway to another, anyone who lists the fishing up there as being "unusually good" is being guilty of gross understatement, for he insists that in most areas it is "too good to be true."

Judge Harold R. Medina and Government counsel yesterday disputed in Federal Court the significance of the fact that no anti-trust complaints about price-maintenance were brought against securities distributors in the period of nearly twenty years during which such practices were the subject of Congressional legislation and Security and Exchange Commission supervision. The colloquy took place in the trial of the Government's antitrust case against seventeen investment banking houses and the Investment Banking Association of America.

The Rome Cable Corporation completed its fifteenth and biggest year on March 31 with sales and earnings the largest in its history, according to the annual report to be issued to shareholders on Monday.

United Nations forces in Korea, maintaining their pressure on the retreating Communists, advanced across the Thirty-eighth Parallel in two additional places. The enemy offered little resistance from small, scattered rear-guard units. [1:8; map P. 2.]
ITHACA, N.Y., May 26--Harvard crews broke the two-mile West Shore record twice on Cayuga Lake today as they swept a regatta with Cornell.

TELEVISION was born as a medium for "live" entertain ment but, generally, a film recording is made of every "live" commercial show on a network. This film is shipped to stations not linked by the coaxial cable. To feed video's celluloid circuit, the industry this year will require an estimated 550 million feet of film, about one-fourth of Hollywood's consumption.
A thirteen-minute test of the 526 fixed air-raid sirens atop buildings in key sections of the city, augmented by hundreds of Police and Fire Department mobile sirens, was held at noon yesterday.

Mortgage financing amounting to $16,966,000 was announced yesterday for Ivy Hill Park, an apartment development in Newark, N.J., for 2,095 families that will be the first in the area erected under a revised building code permitting the builders to use reinforced concrete in the place of the scarcer and costlier structure steel.

During the course of last week's debate on the Administration's bill to lend India $190,000,000 for the purchase of much-needed grain, Representative Eugene E. Cox, Democrat of Georgia, reproached India for placing an embargo on the export of monazite sands.

IN the Harvard Class of 1893, Billings Learned Hand of Shoreham, Vt., grew a mustache and goatee and was called the "Ancient Mongolian." Then he shaved them, shed his first name, and "nobody could think of a nickname for 'Learned.'"

CINCINNATI, May 26--A budget of $13,429,210 for 1952 was unanimously approved here today by the 163d General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. The figure represents an increase of $1,624,230 over the current budget.
TORONTO, May 26--Major Factor, gelding owned by E.P. Taylor of Toronto, won the ninety-second running of the King's Plate today with a great stretch drive before 35,000 fans at Woodbine.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 --A new telescope camera just acquired by the Harvard College Observatory will track and photograph meteors as small as buckshot.

The near-by July contract on the New York Cotton Exchange registered a net decline of 24 points last week, but new-crop deliveries sagged 122 to 146 points. In the preceding week, the July option gained 20 points, while the more distant months fell 1 to 15 points.

The Daisy Farms development on Wilmot Road in New Rochelle, N.Y., has been acquired by the Berne Construction Company, Inc., of White Plains, which plans the immediate construction of the first group of what is expected to be a 300-home project on 115 acres.

Mrs. Trowbridge Callaway and Mr. John Q. Rowland are cochairman of the committee in charge of arrangements for the annual Summer Day Fair for the benefit of St. Johnland to be held June 28 on the grounds of the community of St. Johnland near Kings Park, L.I.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 26-- Federal officials have made a small but noteworthy start to check the employment on Southwestern farms of wetback Mexican nationals who have illegally filtered across the 1,600-mile international boundary from the Pacific Coast to the mouth of the Rio Grande.
A SETTING of fine jewelry will provide the background for the seventh annual Garden State Flower Show of the Garden Club of New Jersey, which will be held on June 6 and 7.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 26--Bitterly attacking the "menace of reviving nazism" in Germany, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, United States Assistant High Commissioner, called today for prompt, courageous and forthright action by the German people to check the neo-fascist advance.

DETROIT, May 26 (UP)--The lowly St. Louis Browns handed the Detroit Tigers their fifth straight setback, 3 to 2, at Briggs Stadium this afternoon. Southpaw Bill Kennedy scattered eight Detroit hits effectively as he recorded his first victory of the season.

ONE of the omissions in the Schumann diskography was an up-to-date recording of Papillons (Op. 2). Recently a pair of versions has been released almost simultaneously. One recording comes from Vox, with Guiomar Novaes at the piano. The other, from Columbia, features Gyorgy Sandor.

A number of children given up as "hopelessly" retarded in mentality have been materially helped after training, medication and psychotherapy, it was reported yesterday at the closing session of the seventy-fifth annual convention of the American Association on Mental Deficiency.

CASTING shows for television is a more ticklish proposi tion than the average viewer might suspect. Eleanor Kilgallen and Monique James, who head a casting agency dedicated to relieving the headaches of TV producers, find it an almost twentyfour-hour-a-day job that keeps five telephones and a night answering service busy and plays hob with nerves and social life.

To the music of kilted bagpipers and Irish singers and harpists, the 172d anniversary of the birth of the Irish poet and songwriter, Thomas Moore, was celebrated yesterday by the United Irish Counties Association at his statue in Poet's Corner of Central Park.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26--The casualty list in the capsizing of a Navy Liberty boat in the harbor here Thursday was revised by the Navy today to fifteen dead, three missing and presumed dead and eight others "presumed to be overleave or absent without leave."

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 26 (AP)--A Federal Court suit will open here Monday against South Carolina's segregated schools. At issue, for the first time anywhere, is whether segregating white and Negro children at the public school level is unconstitutional. A threejudge Federal Court will hear the arguments.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 26--Despite the fact that the fighting in Korea took on new vigor at the end of the week, the belief is almost unanimous here that the present limited war cannot continue much longer.

Plans for a community of 300 ranch homes to meet the demand for housing by moderate-income groups were announced yesterday by Lakeville Manor, Inc., which has opened two models on Merrick Road (Montauk Highway), two miles east of Bayshore, L.I. The development is called Oakhaven Estates and will represent an investment of about $2,250,000.

Two new homes colonies are planned in the Bergen County section of New Jersey where acreage sites have been acquired in Allendale and Hillsdale by Carl C. Low Sons. Prices will range from $21,000 to $22,000.

To replace the National Assembly elected in 1946, France is to have national parliamentary elections on June 17. The Assembly chosen five years ago was by proportional representation under a law adopted soon after the liberation. The result was an Assembly with seven major party divisions, the two largest of which were the Communists with 28 per cent of the members and the MRP, party of fornner Premier Bidault, with about the same number.

BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP)-- Jeannie C., owned and trained by her breeder, Alan T. Clarke, sprinted to a two-and-a-half length victory in the $5,000-added Havre De Grace Breeders' Stake, feature of today's final program at Pimlico.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP)-- Philadelphia's La Salle High School won the American scholastic eightoared championship and two other United States titles in today's finals of the seventeenth annual Schoolboy Rowing Association regatta on the Schuylkill River.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 26-- When several top-ranking army generals stepped in to form a junta after President Mamerto Urrilagoitia had resigned, and to abrogate the election of May 6, which had been held to choose the President's successor, they were only following an old Bolivian custom.

TWO of the newly opened exhibitions in local institutions reveal with special clarity how the winds of change have blown through the art world in the last generation. Sharon Springs, N.Y., upstate rural village of about 400 population, has been chosen as the site of the Seventh Annual State Institute on Community Leadership, to be held May 30-June 2. U. marathon title today. Coming from far back to win, he covered the rain-lashed 26-mile 385-yard course in the good time of 2 hours 37 minutes 12.5 seconds.

ASHDOT YAACOV, Israel, May 27--This is one of the loveliest kibbutzim in Israel. It lies nearly 200 meters (approximately 660 feet) below sea level in the sun-drenched Jordan Valley and its 1,000 acres of fertile fields bear rich crops of grapes, bananas and vegetables. Its canning and preserving factory is one of the country's largest.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today broadened its ruling that witnesses before Federal grand juries might refuse to testify if they feared self-incrimination. PALISADES, N.Y., May 28-- Columbia University dedicated its Lamont Geological Observatory today to the promotion of free scientific inquiry and pledged that within a few years its laboratories would make "revolutionary" contributions of service both to the nation and the academic community.
The Carrier Corporation, manufacturers of air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment, achieved new sales and earnings records in the twelve month ended with April, the report revealed yesterday.

THE ill wind that troubled the Long Islanders during the past few days seems to have brought unusually fine fishing for the New Jersey coastal fishermen, who have been hauling in bluefish and striped bass with delight and abandon.

Commodity markets continued weak yesterday. Sugar, vegetable oils, cocoa and wool futures dropped substantially. On the New York futures markets only coffee was undecided, but even there losses outnumbered the gains.

Queena Maric, lyric soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera Company from 1922 to 1938, died yesterday at the home of a niece, Mrs. Claude Geiser of 78 Irving Place, after a long illness, at the age of 54.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 28 (AP)--The Eastern Air Defense Force announced today that 210,000 civilian volunteer members will undergo night training in plane spotting on June 23 and 24.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 29--The United Nations advance rolled slowly forward into North Korea yesterday, meeting stiffened resistance on the eastern and central fronts, where advance guards probed toward Chinese and North Korean reserve areas.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The highest air officer of this country declared today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's rejected policy for bombing Communist China might have left the United States "naked" before the Soviet Union.

CINCINNATI, May 28--A move to revise drastically the supreme authority of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.--the Confession of Faith--in order to clarify the Church's stand on marriage and divorce, was approved here today by the denomination's 163d general assembly.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)-- Archie Hindman, president of the National Boxing Association, announced today that an N.B.A. world championship certificate had been forwarded to Jimmy Carter of New York.

FRANKFORT, Germany, May 28--Twin jet bombers began to replace the old Ilyushin bombers of the Soviet Air Force in East Germany recently as part of the systematic rebuilding program aimed at giving the Russians more and better planes than the Allies in Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 28--Senate and House conferees agreed today on a continuation of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements prograan for two more years, until June 12, 1953, but with prohibitions against lowering tariffs on imports from Russia and her satellites so severe that existing treaties and agreements face abrogation.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The Appalachian Electric Company, Roanoke, Va., applied to the Securittes and Exchange Commission today for approval for issues of stocks and bonds amounting to $27,500,000.

An American edition of "Umberto's Circus," a novel by the Czechoslovak writer Eduard Bass, will be issued by Farrar, Straus Young on June 20. It is a story about life in a traveling European circus in the late nineteenth century. Mr. Bass, who died in 1946,

Retail prices of 5,978 items fixed by the Feld-Crawford (New York State "Fair Trade") Act will be reduced 6 per cent today by Macy's New York. All merchandise to be offered at lower prices will be nationally advertised goods, Richard Weil Jr., president, announced yesterday.

PARIS, May 28 (UP)--Top-ranking United States military leaders and diplomats conferred today on strategy to be used in breaking the threat of Russian aggression and ending the deadlock of the deputies of the Big Four foreign ministers.
HOLLYWOOD, May 28 (AP)-- How old was Al Jolson when he died? The answer is worth $122,000.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 28-- Angry nationalist sentiment was getting the better today of the initial favorable reaction to President Truman's announcement of the inclusion of the Arab world in the United States economic aid program, and his hint that the Arabs might be included in the military aid program.

TOKYO, May 28--Reports reaching G-2, United States Army intelligence section and Embassy officials here indicate that, despite enormous casualties, the morale of the Chinese Communist troops is still good, though it has slumped somewhat because of two major setbacks in six weeks.

The failure of the public to understand changing concepts of education is one of the major problems confronting the city's school system, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday at the Education Writers Institute held at Columbia University.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 28-- A best-ball round of 65 was the winning score in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro handicap tourney at the Brookville Country Club today, in which seventy-six teams competed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 28--A North Korean statement was released here today charging that the captured documents submitted by the United States to pin the starting of the war on North Korea were "a poor and clumsy concoction."
MILWAUKEE, May 28 (AP)-- Heavyweight Rex Layne floored Odell Riley of Detroit twice tonight before he caught him with an overhand right in the sixth round to end the fight.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The Supreme Court rejected today an attack on the Virginia poll tax law by affirming a lower court decision that the statute did not violate the Constitution.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 28 --Luck and influence today ran out on Joe Adonis, the former Brooklyn hoodlum who had enjoyed immunity from jail sentence during a twenty-five-year rise to affluence, political ties and high rank in the underworld.

Horne, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, that civil aviation would be used to "the fullest advantage" should the national emergency become more acute.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 28-- In an unexpected parliamentary maneuver, the state legislature dealt a damaging blow late today to Dr. Paul A. Wagner, deposed president of Rollins College here, in his fight for re-instatement.

MEXICO CITY, May 28--A fear that the United States defense program may involve heavy spending by the Good-Neighbor countries to the detriment of their economic development was expressed today at the opening of the fourth conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 28-- Warren R. Austin, United States delegate to the United Nations, said tonight that our government would soon state the type and strength of armed forces it would maintain for service as United Nations units.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The Treasury Department announces a new type of certificate of indebtedness with a maturity of nine and one-half months in disclosing plans today for refinancing more than $10,000,000,000 of outstanding bonds and Treasury notes.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (UP)-- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, told President Truman today the Administration's loyalty program now was "basically sound" and made clear that he would continue his opposition to the President's Nimitz Loyalty Commission.

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (UP)--Red Schoendienst's single with the bases loaded and two out in the tenth inning gave the Cardinals a 6-5 victory over the Pirates tonight and, with it, second place. Outfielder Gus Bell apparently lost...

WASHINGTON, May 28--The Senate (Fulbright) subcommittee investigating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation stated today that there "undoubtedly" had been instances in which members of Congress had put the lending agency under pressure on behalf of loan applicants.

JERUSALEM, May 28--The Knesset (Parliament) elected a committee today to investigate charges of police mistreatment of an Orthodox religious group detained under an administrative order in connection with an alleged plot to sabotage the Knesset.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., May 28-- The Westchester Professional Golfers Association's weekly pro-amateur best ball tournament today at the Vernon Hills country club brought out a field of eighty-two teams despite the threatening weather and cold winds.
WITH THE U. . SECOND DIVISION, Korea, May 28--Sgt. Claiborne W. Hodges of Wilmington, Va., strapped on a .45 pistol yesterday and went hunting. He brought back 112 Communist prisoners.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., May 28--Trucks toured this sprawling 15,000-home community today collecting food for orphanages in famine-stricken areas of India. At the end of the day, three tons of dried and canned foods had been brought to the home of Mrs. Irwin N. Pollock at 6 Knoll Lane, although only one of the community's six areas had been canvassed. TAEGU, Korea, May 28--The people of South Korea were told today to stop singing their favorite songs--Japanese melodies--in restaurants and tea rooms because these lilting tunes were undermining the "wholesome spirit" needed by a nation at war.

CHICAGO, May 28--The splendid growing conditions now prevailing in ail principal grain area. proved a handicap to bulls today and, with a further slump in soybeans to unsettle the market and nervousness over peace talk resulting from United Nations successes in Korea, the trend of prices was downward.

WASHINGTON, May 28 --Dr. George W. Taylor, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, today favored continued operation of the escalator clauses in wage contracts even if they pierced the 10 per cent ceiling for wage increases established by the board.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28--The last six places in the thirty-threecar field for the 500-mile Memorial Day race were filled today and when the roar of the supercharged motors had faded the highest overall record in the history of the speedway had been recorded.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 28-- Experts in the fields of education and psychology testified in a crowded Federal Court here today that under the South's segregated school systems the children of both races suffer basic personality damage that ultimately endangers the welfare of the nation.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The Supreme Court removed today the final legal block to introducing commercial color television.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 28-- The Connecticut General Assembly got into a tangle today over legislation to control natural gas pipe line companies in this state.

YONKERS, May 28--Miss Elsa Riesenberg and Sidney Riesenberg have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Anne Atheling, to George Edward Wendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wendell of Montclair, N.J., and Rockport, Mass. The wedding will take place in September.

Plans for safeguarding the city water system as a defense measure were announced yesterday by Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. He said he was preparing to recruit by July 1 a force of guards to patrol the Catskill and Croton watersheds.

The Giants will make another attempt to move into first division company in the National League race while the world champion Yankees seek to return to the American League lead in two of the eight mayor league doubleheaders booked for the Memorial Day program today.

CHICAGO, May 29--Pursuing the campaign by which he hopes to rival the unprecedented twentyfive title defenses of Joe Louis, Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro, places his share of the world heavyweight championship on the line again here tomorrow night, in the Stadium.

LONDON, May 29--Britain's willingness to consider "some form of nationalization" of the British oil properties in Iran was officially confirmed by Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison today. That compromise proposal, a major concession from Britain, already has been conveyed to the Iranian Government.
TRENTON, May 29--Joe Adonis, big name gambling figure of the New York metropolitan area, became just another inmate of the New Jersey State Prison today.

CHANTILLY, France, May 29 (UP)--Robert Knowles Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Bill Campbell of Huntington, W.Vs., led seven Americans into the third round at the French amateur golf championship today but nine other United States players lost or defaulted their opening day matches.

MECICO CITY, May 29--By the end of this year the United States defense program is expected to curtail seriously the goods that Latin-American countries require for their industrial and agricultural development projects already under way.

PARIS. May 29 (UP)--Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., and Straight Clark of Los Angeles, the last United States men's singles hopes in the French international tennis tournament, were eliminated today in the quarterfinals.

HONG KONG, May 29--Just a few weeks ago Wu Shun, a late Ching Dynasty figure who begged in the street for money to build a school, seemed to have been officially confirmed as a folk hero in China. The "Life of Wu Shun," a film produced by Shanghai's Kunlun studio, had won special critical acclaim in the Communist-controlled press.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The Government reported today the general level of farm prices dropped a little more than 1 per cent in the month ended on May 15.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 29 --The Finnish Communist party is now purging its ranks of "deadwood," in view of the general elections scheduled for July 1, reports from reliable Helsinki sources indicate.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 29--A petition for an injunction against the Franklin National Bank of Franklin Square, restraining it from using the words "saving" or "savings" in its publicity and from holding itself out as a savings bank, was dismissed in Supreme Court here today.

School children with uncorrected eyesight defects are five times as likely to fail scholastically as others, according to a report made yesterday at the fifty-sixth annual convention of the New York State Optometric Association.

The withdrawal of thirteen additional ships from the reserve fleet and their allocation to general agents for operation raises to 123 the number of Government-owned vessels in emergency service as of May 19.
Two blocks from Brooklyn Police Headquarters, a 62-year-old bank messenger was shot once under the heart and robbed of $1,370 at 1:40 P.M. yesterday by two armed thugs who escaped by automobile.
The terms of the Treasury's first big summer refunding were well received in the market for Government securities yesterday.

Citizens who have been deprived of their inalienable right to see "Oklahoma!" any time they want to now have nothing to complain about. For the national company, which has been touring since 1943, has settled down at the Broadway Theatre, where it opened last evening.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29-- "The Prisoner of Zenda," Anthony Hope's 1894 Ruritanian novel, will make its third screen appearance, this time with Stewart Granger as the leading man, Metro-GoldwynMayer announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP)-- A State Department spokesman said today he believed the United Nations embargo against the Chinese Communists would spike a British-ordered transfer of forty United States-owned transport planes to the Peiping Government.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, advocated yesterday a more intensive study of science, especially the development of nuclear energy, at Roman Catholic universities. Union and from Communist China.

A holiday originally designed to honor the Union dead of the Civil War has broadened with the passing of the years. We think today of all Americans who fell on our own soil and on other soils in defense of freedom.

CHICAGO, May 29--Ezzard Charles meets Joey Maxim here tomorrow night for the heavyweight championship of the world-- if you'll pardon the use of the expression--and Chicago is going crazy with jubilation. Over the fight? Heavens, no. Over the sensational White Sox, who have won twelve straight and zoomed into first place.

Senator Estes Kefauver urged President Truman yesterday to call a convention of members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to work out some form of limited federation to give unified political backing to General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's forces in Europe.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein denounced officials of the city school system yesterday, charging that they had made premature disclosures of confidential information on the teen-age narcotics problem and had thereby impeded his state-wide inquiry into addiction.

Investment buying featured Manhattan realty activity reported yesterday.

A controversy that has shaken the television industry for five years has been settled by the Supreme Court of the United States--at least for the time being. The court has decided that the Federal Communications Commission has the power to dictate by what technical procedure color-images may be transmitted and received by television.

On Nov. 6 a successor to Vincent Impellitteri as President of the City Council will be elected, to serve until Dec. 31, 1953. The office is now occupied by Joseph T. Sharkey, who moved in when William O'Dwyer's resignation last Sept. 2 made some changes.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 29-- Nearly 10,000 business and professional executives from thousands of communities in sixty countries throughout the world--all Rotarians--were asked today to concentrate on improving employer-employe relationships.

United Nations ground forces continued to advance in Korea yesterday against increasing enemy resistance. In the western sector friendly units made advances up to five miles against light resistance. Strong enemy counter-attacks were repulsed during the advance of United Nations elements in the Hwachon-Inje areas. Along the east coast friendly units continued to advance without opposition.

CINCINNATI, May 29--The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake of Pasadena, Calif., was elected Stated Clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. today by unanimous vote of the 880 commissioners, or delegates, present.

A new national committee to carry out the objectives of the recent Midcentury White House Conference on Children and Youth was organized here yesterday. The group adopted the name of the National Midcentury Committee for Children and Youth.

WASHINGTON, May 29--Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg declared today that the United States had it in its power, by raising a great Air Force, to remove from the world the threat of major war.
The first major price rollbacks under Ceiling Price Regulation 30 of the Office of Price Stabilization have been announced by industrial supply manufacturers, it was disclosed here yesterday.
ROME, May 29--The four-party anti-Communist coalition was retaining its lead late tonight in the administrative elections held last week-end in nearly 3,000 municipalitiles in Northern Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP)-- Assistant Veterans Administrator Harold W. Breining retired today after heading Government insurance operations for more than thirty years, during which time 22,000,000 policies were issued worth almost $170,000,000,000.

WINTER PARK, Fla., May 29-- A reconstituted Board of Trustees of Rollins College announced here this evening after a seven-hour meeting that it had unanimously "reaffirmed, confirmed and ratified" the dismissal of Dr. Paul A. Wagner as the institution's president.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP)-- The Federal Government authorized price increases for many whisky retailers today but assured consumers slack market conditions probably would absorb the rise.
The United States, fighting in Korea and arming against the danger of a new world war, will pause today to honor its service men who died in previous wars.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 29--The trial of three men and one woman accused of espionage on behalf of the Czechoslovak Government began today in a Belgrade military court.

Father Tiber of the Phantom Farm lasted just long enough to win the Smithtown, the one-mile race that served as the star attraction at Belmont Park yesterday. THIS first week of June finds many of the rose bushes in full regalia here in New York City.

In Solomon he has found a character peculiarly suited to his talents.

SCIENCE fiction on the larger scale is Isaac Asimov's spe cialty. The scene of his new book, a rousing adventure story of the remote future, is the Galaxy, which, with its hundreds of inhabited planets, has been taken over by a dictatorial race called, appropriately enough, the Tyranni.

ANYONE interested in the Near East, even to the limited extent of having enjoyed T.E. Lawrence's "Revolt in the Desert," will relish the "Memoirs of King Abdullah of Transjordan," an exciting story skillfully told.

Ignoring the dictates of the "book," which ostensibly has an answer for every situation, the Dodgers whipped the Reds, 2--1, yesterday at Ebbets Field. Ralph Branca, in his second starting-finishing, role, and Duke Snider were the Flatbush heroes, one with his highly commendable hurling, the other with his game-winning homer.

Coach Howie Borck's Red and Gold Cardinal Hayes team once again demonstrated its superiority over Bishop Loughlin, former schoolboy titleholder, by retaining the City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship yesterday at Randalls Island. Just a year ago the Bronx team came to the fore of interscholastic track by dethroning Loughlin as the outdoor city C.H.S.A.A. kingpin.

A three-day sale of English and American period furniture, of paintings, silver, rugs, porcelains, eighteenth-century gold and silver boxes and other decorative objects will be held each afternoon, Wednesday through Friday, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

ROME. AMERICANS who wandered in to Rome's Teatro Eliseo to see "Harvey" met with a curious surprise. Elwood Dowd was not drinking, at least hardly more than an aperitif. Elwood still saw Harvey, but without the help of beverage. Rather, his rabbit friend was a fantasy arising from a pleasant touch of personal madness.

McCuaig of Gannanoque, Ont.

Cortisone acetate applied as an ointment on the skin of mice is as effective as an injection, says Dr. Robert S. Speirs of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me., in Science. Mice which had their adrenals removed were used in these studies.

Chapin of Whitesville, N.Y. The Rev. James B. Madison performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Roger Smith Hotel.

One by one they disappear, those colorful relics of New York's earlier days. This time it is a Sutton Place landmark, closely associated with the life and times of the Doelger brewing family.
ATHENS, June 2--United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy, who had canceled his trip back to his post in Greece by ocean liner and took a plane instead, arrived in Athens before dawn today.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 2 (UP) --Ruth Lily led all the way today to score a one-length victory in the $24,700 Hollywood Oaks for 3-year-old fillies at Hollywood Park.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., June 2--The marriage of Miss Harriet Brewster Judson, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Myers Scribner of Sewickley, and the late Charles Henry Judson of Rochester, N.Y., to Ferguson Taylor, son of Mrs. Jessup Taylor of Sewickley, and Comdr. Daniel McLane Taylor, U.S. N., of Greenwich, Conn., took place this afternoon in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Department store sales were estimated at about 10 per cent above the 1950 week, chiefly as a result's of the stimulus supplied by the price war growing out of the Supreme Court's fair trade decision. Volume for the week would have been about 5 per cent ahead even without the price-cutting, trade observers estimated.

WASHINGTON--Hikers will find walking aplenty this summer on the 2,021mile Appalachian Trail, which for the first time in fourteen years will be open all the way from Mount Katahdin in Maine to Mount Oglethorpe in Georgia.

PROGRESSIVE sportsmen, conservationists and others interested in wildlife are coming increasingly to be lieve that more and more emphasis ought to be placed on permanent improvement of habitat rather than on mere annual restocking.
WASHINGTON, June 2--Secretary of State Dean Acheson made it clear today that the United States would be gravely concerned by any Communist assault on Iran or Hong Kong.

PARIS, June 2--AS the campaign gets under way in France for the new National Assembly to be elected June 17, special billboards at City Halls and in the public squares are blossoming with multicolored posters, and from speaking platforms in various parts of the country are now echoing all conceivable issues in foreign and domestic policies.
BARBARA MORGAN'S "Summer's Children" (Scarsdale, N.Y.: Morgan Morgan. $7.50), a beautifully pre pared picture book of camp life with descriptive captions and running text will be published tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 2--A new phase in psychiatry for the Michael Reese Hospital began today with the dedication and formal opening of the Institute for Psychosomatic and Psychiatric Research and Training, a pioneer project for the nation.

A realty business program designed to help the members to "learn to earn" has been arranged for the forty-seventh annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, to be held June 20 to 23 at the Lake George Sagamore, at Bolton Landing, N.Y.
Unusual summer leasing activity is reported in new store developments at Great Neck, Manhasset, Forest Hills and other sections of Long Island.

YAPHANK, L.I., June 2--Two pilots of the 119th Fighter Group, New Jersey Air National Guard, were killed here at 11:22 o'clock this morning when their airplanes collided in mid-air and crashed near this village.

Should a large part of the oil production of Iran be lost to the international market through the proposed nationalization by that nation, a serious shortage of petroleum products would be created almost immediately in the Eastern Hemisphere, particularly in Europe, according to oil executives here.

John Erskine, who gained considerable fame in three roles, as a teacher, a novelist and a musician, died yesterday in his home, 540 Park Avenue, at the age of 71. He had been suffering from a heart ailment for eighteen months.
A baccalaureate service in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus this afternoon will mark the beginning of Columbia University's 197th commencement week.

Lippincott of 1040 Park Avenue, New York, and the late James Blackstone Taylor Jr. of Oyster Bay, was married to Graeme Elliott, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Elliott of East Hampton and New York.

The shortage of engineers in industry will become acute this year, the deficit being made larger by the increasing demands of national defense production for industrial, technical and engineering services. This conclusion was revealed by a national survey of engineering graduates of eighty-six leading educational institutions which has just been completed.
The ability of the nation's $25,000,000,000 electric power and light industry to meet the sharply increasing demands of defense mobilization will receive a thorough airing this week.

THE average citizen to whom the word "parole" is simply a term associated with release from prison can obtain knowledge as well as reading enjoyment from this fine autobiography of a parole officer. David Dressler, former executive director of the New York State Division of Parole, has presented here the distillation of seventeen years in the field, a period in which he sat in on more than 100,000 parole interviews.

When big department stores fight price wars, they use almost military tactics. Each one sends out scouts-- comparison shoppers--to find out prices at the other stores. When a comparison shopper telephones a message to headquarters, there are hurried councils.
Despite credit restrictions of Regulation X and the possible shortage of materials, Long Island builders have started June operations on a scale comparable to their activity of mid-1950.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Amid renewed reports of peace feelers in the Korean conflict, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today he knew of no present negotiations for a settlement. Meanwhile, the Defense Department explained there was no political significance to the ending of the "pursuit phase" of United Nations operations in Korea.
A WEEK'S menus for five at a cost of $35.98 are pre sented for those struggling with high food prices.

The American Red Cross and the five county medical societies of New York have signed an agreement for a new program to increase the supply of blood in the metropolitan area for the armed forces and existing hospital blood banks.

Alvin E. Dodd of 160 East Fortyeighth Street, since July 1, 1948, honorary president, and previously, for twelve years, president of the American Management Association,330 West Forty-second Street, died yesterday afternon in the University Hospital, after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

THE Haydn Society is not the only organization devoted to Haydn. Westminster Records, which has already issued recordings of his Symphonies No. 80, 95, 100 and 103, has now released four more. There is also a new recording of the Clock Symphony issued by Mercury on a teninch disk. The group of them tellingly attest the composer's greatness.

THE twenty-eight studies, comprising this volume originated at a conference on modern France held in Princeton in February, 1950. Written mainly by scholars attached to American universities or holding special jobs with the State. Department or Economic Cooperation Administration, they bring together a wealth of learning and acute observation.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 2--Premier Mohammed Mossadegh gave clear intimations today that a solution to the British-Iranian oil dispute could not be found along the lines suggested to him by President Truman in his personal message yesterday.

WINCHESTER, Va., June 2-- Miss Eleanor deGrange and Milton Sydney Heath Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Heath of Chapel Hill, N.C., were married here this evening in the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay deGrange. HERE is a quiet, simply told novel about a group of Virginia Quakers a few years after the close of the American Revolution. The principal characters are the three sons of Patience and Obadiah Roberts, with the story of their friends, loves, enemies and adventures.

Four themes consonant with a major aim of the Young Men's Christian Association to adhere to a practical world-wide effort to remove the causes of war have been scheduled for the plenary sessions of the North American Centennial Convention of the Y.M.C.A.'s of the United States and Canada. The sessions will be held June 21 to 24 in the Cleveland Public Auditorium.

SEATTLE, June 2 (AP)--More than sixty awards to newspapers, editors and writers were announced today by the National Editorial Association. The winners of the association's 1951 "Better Newspaper Contests" were honored at its convention here.

CINCINNATI, June 2--In the historic Rockdale Avenue Temple, for more than 125 years a stronghold of American Reform Judaism, the Cincinnati section of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion today conferred honorary degrees upon one Briton and four Americans, and ordained nine students as reform Rabbis.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 2-- With one-over-par golf, Mal Galletta of North Hills, former Long Island amateur champion, and his host, Paul Engels, were among the first-round victors in the Hempstead Golf Club's annual memberguest tournament today.

SINCE annuals provide most of the color in the summer garden, it pays dividends to exercise a bit of care in transplanting them. Properly set in their new location, the seedlings will take hold almost immediately and start to grow. Handled haphazardly, they are apt to wilt down for several days; some may be lost and those that do live will suffer some setback.

For the first time since the night in early March, 1949, in New Haven's Shubert Theatre when "South Pacific" began its career as one of the most fabulous musical hits in history, Mary Martin is temporarily at liberty this morning--free to wash or not to wash her hair as befits her whim.

PITTSBURGH, June 2--The sensational shiny mahogany speed boat Miss Pepsi, which last fall won the President's Cup on the Potomac to close the season of 1950, ushered in the season of 1951 this afternoon by winning the new Steel Cup in Pittsburgh's gala excitement known as "Welcome Week."

CLEVELAND, June 2 (AP)--With a blast of four home runs, the Indians polished off the Senators, 12 to 4, today for their sixth straight victory. Defensively, the Tribe tied an American League record by going nine consecutive games without an error.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 2 (AP)-- Herb McKenley of Jamaica, the world record holder in the 440yard dash, set two meet records today in the Ohio amateur. Athletic Union track and field championships.

A SPLASH of posters in Argentina's national colors of blue and white recently blazoned in downtown Buenos Aires: "Eva Peron, standard bearer of the meek, should be elected in 1952." The meek could scarcely find in all this world a more dramatic opposite to lead them.

Backlogs of orders for industrial items dropped in May for the third consecutive month. This is the estimate of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, whose business survey committee has just issued its report. Production was shown to be easing off, and although defense orders increased, their effect is not being felt over a wide area of industry.

OUTBREAK of a full-scale price war among local department stores provided the big news in the retail field last week. The price-cutting followed in the wake of the Supreme Court decision holding that non-signers of fair-trade agreements could not be bound in interstate commerce.
Contracts totaling $12,447,339 for construction of the new nurses' residence and training school at Bellevue Hospital were awarded yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 2--Thirty-four of the larger yachts in Eastern waters competed in three classes today in the run of the New York Yacht Club here from off Glen Cove.

The United States Government last week brought its full weight to bear in an attempt to resolve the Iranian oil crisis. In Teheran early in the week, U.S. Ambassador Henry F. Grady employed all his veteran skill at mediating the dispute between Britain and Iran.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., June 2-- At the age of 50, Nicholas Nyary, who was corporation counsel in Budapest until he and his family fled before the Russian invasion of Hungary in 1944, will find himself on the threshold of a new career beginning next Thursday--that of a Presbyterian minister.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 2-- The Reformed Church was the scene of the marriage this evening of Miss Marion Ballow Rust, to Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Bulfinch, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis V. Bulfinch of Dover, Mass. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Rust. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lowell R. Ditzen. A reception took place at the Rust home here.
HONG KONG, June 2--A nationwide drive to raise funds to buy more planes, tanks and guns for Korea was launched today by the Chinese Communists.

Modern civilization could be "one of the most fruitful and joyous" in all history if mankind was not obliged to "live upon the bitter nourishment of fear and anxiety," Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street.

Prices of cotton turned generally firmer last week. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange on Friday, the near-by July delivery, an exception, was off 19 points from the final level of the preceding week, but other futures showed net gains of 15 to 26 points. During the preceding week the market registered net declines of 24 to 146 points.

ROME, June 3--Pope Pius X was beatified today in St. Peter's Basilica. Later, in the vast square outside the basilica, Pope Pius XII implored the new Blessed to intercede with God to obtain "true and lasting peace" for the world.

CLEVELAND, June 3--The rarity of this June day was entirely unappreciated by Casey Stengel and his Yankees. Before the season's largest crowd, 75,163, at Cleveland Stadium today the Bombers last both ends of a double-header to the Indians, 8--3 and 4--1.

TOKYO, Monday, June 4--United Nations troops stabbed forward yesterday in a two-pronged drive on Korea's west-central front, cutting into the edges of the Communist main defensive area, the so called iron triangle, pointed on Chorwon, Kumhwa and Pyonggang.

Premier Sukiman has now set forth the major policies of the recently formed Indonesian Government. They are quite understandable in the circumstances but they are not reassuring, since they offer the possibility of further tension in the critical area of Southeast Asia.

SHAAB, Israel, June 3--The 800 Arabs evacuated from the demilitarized zone along the Syrian frontier are a discontented lot. They are torn between the possible advantages of their new homes in this village and the memories of the places from where they were uprooted.

ROME, June 3--The second round of the current battle being fought in Italy between the democratic parties and the Communists and extreme left began today when the people of Sicily went to the polls to elect ninety representatives to their regional parliament for four-year terms.

BEATRICE, Neb., June 3 (UP) --The Big Blue River raced through eastern Nebraska's lowlands today, flooding a thirtyblock area here and pounding an earthen dike that threatened to collapse and endanger another big residential area.

PARIS, June 3--French authorites will be obliged this week to confess in talks with General of the Army Omar N.Bradley, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, that France's rearming program has now dropped behind and will not attain the goals that had been set for 1951.

Inflationary forces have made no significant advance for three months, but they still present a danger which can be arrested only by effective taxation and credit control, the National City Bank of New York declares in its June letter, issued for publication today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 3 --Reorganization and re-equipment by the Soviet Union of the armies of the satellite states are proceeding so swiftly and efficiently that by the autumn of 1952 most of these forces should be ready for offensive operations.
