New Federal prosecutions of the nation's Communists were foreshadowed here yesterday as a result of the Supreme Court's decision upholding conviction of eleven of the party's top leaders.

MANY years ago the City Council in Chicago debated the idea of renaming Thirty-fifth Street, on which Comiskey Park is located. The name which found the greatest favor was Comiskey Road. But the entire project was hastily abandoned when a mischievous and irreverent sportswriter--it probably was John Car michael--tossed in his two cents' worth.
Action in Washington is still needed on those proposals of the Hoover Commission that Congress has not yet considered nor the President endorsed.
WASHINGTON, June 4(AP)--The American Newspaper Publishers Association today gave notice it would continue to oppose the major increases in telegraph press rates proposed by Western Union.

ROME, Tuesday, June 5--Despite the efforts of parties of extreme left and extreme right to undermine the authority of the Italian Government, Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Christian Democratic party obtained a plurality of votes by a slim margin, according to final returns early this morning for the Sicilian regional election held Sunday.

BROADSTONE, England, June 4 (UP)--Beverly Hanson, United States amateur golf champion from Indio, Calif., scored two victories today to reach the third round of the British women's amateur championship, but America's other two entrants were eliminated in second-round matches.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court ruled today by a 6 to 3 vote, that the Taft-Hartley Act applied to the construction industry. In four related cases, it held that the law's ban on secondary boycots prevented the picketing of a general contractor to force him to discontinue his association with a subcontractor who employed nonunion labor.
Fairfield, Conn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 12 on $4,375,000 of school and sewer bonds dated June 1, 1951, and due on June 1, 1952 to 1982.

HONG KONG, June 4--All Government and privately operated cotton mills in Shanghai, where almost half of China's total number of spindles are concentrated, have been ordered to suspend operations for six weeks because of a shortage of raw cotton.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- Following is the text of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson's opinion today upholding the conviction of the eleven Communist leaders on charges of teaching violent overthrow of the Government:

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada, opened the union's fiftyfourth annual convention yesterday with a stinging rebuke to "politicians" whom he charged were helping to destroy this nation's musical heritage.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4--The sudden visit of Abdul Rahman Azzam Pasha, secretary general of the Arab League, to Jordan's King Abdullah in Amman today, added emphasis to reports that Turkey was making a major effort to effect some type of mutual defensive arrangement in the Near East that would defend her back door if Iran came under Soviet domination.

ALBANY, June 4--Governor Dewey and the State Defense Council, who have the power to remove public officials who fail to cooperate in civil defense, charged today that there had been an intolerable lack of cooperation in about half the cities and counties of the state.

For a ball club only recently recovered from a varied assortment of ills and injuries, the Cardinals, paced by their matchless Stan Musial, put on quite a robust performance at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they belted the Giants into submission, 7 to 2, in the series finale.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Civil Service Commission reported today there were 532,500 women on the Federal payroll on April 1, an increase of 126,000 since July 1, 1950.

Underwriters headed by Lee Higginson Corporation will put on the market today a new issue of 175,000 shares of common stock of Tracerlab, Inc., manufacturer of equipment for detecting and measuring radioactivity. The shares are priced at $14.75 each.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 4--Relief rolls in New York State declined more than 15 per cent in the past year, Robert T. Lansdale, commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, reported today.
Dr. Luis Machado, Cuba's Ambassador to this country, was honored yesterday at a luncheon flat which the close ties between Cuba and the United States were traced by speakers from both nations.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4-- The United States Military Academy will commission 477 cadets as second lieutenants in the Army and the Air Force at commencement exercises here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court held today that it was constitutional for communities to pass laws against door-to-door selling, even of books and magazine subscriptions.
The junior high school teacher who disobeyed an official directive by refusing to join in the city's welcome to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in April will be transferred to another school.
PARIS, June 4--(AP)--Two gruelling matches under today's hot sun proved too much for the veteran Gardnar Mulloy and his youthful partner, Dick Savitt, and
Dr. B. Wallace Hamilton, since 1936 secretary of the Medical So ciety of the County of New York, died in his home at 52 East Sixtysixth Street yesterday at the age of 73.
The Queens Borough Control Station, the first of five to be set up by the city Office of Civil Defense, will be tested tonight.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 5 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 905, issued at 10:50 A.M. Tuesday (8:50 P.M., Monday, Eastern daylight time):
Ora W. Grow, 37-year-old director of a beauty school, was sentenced to seven years in prison and fined $14,000; his 43-year-old wife, Dassie, was sentenced to three years and fined' $11,000, and the

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 4-- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, declared today that the inernational organization was prepared to back up its embargo on Communist China with additional measures if they were needed to halt aggression against free nations.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Whatever may be thought of the diplomatic competence or intellectual honesty of the Policy Information Paper on Formosa of Dec. 23, 1949, which was made public last week by the Senate committees over the protest of the Secretary of State, it seems to this correspondent
Except for coffee, which spurted 10 to 22 points on trade buying with an absence of offerings, commodifies futures in New York lost ground yesterday.

A retired policeman, one of twenty-one retired or suspended members of the department about to go on trial for conspiracy in the Brooklyn gambling graft racket, leaped to his death yesterday morning from a sixth-floor window of the Central Courts Building in Brooklyn. His suicide failed to halt the start of the trial.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the attacks General of the Army Douglas MacArthur wanted to make by bombers on Communist China would have given the Russians a legal basis to enter the Korean war.

HONG KONG, Jurie 4--Official reports from Shanghai disclosed today that 208 persons had been executed there May 31 as alleged "counter-revolutionaries." This brought to 529 the number the Communists have acknowledged shooting in China's largest city in May.

MOSCOW, June 4--A second bitter attack in three days by Pravda, leading Soviet press organ, upon Amerika, the Russian-language monthly magazine put out by the State Department for circulation in the Soviet Union, was published today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 4-- Forty-eight hours before its constitutional adjournment date the Connecticut General Assembly went into its first night session in an effort to clear its files of hundreds of bills.

Ann Stoddard, solo harpist in Phil Spitalny's All Girl Orchestra gave her first New York recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall It was a bid for her to be considered as a serious artist, for she confined herself to the classics and to those who have written concert pieces for the harp.

GUATEMALA, June 1--LatinAmerican Communists, already entrenched during the regime of President Juan Jose Arevalo, appear to have consolidated their position and increased their power in the ten weeks since Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman became Chief Executive of this Central American country of 2,787,000 inhabitants.
BOSTON, June 4 (UP)--Trailing, 7--0, after seven innings, the Reds got three runs on Connie Ryan's homer in the eighth and rolled up seven more runs in the ninth to beat the Braves, 10-7, today.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The House of Representatives adopted a resolution today expressing the friendship of the American people for the peoples of the Soviet Union, but did it by a meager vote of 36 to 7 that failed to reflect for the record the extensive support behind the proposal.

BOSTON, June 4--Mrs. Lora C. Rathvon of Boston became president of the Mother Church of Christian Science today at the annual meeting of The Mother Church, The First Church of Christ, Scientist, here. The meeting was attended by nearly 7,500 Christian Scientists from all over the world.

The First Amendment is not violated when men are punished for entering into a "conspiracy knowingly and willfully to advocate the duty and necessity of overthrowing the Government of the United States by force and violence." That is the basic meaning

"I AM going to understand everything in this world before I get through," Rhoda Lee Dalton promised herself when she was 16 years old. It was a lofty ambition which she learned to modify in the next few years of growing up, just as she learned how impossible was her other, firm decision, to avoid the terrible turmoil of adult emotions.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Truman Administration is blocking needed amendments to the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act because it-will take nothing short of complete repeal, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio and co-author of the statute, told the Senate today.
George T. Paine has been appointed executive vice president of the American President Lines.

Sales of Deere Co. and subsidiaries for the six months ended on April 30 reached the second highest on record, but earnings declined $4,238,854 from the previous year's period as a result of taxes which rose $5,600,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Board of National Consultants of the Veterans Administration, in a closed session today, resolved that the chief medical director of the agency should be responsible for its medical program and run its hospitals.
WASHINGTON, June 4--Imposition of limited "community" price control regulations is scheduled on fifteen to twenty grocery items within a month or six weeks, Michael V. DiSalle said today.

DENVER, Colo., June 4--The rapid rate of expansion of the electric power and light industry in the United States in order to meet civilian and defense requirements during the next three years will require the raising of nearly $2,000,000,000 of equity capital.
CLEVELAND, June 4--The mother of a 15-year-old boy student and the principal of Albert Bushnell Hart Junior High School engaged in a fight today in which both were battered.
The admirable C.A.R.E.-Unesco Book Fund has developed and added a new and important project.

The best place to eat a ripe mango probably is in the bath tub. So juicy is this fruit when mature, so soft the flesh, that the finger bowl has not been designed that is large enough for the cleanup job of face and fingers that becomes necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The constitutionality of the bitterly contested Feinberg Act, aimed at purging the New York State public-school system of Communist or "fellow-traveler" teachers, will be reviewed by the Supreme Court during its next term beginning in October.
Rain after one out in the top of the third inning of a scoreless duel between Clarence (Bud) Podbielan and Paul Minner washed out last night's Ebbets Field contest between the Dodgers and Cubs.
CHICAGO, June 4--Cattle receipts here today were the lowest in more than sixty years for the first Monday in June. Receipts at twenty large markets throughout the country also were low.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)--A series of recommendations for furthering Turkey's economic progress and broadening the country's investment program were announced today in the report Of a mission for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

Arthur N. Holcombe, Professor of Government at Harvard University, and Henry Nash Smith, Professor of English at the University of Minnesota, have been chosen by Columbia University as the 1951 winners of the Bancroft Prizes.

Formal openings of fall lines in the women's apparel field brought thousands of buyers into New York yesterday, Crowded hotels in the midtown area attested to the fact that the buyer influx was the heaviest on record for the first week in June.
The Stage Relief Fund, which has served the theatrical profession for more than eighteen years, will go out of existence on June 29.

A flowing silhouette with fullness falling from below the shoulders, frequent use of small collars and a soft natural shoulder given firmness with the slightest bit of padding were highlights of the Schwartz Bluestein showing of Fredrica furs yesterday at 345 Seventh Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 4 (UP)--The White Sox set back the Boston Red Sox, 6 to 5 and 2 to 0; on two wellpitched games by Billy Pierce and Saul Rogovin before 42,718 fans tonight to take a three-and-a-halfgame lead in the American League race.

CHICAGO, June 4-Long liquidation was the order of the day in all the grain pits here today. The selling was the result of uneasiness over possible peace developments and the favorable weather that prevailed in all sections, especially in the spring wheat areas, where dry weather had caused some apprehension.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 4 (AP)--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India declared tonight the Government of Kashmir had the right to call a Constituent Assembly to decide whether to join Pakistan or India.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4--Dr. Julius Katz-Suchy, Poland's chief delegate to the United Nations, said today that merely halting the shooting at Korea's Thirtyeighth Parallel would not effect a cease-fire.

The Joe Low Corporation of New York, manufacturer of candy and bakery equipment, has purchased a plot of 70,000 square feet at 110th Avenue and 180th Street in Jamaica, Queens, from the estate of Leon Wolosoff and mans to improve it with a factory.

CLEVELAND, June 4--Maybe it was the 15,000 rabbits' feet distributed among the 20,217 fans, or perhaps it was the frigid weather, as the Indians tonight finally snapped the phenomenal streak of triumphs Eddie Lopat had piled up over them in the past two seasons.

Henry Ginsberg, who resigned a year ago as vice president in charge of studio productions and operations for Paramount Pictures, Inc., has been appointed a general consultant to the National Broadcasting Company.

The free world, particularly the United States, must do a great deal more than it is doing now to help the more than a quarter of a million refugees from the Soviet Union if their full potentiality for assisting the birth of a free Russia is to be realized.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The National Production Authority removed from the jurisdiction of its field offices today authority to pass upon applications for construction of radio and television broadcasting studios.

At 2:30 P.M. yesterday Deputy Mayor Charles Horowitz turned a valve and natural gas began flowing into the homes and business establishments of 12,000 consumers, beginning commercial use of the natural fuel in Brooklyn.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 4-- Louis de Brouckere, a member of Belgium's Council of State, a body of elder statesmen equivalent to a Supreme Court, died here today. He was 81 years old.

City bills designed to supplement enforcement here of Federal price regulations were assailed yesterday by a Commerce and Industry Association spokesman at a City Hall hearings as "creating a two-headed administrative arrangement promising inefficiency, confusion and waste."

CHICAGO, June 4 (UP)--The first-place White Sox traded for hitting insurance today in two deals which resulted in acquisition of infielder-outfielder Don Lenhardt from the St. Louis Browns.
The impressive parade of the Indian Socialist party in New Delhi on Sunday emphasizes a development in Indian politics that is worth watching.

MEXICO CITY, June 4--Remedies for a decline in trade between Latin America and Europe, which has dropped below the 1913 level while commerce with the United States has tripled since that year, were sought today at a meeting here of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 14--The Saar issue emerged as a barrier to the Federal Bundestag's ratification of the Schuman plan today as the German debate over foreign policy assumed new importance.

Twenty-four hours before he was to start trial in General Sessions with four other former firemen on charges of participating in a $500,000-a-year shakedown of fuel oil equipment installlers, Edward J. Donnelly pleaded guilty yesterday.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, June 4--Bacteria have been harnessed in a laboratory to improve the extraction of oil and change its properties, a United States scientist reported today at the third World Petroleum Congress here.

HANOI, Indo-China, June 4-- Major fighting between Communist-led Vietminh insurgents and French Vietnamese forces in South Tongking spread far into the flat, rice-growing Red River Delta yesterday as French and Vietnamese forces, moved against infiltrating Vietminh units near the South Delta city of Namdinh.
BRADENTON, Fla., June 4 (AP) --Thomas C. Trueblood, a golfplaying professor who served on the University of Michigan faculty, died here today at the age of 95.

The worsening terms of trade of most Western European' countries will raise "progressively serious" problems for that area as its rearmament program gets under way, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

After both sides had indicated yesterday that they had no further witnesses in the $300,000 libel suit brought by Mrs. Marie M. La Guardia, Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen, excused the jury until 10 o'clock this morning, when both will sum up.

The first color television receivers to be produced by the Columbia Broadcasting System's new set manufacturing subsidiary will cost $400 or Q500 and give twelve-andone-half-inch pictures, it was announced yesterday.
TRENTON, June 4 (AP)--The state presented rebuttal witnesses today to challenge the alibis of two defendants in the "Trenton Six" murder trial.

VIENNA, June 4--Well-authenticated reports from Budapest indicate that Archbishop Josef Grness, chairman of the Hungarian Bench of Bishops, has been arrested by the Hungarian Gov eminent for having refused to sign the latest "peace" manifesto.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Federal Reserve Board today made public its first weekly report showing changes in business loans.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court affirmed today in a 6-to-2 decision the convictions of the eleven United States Communist leaders on charges they advocated overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

CHICAGO, June 5--Steel allocations to the railroad industry under the Controlled Materials Plan far the next three months are insufficient for the carriers' equipment building program, James S. Knudson, defense transport administrator, said today.

Handsome William Fellowes Morgan, former City Commissioner of Markets, gives visitors to his office a cold welcome. He takes them backstage at the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company, tucked unexpectedly under the Brooklyn Bridge on the Manhattan side, where the temperature is zero.

PARIS, June 5--President Truman, as Commander in Chief of the United States armed forces, has directed the Sixth Task Fleet, stationed in the Mediterranean, to support the North Atlantic command of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower in Europe.
Virtually every commodity traded on New York futures market drifted into lower ground yesterday. Trade houses appeared to be waiting for developments.

The outstanding lesson that Mayor Impellitteri should have learned thus far from the transit crisis is that he will continually find himself in trouble until he gets some stronger people to stand at his side and furnish counsel.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 5 (AP) --The chief Australian ports were idle today during demonstrations protesting Government prosecution of James Healy, general secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States and Dr. Max Euwe of Holland, each with 2 -- , were tied for first place in the Wertheim Memorial international tournament at the close of play last night at the Manhattan Chess Club.
Misfortune hounded the United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music as it was preparing for last night's concert in McMillan Theatre, Columbia University.

A ballet season in June may break all precedents, but if the New York City Ballet carries on at the level it set itself in its opening at the City Center last night, there should be no financial risk involved.

A late rally in the railroads and oils pulled the stock market out of a further slump yesterday. While some of the losses prior to the recovery were of major proportions, the rally shifted the list to the higher side but the gain was slight.

MADRID, June 5--Spanish authorities returned press credentials today to Sam Pope Brewer. THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Madrid, from whom they were withdrawn April 17 on unspecified charges that his work gave a false impression of the state of affairs in Spain at this time.

Now possessor of the longest victory streak in the majors this season and also the biggest winner in both leagues, Sal Maglie of the Giants turned back the Reds, 3--2, last night for his ninth straight.

A new seven-point formula for public service by industrialists was urged yesterday by Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, in an address before the thirty-sixth annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kelly of Cincinnati, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in East Fourteenth Street.
Louis Hollander, president of the million-member State Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged yesterday that those fighting "effective controls" were "doing a job for the Communists."

Dr. George Avery Jr., director of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, asked the Park Association of New York City yesterday for aid in adding another acre to the small plot at the end of the garden on which children plant their own crops.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 5 --There was a four-way tie in the amateur-pro golf tournament held today over the course of the Piping Rock Club for the benefit of the North Country Community Hospital of Glen Cove.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- The State Department planned a simple little ceremony today--but up popped the explosive Mrs. Perle Mesta, protocol, high diplomacy and mechanical breakdowns.

The present price war affects only a relatively small percentage of the items carried in a department store, Fred Lazarus Jr., president of Federated Department Stores, Inc., told shareholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.

The Coast Guard urged yesterday the closest cooperation among all shipping companies and federal and civil agencies to implement the limited port security program now in force here and announced that it planned soon to establish restricted areas where vital shipping activities were conducted.

Patience and soft words enabled five policemen and a priest to balk a suicide attempt by a deranged man in a dramatic scene yesterday afternoon atop the Queensboro Bridge tower, about 500 feet above Welfare Island.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 5--The leadership of Western civilization has passed into American hands and only the "moral mobilization of all of us" can sustain it, Turner Catledge, executive managing editor Of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared here today.

Sir Alan Burns of Britain was elected president yesterday of the United Nations Trusteeship Council for its ninth session, as the Council commenced its meetings at Flushing Meadow.

LONDON, June 5 (AP)--Argentina's rugged Cesar Brion won the decision over Jack Gardner, Britain's heavyweight king, tonight, but two other English champions felled American foes to thrill 50, 000 fans at White City Stadium.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 6-- United Nations troops fought a hard, seesaw battle yesterday with Chinese and North Korean Communists in an allied advance that was slowed in many areas almost to a standstill by a stiffly resisting enemy.

WASHINGTON, June 5--As part of a general move to reduce the vast amount of routine paper work that chains every President to his White House desk, President Truman issued an executive order today delegating a score of powers vested in him to the Secretary of the Interior.

Television station WNBT, owned and operated by the National Broadcasting Company, is planning to begin the first regular program transmissions Monday from the new 222-foot steel tower atop the Empire State Building, nearly one year from the date construction started.

Commencement exercises were held yesterday for 112 students at the Horace Mann School, 231 West 246th, Street, Fieldston, the Bronx. Thirty-eight awards and prizes were distributed among twentyseven members of the sixty-fourth graduating class.

A Supreme Court jury last evening returned a verdict awarding six cents to Mrs. Maria M. La Guardia, widow of Fiorello H. La Guardia, the former Mayor, in her $300,000 libel suit against the Hearst Corporation, publishers of The Daily Mirror.
Vice President Alben W. Barkley said last night that the American people and the American Government had an important stake in seeing that the state of Israel was successful.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Green River Steel Corporation of Owensboro, Ky., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for the registration of $4,000,000 of 31 per cent debentures due 1961 and 320,000 shares of common stock of 25 cents par value.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican of Maine, told the Senate today that he had never heard more "barefaced distortion" than Secretary of State Dean Acheson's testimony on the China policies of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Secretary of State Acheson has taken a firm legal stand in the MacArthur inquiry against recognizing the Chinese Communists or voting them into the United Nations, but at the same time he has recognized their power and offered them an honorable Peace.

SECAUCUS, N.J., June 5--The staccato of riveters' guns, the whine of winches straining under heavy loads of steel and the roar of bulldozers create a nerve-jarring cacophony of sound ... as the New Jersey Turnpike takes form.

BOSTON, June 5--The Rev. Michael J. Ahern, S.J., founder of the Boston College seismographic station and a widely known Jesuit lecturer, died today in St. Elizabeth's Hospital. His age was 74.

Miss Lilian Brandt, who had been engaged in social welfare research work here for almost half a century, died Monday night in French Hospital at the age of 78. She had been ill for several weeks.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 5 (UP)-- Two Air Force pilots were killed and a third injured slightly when three fighter planes flying in two separate formations collided twenty miles east of here today.
The number of shoppers besieging sales clerks in stores yesterday dropped sharply as the sixth day of the price war ended with no indication that the stores were relaxing their price-cutting.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 5-- In a new over-all summary of the week-long battle with Vietminh troops along the Day River front in South Tongking, the French command here claimed tonight 4,300 casualties to date among the Communist-led insurgents.

The thirty-six-family apartment house also containing five stores at 1382-84 White Plains Road, the Bronx, has been sold by Domenico Randazzo to Mildred Stern for cash above a mortgage of $78,000. G. Satriale was the broker. The property occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet.

Paramount Pictures Corporation is on a more solid foundation than it was before becoming an independent production, and distribution company a year and and a half ago, Barney Balaban, president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting.
Although Serge Koussevitzky had a secure reputation in his native Russia and, after the revolution, in France, his name will inevitably be linked with that of the Boston Symphony.
ST. LOUIS, June 5--Rising expenses and a reduced gross margin will seriously cut department store profits in the fiscal year 1951, and there will be only moderate sales rises.

LONDON, June .5 (AP)--The British Government took President Truman's hint today and named one of the Government directors in the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company to a delegation that will try to settle the dispute with Iran.

PARIS, June 5--The Communist authorities in Budapest have apparently begun to deport considerable numbers of families from the Hungarian capital.

A writ that would have prevented Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz from conducting a hearing on neglect of duty charges against Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh was denied yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5--The neutral government of Hussein Oueni resigned today as the new Parliament met. The Cabinet left office amid warm congratulations from all quarters because of its success in guaranteeing relatively honest elections.

"Hollywood Story," a UniversalInternational melodrama featuring Richard Conte, will have its premiere this morning at the Paramount.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5-- Thirty-two members of the graduating class of the United States Military Academy were married here today in a day-long series of ceremonies that provided a romantic climax to June Week activities, the traditional round of social and military events preceding graduation.

VIENNA, June 5--The disclosure by Josef Frank, acting general secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party, that the Czech economy was in a catastrophic condition has been the most open confession yet that the stepped-up five-year plans imposed by the Soviet Union on its east block of satellites cannot be achieved.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5--Henry M. McAdoo, former chairman of the Board of the United States Leather Company of New York, died yesterday in Hanover, N.H., at the age of 70.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 5--A simplified form of recording essential data on all public assistance cases was made public today by John J. Keppler, assistant to the Commissioner of the State Social Welfare Department. He spoke at the annual meeting of the State Public Welfare Association.

DETROIT, June 5--The reluctance of some North Atlantic Treaty nations to accept Spain as a partner will not deter Madrid from seeking an alliance with the United States, Jose Felix de Lequerica, Spanish Ambassador, said here today.
Martin James Monti, former lieutenant in the Army Air Forces, who is serving twenty-five years in prison as a traitor, brought an action yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court to regain his freedom.

WASHINGTON, June 5--A conference committee on behalf of the Senate and the House agreed today on terms of the bill to authorize a loan of $190,000,000 for food relief to India. In general, the compromise version would follow the measure passed by the House.

The U.S. Leather Company has sold to Jacob L. Appollon the fivestory office building and ware house at 27 and 29 Spruce Street in the downtown leather trade center in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $135,000.

The first significant economic challenge to television in the home came yesterday with the announcement that a group of motion picture theatres had bought exclusive rights to cover next Wednesday's heavyweight fight between Joe Louis and Lee Savold at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, June 5--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today that price wars among New York and other department stores should not be taken as an indication of a reversal of inflationary trends.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and its largest common stockholder, the Alleghany Corporation, won the right today to inspect the balloting on Missouri Pacific's proposed reorganization plan.

The showdown between the Communist-led unions in Australia and the new Menzies Government must be near at hand. Almost every day little items of news are coming out of Melbourne telling of strikes and disorders.
ATHENS June 5--The collective resignation of the royal court, announced last night, was not accepted by King Paul, who formally said so tonight in thanking the thirty or so members for their loyalty.

WASHINGTON, June 5, (AP)-- Following is the censored testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees inquiring into the Administration Foreign Policy (censorship deletions noted parenthetically):

WASHINGTON, June 5 (UP)-- Sixteen members of key House committees will confer in Paris with Gen. of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower next week on President Truman's request for $8,500,000,000 in foreign aid in the next fiscal year starting July 1.
Since the end of World War II personal borrowings of the American people have more than doubled, according to a report yesterday by the Institute of Life Insurance.
Because Pee Wee Reese was able to bunt and because Roy Campanella was not, the Dodgers bagged a 3-2 victory over the Cardinals yesterday at Ebbets Field.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5-- Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall today told United States Military Academy graduates here they would serve the armed forces of a democracy and would have to reconcile its procedures with military necessity.

BROADSTONE, England, June 5 (AP)--Miss Beverly Hanson, seeking to become the third American to hold both the United States and British women's amateur titles at the same time, swept into the quarter-finals of the British amateur golf championship today with two victories.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 4--The World Petroleum Congress elected as chairman of its permanent council today Dr. E.V. Murphree, president of the Standaxd Oil Development Company, research subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

On Oct. 14, 1949, after the verdict had been brought in against the eleven Communist leaders, Judge Medina dismissed the jury, called out the names of the six defense counsel, found each of them guilty of criminal contempt, and forthwith imposed sentences varying from thirty days to six months in jail.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today it was taking surplus farm products out of former national defense storage space to make room for military equipment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP)-- Jim Konstanty, making his first starting appearance since he lost the world series opener, 1-0, to the Yankees last fall, failed again tonight as a starter as the Cubs defeted the Phillies, 3--2.
Degrees were distributed yesterday to 132 graduates of the College of Mt. St. Vincent, Riverdale, by Cardinal Spellman, president of the college.
Ferrucio Burco, Italian boy conductor, who made a "farewell tour" here in February, 1949, apparently did not take his adieux any more seriously than some oldtimers.

Columbia College's 197th graduating class and its outstanding students and leaders will be honored at the school's annual Class Day exercises at 10 o'clock this morning in Van Amringe Quadrangle on the campus.
At least five factors would seem to preclude any serious shortage of consumer goods and a consequent "uncontrollable pressure on the cost of living in the coming twleve months."

WASHINGTON, June 5--Strong indications that cutbacks in the production of passenger buses are soon to be ordered by the National Production Authority were seen here today in an announcement that the agency is preparing an order dealing with bus production.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 55--If the price war now going on in New York City continues for long, it will result in the bankruptcy of many small merchants and widespread unemployment, it was said here today by Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of
A thirty-one-page statement admitting, the murder of 23-year-old Dorothy Sarasky on Staten Island two weeks ago was attributed yesterday to August Jagusch, 42, and homeless.
LAKE PLACID,N.Y., June 5 (AP)--Governor Dewey said today that home-front defenses should be prepared "as though the atom bomb were expected to fall on us tomorrow."

Ninety women, passengers on the eighty-foot sight-seeing craft Islander, were safely put ashore last night minutes after the vessel had been in collision at 6:45 P.M. with a railroad freight car float off the Battery in the North River. Five were treated for minor in juries and sent home.

CLEVELAND, June 5--With Allie Reynolds, the Yankees' only winning pitcher on this trip, hurling a five-hitter, the Indians needed something more than rabbits' feet today as the Bombers triumphed, 8--2, to stay three and a half games behind the league-leading White Sox.
Mayor Impellitteri and the Board of Estimate warned the city's 36,000 transit workers last night that they would lose their jobs if they struck July 1.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 5 (Reuters)--More than half the regional leaders of the Czechoslovak Communist party have been replaced as a result of the annual party conference held recently, Rude Pravo, the party newspaper, disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)-- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman told the National Petroleum Council today to "continue to function as it has in the past."

Graduates of the New York University College of Medicine, a unit of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, were advised yesterday not to feel resentment at being deprived of an immediate opportunity to practice in civilian life.
The caliber of American handicrafts has not diminished in the last year, judging from the second annual competition held by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council.

Experimental evidence from a series of thirty-seven human patients at the University of California Hospital, which were reported here yesterday, give a strong indication that the bodily hormonal balance may exert a controlling influence over the rate at which the brain "works."
CHICAGO, June 5--Wheat prices advanced today after being weak and sharply lower in the early trading. Commission-buying broad

GREENWICH, Conn., June 5-- Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks putted her way to victory today as she won low gross honors in the Westchester Division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament.
John Foster Dulles is now in London to explore the ground for a better agreement between Britain and the United States on the terms of a peace treaty for Japan.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5-- Gwilym A. Price, president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, said here today that a galloping inflatibn over the last year has robbed the American people of billions of dollars of their savings.

Count Turf, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, beat Bold, the winner of the Preakness, at Belmont Park yesterday. Also beating the Preakness winner was the outsider who had never won anything of consequence, the Putnam Stable's Combat Boots.
DENVER, Colo., June 5--Between now and the end of 1953 it will be a "seven billion dollar job" to create the power facilities required to meet this nation's demands for electricity.
The second day of one-way traffic on First and Second Avenues yesterday showed that motorists had adapted themselves to the change.
The City of Birmingham, Ala., borrowed $22,000,000 in the public market yesterday on water supply revenue bonds running from 1954 to 1991 at an interest cost of 2.77 per cent.
Playing "hard to get" may constitute competition, even in the investment banking business, but the Department of Justice and Judge Harold A. Medina did not see eye to eye in the matter yesterday.

A threat that New York City, angered at its "shabby" financial treatment by the state, would seek to secede from New York State and become "the forty-ninth state of the Union" was hurled at Governor Dewey yesterday by Acting Majority Leader Charles E. Keegan in the City Council.

The fifty-fourth annual convention of the American Federation of Musicians meeting at the Commodore Hotel was called upon yesterday by Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to help build a political foundation now for a liberal Democratic victory at the polls next year.
GENEVA, June 5--The Soviet Union told the Western governments today that they could not hurt the Soviet economy by placing obstacles in the way of EastWest trade.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 5-- "The craving for security is sapping the spirit of this nation," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, New York, said today at the 139th annual commencement of the Princeton Theological Seminary, held in the Princeton University Chapel.

THERE is one aspect of baseball that completely defies explanation or logic. That is the slump. Why does a hitter suddenly stop hitting or a pitcher suddenly stop pitching? He does everything the same during failure as he did during success. He tries harder and gets worse. Then in some perfectly unreasonable fashion he's back on the beam again.

Eight 15-year-old boys from two of the "600" schools for maladjusted children gave their views on street gangs in a panel discussion yesterday before 145 pupils of Public School 611, Youth House, at 331 East Twelfth Street.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 5--The three provisional directors of the Iranian National Oil Company, the yet-to-be-established successor to the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, were received today by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi at his summer palace prior to their departure for the oil-producing province of Khuzistan.

LONDON, June 5 (UP)--Mel Patton's time of 20.2 seconds for 220 yards and the total of 8,042 points amassed by Bob Mathias in winning the 1950 National decathlon championship were accepted officially as world records today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

BOSTON, June 5 (AP)--The lastplace Pirates supported Paul La Palme with a twenty-one-hit attack as he shut out the Braves, 8-0, tonight after drawing his first major league starting assignment. It was the fifth straight setback for the slumping Tribesmen, who were limited to five safeties.

PARIS, June 5--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, United States chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, preparing himself for Congressional hearings on the $8,500,000,000 foreign aid bill, received first-hand information today on France's rearmament needs from top French defense officials.

New York University today will graduate 8,673 students at its 119th commencement ceremonies. The exercises will begin at 10:30 A. M. on Ohio Field on the Bronx campus, 181st Street and University Avenue. A curtailed indoor program has been arranged in case of rain.

QUEBEC, June 5 (Canadian Press)--Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec tonight asked newsprint companies to give special pride Consideration to newspapers of Canada, and especially of Quebec, and hinted that if this were not done the province might institute controls.

A test of the speed and efficiency with which civil defense communications workers could take calls for help and dispatch aid to a stricken area in the event of an atomic bombing was held last night at the Queens Borough Control Center.
TRENTON, June 5--Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons invoked a ban on commercial wheels of fortune and bingo games at amusement places and carnivals today.

Annual bank turnover has already reached an estimated 100,000 persons, and in view of the growing shortage of competent personnel, the nation's banks must intensify their training programs to use the full capacities of their present employes.
TOKYO, June 5 (AP)--Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway's Far East Command announced today plans to take single, airtight control over censorship of Korean war news, effective June 15.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, and prices at the close were off 9 to 13 points on all months from Monday's close, except new October which was 41 points net higher.
Mayor Impellitteri presented awards for outstanding bravery yesterday to twenty-eight policemen and the widow of a patrolman who was killed while trying to capture two bandits.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Rumors of an impending compromise on beef price control regulations, which have been under heavy attack from cattlemen, circulated here tonight following a prolonged conference of representatives of cattle raisers and feeders with President Truman and his stabilization chiefs.
Henry A. Wallace denied yesterday that he had ever meant to give the impression that the attitude of American Communists was "patriotic."
A perjury indictment was voted yesterday against Henry D. McEvoy, 62-year-old former stationary engineer member of the Municipal Board of Smoke Control, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.

For the past three days a "plebiscite" has been in progress in Eastern Germany. The people in the Soviet zone were lined up at the polls to answer the simple question: "Are you against the remilitarization of Germany and the conclusion of a peace treaty by the end of the year?"

The five Republican county chairmen in this city, meeting yesterday with William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, flatly rejected Rudolph Halley, chief counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, as a potential coalition candidate for the presidency of the City Council.
HONG KONG, June 5--More than eighty foreign civilians, mainly missionaries, are now reported to be in jail in China. This number does not include those under house detention.
Donations to the Barnard College Development Fund have totaled $330,000 since last July 1, Mrs. Frank Altschul, national chairman of the fund, announced yesterday.
EDMONTON, Alberta, June 5 (Canadian Press)--Upward revision of Alberta Government royalties on petroleum and natural gas production was announced today by Mines Minister Norman Tanner.
CLEVELAND, June 5--Hiram S. Rivitz, nationally known industrialist who was chairman of the board of the Industrial Rayon Corporation, died here last night in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 68.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Unions in industries exempt from emergency price controls argued today that wages in those industries should not be controlled. Some union spokesmen, in fact, contended that it was illegal to control such wages under the Defense Production Act.
United Nations ground unite supported by artillery fire and air strikes, continued to mole forward in Korea yesterday as the enemy fought to halt the advance from well organized defensive positions.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder put the Government on record today as opposed to any general appreciation of currencies in Western Europe.

LONDON, June 5--Two days of discussion between Ambassador John Foster Dulles and Foreign Office officials have failed to reconcile the differences between this country and the United States over the questions involved in the proposed Japanese treaty.
Underwritings of more than $2,000,000 of new common stock of old-established industrial and public utility companies will take effect today.
CHICAGO, June S (AP)--In two mighty scoring thrusts of four and six runs, the sizzling White Sox routed the Red Sox, 10--2, today for their fourth straight victory in three days over Boston.

ROME, June 5--All the major parties--the Christian Democratic, the Communist and Left-Wing Socialist coalition, the Italian Social Movement (M.S.I) and the Monarchist--claimed today to have scored a victory in the Sicilian elections held last Sunday to form a new regional Parliament of ninety seats.
On these late spring days a strange noise comes off the Adirondack lakes. It is the cry of a child in anguish, of a woman in tra vail. It can raise the hair on the head of anyone not used to it.

What promises to be the first clear-cut picture of narcotics traffic and addiction among teenagers in this city will be unfolded next week, when Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein opens public hearings in his two-month-old investigation.

BUENOS AIRES, June 6--The increased prices to be paid for the 1951-52 harvest of Argentina's principal export crops of wheat, corn, linseed and sunflower seed were announced last night by President Juan Peron. His nationwide broadcast obviously was intended to stimulate production.

Evidence of price ceiling violations by several New York meat wholesalers has been sent to the Department of Justice for punitive action, the Office of Price Stabilization disclosed yesterday. The cases are the first here of alleged black marketing in beef since ceilings were imposed last month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6-- Joan Fontaine, who is in Europe, has been signed by Metro-GoldwynMayer to play Rowena in the projected screen version of Sir Walter Scott's "Ivanhoe," with Robert Taylor in the title role and Elizabeth Taylor as Rebecca.
Columbia University will confer 7,610 degrees upon graduates of its sevgnteen schools and colleges this afternoon at the 197th commencement exercises to be held on South Court at 3 o'clock.

An "overwhelming rush" of American students to European medical schools was reported yesterday by Dr. Morris Fishbein, former president of the American Medical Association, on his return from a European survey aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth.
TOKYO, Thursday, June 7 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 907, covering June 6 operations:
Five methods of attacking the nurse shortage, which will be aggravated as more trained professionals are absorbed into the armed forces, are outlined by the Committee of Public Health

LONDON, June 6--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived in England from France today. The general will receive an honorary degree at Cambridge University tomorrow.

Spurred by the United States Supreme Court's decision upholding the conviction of the eleven Communist leaders, the Board of Education will investigate several more teachers to determine whether they are, or ever have been, members of the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, June 6--Dr. Edward Howard Griggs of Alexandria, Va., prominent author and lecturer, died today in a private hospital in Fairfax, Va., after a long illness. His age was 83.

OTTAWA, June 6--Consideration is being given, it is said here, to the request of Price Administrator Michael V. DiSalle for a delay in the imposition of a $10-a-ton increase in the price of newsprint, which Canadian manufacturers have announced for July 1.

The name of James J. Moran, former first deputy Fire Commissioner, cropped up frequently again yesterday in the questioning of prospective jurors in the General Sessions trial of four former firemen charged with participating in a $500,000-a-year shakedown of fuel-oil equipment installers.

Ralph Branca yesterday pitched the Dodgers to their second straight 3-2 triumph over the Cardinals, at Ebbets Field. However, before they can be sure that their fifth consecutive victory is official, the Brooks must await a ruling by the National League president, Ford C. Frick. St. Louis finished the contest under protest.
CLEVELAND, June 6 (AP)-- Great Lakes area carloadings in July, August and September will run 2.4 per cent ahead of the 1950 third quarter, a group of shipping experts predicted here today.

WASHINGTON, June 6--In this period when the Administration's political-military policy in the Far East, both prior and current, is under heavy attack, it is worth noting that one impressive argument can be made for that part which is concentrated in the Korean war, and that the chief point

LONDON, June 6(UP)--Ray Robinson agreed today to defend his world middleweight championship against Randolph Turpin, European and British titleholder, at Earl's Court, July 10, for the largest purse ever guaranteed a fighter in Britain.

Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, challenged advocates of indirect controls yesterday to show how higher taxes could be imposed without undesirable aftereffects of blunting incentives and interfering with the nation's productive capacity.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 6-- Charles E. Meek, retired banker and former president of the National Association of Credit Men, died yesterday in his home here at 67 Hilton Avenue after a brief illness. Mr. Meek, who was 88, had

WASHINGTON, June 6--The House of Representatives, by a vote of 255 to 82, passed today the conferees' compromise bill authorizing a loan to India not to exceed $190,000,000 for the purchase of relief food supplies in the United States. The Senate is expected to follow suit tomorrow.

LONDON, June 6-Foreign Secretary Herbert S. Morrison said in the House of Commons today that despite rebuffs and affronts to British consular officials, Britain still was willing to establish full diplomatic relations with Communist China but, he added, "there have been difficulties at the other end."

CHICAGO, June 6--Beef production was curtailed further through out the country today, with the Chicago plants of two of the "Big Four" packers shutting down their beef departments all day. Spotty beef shortages began to appear, and it was believed that they would become more widespread next week.

VIENNA, June 6--Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner in Austria, revealed today that the United States Government had sent a sharp note to Moscow in connection with the recent shooting of a United States...
The University of Pennsylvania announced yesterday that it would not observe restrictions on the televising of football imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, thereby...
The year 1951, recent events have clearly demonstrated, is not only a year of major international crisis but a year of major significance in the development of atomic armaments.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur himself had approved in 1945 a program for bringing together the Chinese Nationalists and Communists "to promote a United democratic China."

The one-story building at 721 Bloomfield Avenue in Clifton, N.J., formerly occupied by the Edison Venetian Blind Manufacturing Company, has been leased from Sol and Lester Entin by the Lambert Printing and Finishing Company, which will use it for the storage of textile machinery. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Electric Energy, Inc., joined with two of its five sponsors today in an application to the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $100,000,000 worth of bonds to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

An interlocking agreement between two steamship conferences, one Canadian and the other American, which governed freight rates to the United Kingdom, has been voted out of existence by the United States group.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Thursday, June 7--Death, who had been their partner in the past, returned to claim seven Nazi war criminals this pleasant June morning.

For the second program of its season at the City Center the New York City Ballet last night turned largely away from the abstractions of its opening bill and toward more dramatic stuff. Its ballets were William Dollar's "The Duel," Antony Tudor's "Lady of the Camellias," George Balanchine's "Firebird" and, to end on a note of gaiety, Balanchine's "Bourree Fantasque."

BOSTON, June 6--William H. Ruffin, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, advocated tonight a four-point program "to combat the inflation that already has siphoned 45 cents out of every American dollar."

PARIS, June 6--Consultations were in progress tonight among Paris, London and Washington with a view to a common stand of the three Western powers that would not break up the Big Four deputies meeting here and still not yield to the Soviet demand for an agenda item on the North Atlantic Treaty and United States military bases abroad.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service entered the dispute between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and three Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions yesterday in an effort to forestall interruption of shipping.

In reiterating our Government's firm determination to prevent Communist China from shooting its way into the United Nations, Secretary Acheson rightly emphasized on Tuesday that the best way to achieve success in this matter is leadership.

LARCHMONT, N.Y. June 6-- In the chapel of the Roman Cath-- olic Church of SS. John and Paul this afternoon, Miss Shirley Anne Thursby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Thursby of New Rochelle, was married to Lieut. William Michael Quinn, U.S.A. F., son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Quinn of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Flynn. There was a reception at the Larchmont Shore Club.

THE New Jersey coastal fishing is still providing plenty of action through the medium of striped bass and bluefish, and a number of the boatmen are turning their eyes with anticipation toward the off-shore waters, which should begin to provide school tuna within a few weeks.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6-- Gov. John Lodge and Republican legislative leaders yielded today to what they charged was an "ultimatum" from Democratic legislators and accepted the $213,800,000 biennial budget proposed by the Democrats. This budget does not provide for new taxes in Connecticut during the two years beginning July 1.
Entertainers resumed work yes terday at hotels in the Catskill Mountains resort area after a stoppage that began on Memorial Day in Sullivan, Ulster and Greene Counties.
For a few tantalizing moments yesterday afternoon, the Giants could fairly detect the fragrant aroma of second place in the National League flag race.
LONDON, June 6-Philip Furneaux Jordan, press adviser to Prime Minister Attlee and former British press attache in Washington,died at his home here today. He was 48 years old.

An attack against "reactionary" members of Congress and business men who foster inflation by seeking to remove economic controls was made yesterday by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, DemocratLiberal of New York, and former Governor Chester Bowles of Connecticut.
Sixteen leading professionals, including two foreign stars, will begin play today in the Palm Beach round-robin charity golf tourney at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle.

PARIS, June 6--With only eleven days left before the French parliamentary elections, the French electorate is being stirred out of its usual passivity by the resurgence of the Right-wing in French politics.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The Wage Stabilization Board unanimously approved tonight productivity wage increases which meet the conditions and limitations of the General Motors agreement with the United Auto Workers, C.I.O.
A greater exchange of students between England and the United States was urged yesterday by Sir Gladwyn Jebb, United Kingdom delegate to the United Nations.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 6 (UP)--A crippled Air Force freight plane careened through power lines at roof level today and crashed, killing all nine men aboard. Most of the airmen were thrown clear.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The daring Inchon landing in Korea is an instance of military operations that owe at least part of their success to an office known as Weather Central, located at Andrews Air Force Base near here, and to a weather office in New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, June 6-A note delivered Monday to Valerian A. Zorin, Acting Soviet Foreign Minister, by Admiral Alan G. Kirk, United States Ambassador in Moscow, charged that Corporal Gresens had been attacked "without provocation" and that the Soviet High Commissioner in Vienna appeared to have "condoned the crime."
LONDON, June 6--Lord Tennyson, grandson of the poet, died today at Bexhill, Sussex, at the age of 61.

BERLIN, June 6--Provisional final figures announced tonight by Eastern German officials on the Communist "plebiscite" against remilitarization said a total of 99.4 per cent of the eligible voters participated in the balloting in the past three days.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Dismissal of the Government's elevenyear-old anti-trust suit against the American Petroleum Institute was announced today by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath. The action, filed in Sept., 1940, charged a majority of the nation's oil producers with an over-all conspiracy to monopolize the entire petroleum industry.

A banking syndicate headed by the Union Securities Corporation and Equitable Securities Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $20,000,000 thirty-year first mortgage 3 per cent bonds of the Georgia Power Company at a price of 101.871, to yield about 3.4 per cent. The bonds were awarded to the bankers Tuesday at competitive sale at a bid of 101.117.
Revised classification and reporting of crime in New York has resulted in large "increases" in nearly all categories of law violation, according to the annual report of the Police Department.
LONDON, June 6--Navigation for ships and planes approaching the British Isles will become simpler and safer tomorrow with the opening in Scotland of a new chain of radio transmitting stations.

Lloyd L. Schrader, formerly superintendent of personnel and industrial relations at the Morgantown Ordnance Works, has been appointed manager of the industrial relations department of Heyden Chemical Corporation.

Secretary of thg Treasury John W. Snyder said yesterday that the American people's $200,000,000,000 backlog in liquid savings at the end of the war "did more than anything else to prevent a post-war depression."

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 6-- Israel today halted all work on the Lake Huleh drainage project in the disputed demilitarized zone along the Syrian frontier. The dispute over the project had caused two months of sporadic border warfare between Israel and Syria.
The management of the strikebound Manhattan Towers Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street, appealed yesterday to the Board of Health to move a six-day accumulation of garbage and refuse.

In a sweeping move to extend the technical leadership of the free world in telecommunications, three of America's largest companies in that field yesterday entered into an agreement to pool their patents. There was no monetary consideration.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)-- Following is the censored testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees inquiring into the Administration's foreign policy (censorship deletions noted parenthetically):
The city Office of Civil Defense moved yesterday to mobilize New York's clergymen for the local defense organization.
WASHINGTON, June 6--President Truman predicted today that Korea would gain the "peace with justice for which we are dedicated and for which we fight."

There were ten starters in the $12,050 Roseben Handicap, a sixfurlong dash through the Widener Chute, at Belmont Park yesterday. With a little more than a quarter of a mile to go, Delegate was ninth and Miche was tenth. Then they gave it the double-hustle fort a one, two finish.
It does not often happen that there are too many good men available for an important public office, but that appears to be the case with the Presidency of the City Council.

Evidence strongly indicating for the first time that the hormone insulin must combine chemically with the tissues before it can effect the metabolism of sugar was presented here yesterday in papers read before a meeting arranged by the New York Academy of Sciences.

Ninety-five per cent of the graduating class at Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers already have been employed as executive trainees in retailing, it was announced yesterday at the school's graduation luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, June 6--An error by Phil Rizzuto, following a dazzling play by Billy Martin, tonight gave the Browns a 5-4 triumph over the Yankees before 5,936 cash customers at Sportsman's Park. The defeat put the Bombers four and one-half games behind the league-leading White Sox.

A West Side property in the vicinity of Madison Square Garden changed hands yesterday when an investor bought from Harry Horowitz the three five-story buildings on lot 75 by 80 feet at 852-54-56 Eighth Avenue, adjoining the

BROADSTONE, England, June 6 (AP)--Miss Beverly Hanson's bid to add the British women's amateur golf title to her American crown met failure today when the Fargo, N. D., girl was knocked out in the quarter-final round. An English girl and an Irish matron will play in tomorrow's 36-hole final over the Dorset Golf Club course.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 6--While dollar series of department stores in the first quarter of this year were 6 per cent above those of the similar period of last year, net operating profit for the period decliiced. This was announced here today by Raymond F. Copes, general manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at a meeting of the congress in the Jefferson Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 6--The Spanish Embassy took exception today to a statement in a NEW YORK TIMES dispatch reporting remarks made by Jose Felix de Lequerica, Spanish Ambassador, in Detroit yesterday.

DENVER, Colo., June 6--Clifford B, McManus, head of the Defense Power Administration, said today that official Washington is concerned about the power situation in three regions. He said the power supply situation in Washington and Oregon "is critical and will remain so at least through 1953." The Southeastern region, he said, also is a problem.

Albert B. (Happy) Chandler last night told The Associated Press he had turned in his resignation as baseball commissioner contingent on the club owners' acceptance of a self-provided severance contract for his protection.

Long-awaited issuance by the Office of Price Stabilization of a specialized regulation for the export trade should come "without much further delay," a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau was told yesterday at the Statler Hotel.
LONDON, June 6--The public service of the British press was signalized by King George VI tonight in the bestowal of honors on the occasion of his official birthday which will be celebrated tomorrow.

Away from the New York stage for twenty-three years, George Cukor, one of Hollywood's topnotch directors, plans to return to the legitimate field next fall. While no contracts have been signed, the noted motion-picture director has promised Gilbert Miller to stage his forthcoming production of "Gigi." This is the Anita Loos adaptation of the novel by Gabrielle Colette, 77-year-old French author.

ST. LOUIS, June 6--Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall, vigorously defending the United States' foreign policy today, asserted that the prestige of the Communists in Asia had been dealt "a deadly blow" in the last month in Korea.

Henry D, McEvoy, who was indicted for perjury Tuesday three weeks after he had resigned under attack as a member of the Board of Smoke Control, stands to receive an annual pension of about $4,000 a year from the city.

SAIGON, Indo-China, June 6-- Yencuha, key position in the French defense line guarding the Tongking delta in the south, changed hands twice in a bitter battle between Vietminh rebels and French Vietnamese troops Monday and Tuesday.

By next spring Hanover Square may have a little park with a nautical monument. This was indicated yesterday at a luncheon arranged by the Greater New York Civic Center Association and held in the headquarters of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in 65 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Congress began today to take another look at itself, through hearings of the Senate Expenditures Committee, with a view to improving its efficiency and perhaps streamlining its agencies.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 6-- Boris Christoff, who could not get a visa to enter the United States last fall to fill an engagement with the Metropolitan Opera, is a singing actor of major stature. This much could be ascertained last night when this listener heard him for the first time in Verdi's "Sicilian Vespers" at the Florence Festival.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., June 6--Edith Macy Training School, the Girl Scouts' national adult education center on 265 acres of wooded hillside near here, began a celebration today of its twentyfifth "birthday."

WASHINGTON, June 6--Newspaper publishers and American manufacturers of newsprint were invited to meet with Office of Price Stabilization officials here on Tuesday to discuss advancing Canadian newsprint prices and their probable effect upon prices of American newsprint.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Seth W. Richardson, Washington attorney and self-described "lifelong contentious Republican," presented to President Truman today his resignation as chairman of the Subversive Activities Control Board.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 6 (UP)--A Hawaiian hurler pitched three-hit ball today as Springfield College downed Brown University by 2-0 and became the New England representative in the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament play-offs at Omaha, Neb., starting next Wednesday.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has signed Mike Wallace, Chicago radio and television personality, to a long-teim contract and will introduce him to eastern audiences on Monday, June 18, in a new television series, "Meet the People." The program will be seen Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 3:30 to 4 P. M.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)-- Announced United States combat casualties in Korea reached 68,352 today, an increase of 925 since last week.

IT was almost like a page from the pastalmost but not quite. The Dodgers and the Cardinals, perennial rivals for the National League pennant, again came to grips at Ebbets Field yesterday, still running one-two from force of habit. But the Red Birds from St. Loo no longer scare the Flatbush faithful as was their wont in younger and happier days.

Market trends in commodities futures trading were generally up yesterday, only coffee displaying any independence of movement. On the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange coffee dipped 31 to 48 points in sales of 22,750 bags when scale-down covering proved insufficient to match trade selling was apparent. No Brazilian interest was in the market.

A redevelopment plan for Harlem, covering generally a new housing project, parking facilities, landscaped areas, playgrounds and stores, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall.
A hospital ambulance attendant who allegedly "took care" of $280 belonging to a man seized with a heart attack was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a grand larceny charge.

MANCHESTER, England, June 6(UP)--Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., rushed through three rounds of the Northern lawn tennis tournament today in an effort to make up for lost time. Keeping pace with him were three tardy American women.

After settling on the locality for a summer holiday, the next problem for most women is the selection of a wardrobe and a travel costume that is not only modish but practical. Advice from seasoned travelers on all sides warns against taking too extensive a wardrobe, while the first requisite for a travel costume, regardless of its destination or method of getting there, is that it be wrinkleresistant.

WASHINGTON, June 6--Stopgap legislation that would give the Federal Government unchallenged control of oil and gas-bearing off shore lands for five years was endorsed today by two Cabinet members.
TRENTON, June 6 (AP)--A state psychitarist said today he doubted that the police forced confessions from defendants in the Trenton Six murder trial.

The industry, however, is experiencing serious difficulty in obtaining sufficient critical materials.

Seven industrial states yesterday set up machinery to cooperate in the suppresion of illegal distilling.
WASHINGTON, June 6--President Truman is expected to appoint W. Averell Harriman to the chairmanship of the National Security Resources Board within the next few days.
The winning designs from a group of 16,341 costumes submitted in the National Sewing Contest were shown last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and the awards presented.
Samuel Reshevsky took the lead last night in the Wertheim Memorial tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club when he defeated George Kramer in forty-nine moves. Kramer played the Nimzowitsch defense.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP)-Chicago's White Sox, off on a new victory binge, chalked up their fifth consecutive triumph today by defeating the Senators, 4-2, before 5,665 chilled spectators. The victory was the White Sox's nineteenth in their last twenty-one games.
Another textile company has leased a floor in the new Sinclair Oil Building at 600 Fifth Avenue.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 6-- Teheran was buzzing today with rumors of extraordinary concentrations of Soviet troops on maneuver along the northern frontiers of Iran.

New York University celebrated its 119th commencement yesterday with the conferring of degrees and certificates on 8,673 graduates and the presentation of honorary degrees to six public figures. Awards for distinguished service to the institution went to five alumni.
DETROIT, June 6 (AP)--Third Baseman George Kell's diving catch of a bases-loaded line drive in the ninth inning stopped a Red Soa rally and gave the Tigers a 6-4 victory today before 9,002.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a 12 per cent increase in the capital gains tax on corporations.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 7--The Allied offensive moved forward for small gains in North Korea yesterday, occupying ground that Chinese and North Korean Communists had abandoned for stronger positions.

The food-to-India bill has advanced another important step in its slow progress through Congress. Negotiations by Long Island University to purchase the Brooklyn Academy of Music from the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences were made public last night by William Zeckendorf, president of the L.I.U. trustees and head of Webb Knapp, Inc., realty concern.

The State of North Carolina borrowed $75,000,000 in the public market yesterday on secondary road bonds due serially from 1954 to 1970 at an interest cost of 1.944 per cent. Edward J.
