J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturer, had a consolidated net income in the six months ended on April 28 last, of $12,780,985. This compares with $9,927,431 cleared in the corresponding period of the previous fiscal year.

United Nations forces smashed into the Communists' "iron triangle" and captured large stores of arms. Although the enemy was withdrawing from this strategic area he was resisting bitterly east of the Hwachon dam. [1:8; map P.2.]
Two striking points come out in the third annual report on the Marshall Plan, issued today by the European administration, the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

ST. LOUIS, June 10--New York's retail price war was ascribed here today to the failure of advertising to move inventories. With a few notable exceptions which she mentioned, Mrs. Sara Pennoyer, vice president and sales promotion director of James McCreery Co., described post-war advertising as suffering from "mathematical myopia."

CHICAGO, June 10--The Yankees had hopes of leaving here tonight only a half game out of first place after Ed Lopat had pitched them to a 2-1 victory over the White Sox and they had picked up a 4-0 lead in the second game behind Allie Reynolds.

Larry Evans, national speed chess champion, gained his second consecutive victory in the Wertheim memorial tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club, yesterday, when he defeated George Kramer, former New York State champion, after forty-eight moves in the sixth round.

ROME, June 10--The current battle between democracy and the political extremes in Italy resumed today when 8,115,000 eligible voters went to the polls in 2,161 municipalities of thirty provinces to elect new city and provincial administrations for five-year terms.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 10-- Late goals by Archie Young and Johnny Rice enabled the Horse Shoe Club to break a 4-4 tie and go on to a 6-4 victory over Long Island in the opening game of the weekly series on Hitchcock Field...

THE most tantalizing and elusive championship in the entire realm of sports will be up for grabs this week-end, when the National Open is held at Oakland Hills, just outside of Detroit. The best players invariably rise to the top in every phase of athletics--except golf. The divot-digging pastime has more "uncrowned champions" to the square inch than any other sport.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 10--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, left here this morning for Washington. There he will attend the budget hearings of the House Appropriations Committee asking for money for some of the things the United States wants to do in Germany.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 10--An attendance of 13,000 physicians from all parts of the country and many foreign lands is expected at the five-day meeting of the American Medical Association, which opens tomorrow.
Philip Horowitz has been appointed buyer of fashion coats and fall suits for the Newman-Benton stores, an affiliate of Lane Bryant, Inc.
John Frederick Pierson, a member of a socially prominent New York family, died yesterday at the Medical Arts Center after a long illness. He resided at 27 East Sixty-second Street. His age was 79.

Looking hopefully toward using the tailend Pirates as a handy springboard by which they would elevate themselves clear out of sight as they plunge into the West again, the Dodgers had their plans rudely disrupted at Ebbets Field yesterday.

A food encyclopedist, according to the local office of the State Extension Food Marketing Program, writes that strawberries were so named because originally they were strung on straws for easy carrying to market.

CONCORD, Mass., June 10--In the chapel of the Middlesex School here this afternoon, Miss Margaret McDiarmid Winsor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Winsor of Weston, was married to John Delano Stubbe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stubbs, also of Weston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles E. Park. A reception was held in the Winsor home.
Strong northeasterly winds that sometimes attained forty-mile-anhour gusts whipped nearby waters and imperiled the lives of persons on several small craft in the city area yesterday.

DALLAS, June 10 (UP)--L. M. Crannell Jr., bespectacled Navy veteran from North Texas State College, won the Trans-Mississippi golf championship today with a crushing 7-and-6 victory over Don Adding ton of Southern Methodist University.

WASHINGTON, June 10--Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service --worried about the possibility of a total shutdown of transatlantic and Gulf shipping at midnight Friday--tonight called representatives of the ship owners and the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., to separate conferences here Tuesday.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP)--Dick Kryhoski, Vic Wertz and Pat Mullin supplied the home runs and Freddie Hutchinson and Bob Cain the pitching as the Tigers swept a double-header for the first time this year, whipping the Athletics, 11--7 and 9--5, today.

WASHINGTON, June 10--The MacArthur inquiry will resume tomorrow with testimony by Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, but the principals in the case have all been heard and the general conclusions here on the controversy seem to be about as follows:

CLEVELAND, June 10 (UP)-- The Red Sox brightened a gloomy Western swing by sweeping both ends of a double-header with the Cleveland Indians today, 9 to 6 and 8 to 2, before 54,956. Boston regained undisputed possession of third place as a result, breaking a tie with Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, June 10--The Point Four program may lose its identity, if not its aim of aiding underdeveloped countries, as a result of a jurisdiction issue that may soon see the "bold new program" transferred from the State Department to the Economic Cooperation Administration.

The Storm Sash Company, a national organization with home offices in Ohio, has leased the new one-story factory building on plot 150 by 100 feet at 4332 Bullard Avenue, the Bronx, from Antonio Giordano, builder and owner, for the manufacture of storm sash for...

The Government's organization for national security--the Defense Department and the agencies most closely allied with it--has made episodic, but generally steady and major, progress since last fall toward the development of a smoothly working mechanism.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 10--A golfing star from the Argentine, Roberto De Vicenzo, captured his first United States tournament by winning the Palm Beach roundrobin at the Wykagyl Country Club course today by a margin of 12 points.

LONDON, June 10-Talk of the revaluation of currencies of the Western World, particularly sterling, has quickly faded as a stack market factor and trading now is influenced by other more practical and immediate events.

The week-end at the City Center found the New York City Ballet giving season's premieres to Todd Bolender's "Mother Goose Suite," George Balanchine's "Divertimento," Jerome Robbins' "Age of Anxiety," and Lew Christensen's "Jinx."
FLORENCE, Italy, June 10--It has taken 160 years for Haydn's opera "Orfeo Et Euridice" to have its world premiere.

VIENNA, June 10--Walter J. Donnelly, United States High Commissioner, left for Washington by air today to report on the special case of Austria, sometimes called the "problem child of the Economic Cooperation Administration" for further American assistance.

Cuts in the Federal budget for five years hence should be prepared now, the National Industrial Conference Board asserts in a report released for publication today. Steps taken so far this year to reduce outlays planned for years as far ahead as 1958 and even...

CHICAGO, June 10--The new price controls on beef can work "unless some groups attempt to break this thing," E.F. Phelps Jr., assistant director of the Office of Price Stabilization, Washington, D.C., asserted today. Mr. Phelps spoke at the opening session of the annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 10-- Strawberries by the ton are crossing the auction block here as the season moves into high gear. Truckloads of the red, juicy fruit are moving from eastern Long Island farms to urban tables as more than 500 acres of strawberry beds offer peak production this week.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 11--Mike Turnesa fashioned a record 7-under-par 64 at the Ardsley Country Club today to monopolize the spotlight in the oneday pro-amateur tourney of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 11-- Dr. Cornelis W. de Kiewiet was invested today as the fifth president of the University of Rochester in a simple ceremony at the Eastman Theatre.
Sixty-five thousand members of the Ladies Garment Workers Union in the New York metropolitan area and upstate will leave their jobs today in the industry's first strike in a quarter of a century.

Harold R. Medina is a singularly happy choice for the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, and we congratulate President Truman on the appointment. Judge Learned Hand had served with such distinction on this bench, and his recent retirement was felt so keenly, that the filling of ...

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 11-- Although political party leaders, especially left wingers, still attack the United Nations embargo as the main cause of the fall in the price of rubber that is threatening Indonesian economy, official circles no longer are sure this view is correct.

The first Marine Corps reservists in this area to be returned to civilian life were released yesterday at the corps headquarters, 346 Broadway. The twelve men, four of whom were Korean veterans, had been recalled to duty last July.
NEW HAVEN, June 11--Twenty-five of the nation's leading scholars, including four Nobel Prize winners, received honorary degrees here today at Yale University's 250th commencement.

The nation's steel mills set a new record for production last month, turning out 9,094,000 tons. This exceeded the previous record set in March by 23,000 tons. The increase over the April volume was 253,479 tons.
MOSCOW, June 10--The Ministry of light industries staged an eighty-minute fashion parade today at the Central House of Fashions. The displays ranged from beach pajamas to evening frocks.
GENEVA, June 11--Rearmament can be financed without inflation, the Bank for International Settlements states in its annual report released in Basle today.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Defense officials threatened today to cut the volume of rearmament orders Canada is receiving from this country should the announced $10-a-ton price increase of newsprint be put into effect by Canadian paper mills.

The state inquiry into narcotics addiction will bring together, at its first public hearing today, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein and Superintendent of Schools William Jansen, who differ sharply on the extent of the evil among school children in this city.

Three thugs who forced their way into the home of a prosperous Brooklyn steel manufacturer last night robbed the man, his wife and daughter of $14,000 worth of jewelry and $310 in cash. The hold-up men escaped.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)-- Representative Charles A. Wolverton, Republican of New Jersey, said today the United States might some day find itself short of oil unless it makes good use of foreign supplies.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 11--Yugoslav authorities have arrested Vojslav Srzentic, Assistant Finance Minister, in connection with the disappearance of files containing records of the Yugoslav Government's negotiations with the ...
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)-- The nation's wheat crop is making a comeback from bad weather conditions and now promises the eighth successive harvest of more than a billion bushels.

Radium, always associated with uranium, was discovered at Great Bear Lake, Canada, in 1930. At that time uranium was in slight demand as a ceramic coloring agent, and radium was used chiefly in medicine and for painting instrument dials and indicators so that they could be read at night.

A doll-faced Japanese girl, not yet 7, is on her way by plane from Tokyo to become, her father hopes, "an apostle of international friendship" by living in the home of a New York attorney. She had been scheduled to arrive at La Guardia Airport last night but was delayed en route and is expected here tonight.
Dr. John Dewey, wearing the blue and maize doctoral hood of the University of Michigan, came out of retirement yesterday to receive an honorary Doctor of Letters degree from Yale University.

ST. LOUIS, June 11--Frank L. Howley, the now inactive brigadier general who faced the Russians as commandant in Berlin during the critical days of the airlift, bitterly denounced today the "Russian containment" policy of the United ...

Tremendous expansion of productivity in less-developed areas, guided by industrial research providing technical knowledge, is more basic to solution of world problems than political actions, it was emphasized yesterday at the opening of the second annual Conference on Industrial Research.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced the acquisition of two new story properties today, "Death at Attention," a recently published magazine serial by Kem Bennett, and "Oh Promise Me," a comedy written for the screen by Vera Caspary.

Developments in Japan make it an increasingly attractive field for American investment and Bache Co. continues to have a lively interest in that field, Harold Bache, partner in the New York Stock Exchange house, declared yesterday.
LONDON, June 11--The United States and Britain have virtually agreed to drop the idea of a single supreme commander in the Mediterranean, according to reliable information here.

Following quickly on their decisive defensive victory, in repulsing two Communist spring offensives, the United Nations forces in Korea have resumed their own offensive and scored another major triumph. After more than a week of hard fighting, in which American, Greek, Turkish, Filipino and Thai troops joined in a common ...

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11-- Syrian Premier Khaled el Azam announced today that he had instructed the Syrian delegation at the United Nations to protest the permission reportedly granted to Israel by Maj. Gen. William E. Riley, United Nations Chief of Staff in Palestine, to resume work on the Lake Huleh drainage project.
The shortage of beef, begun by a "strike" of cattlemen a week ago as a protest against Government price control, had not yet affected the New York retail stores yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 11--The Senate adopted by a voice vote today the conference report on the bill to lend famine-threatened India $190,000,000 to buy 2,000,000 tons of food grains or their equivalents.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 11-- Louis S. St. Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada, told 3,478 graduates of Northwestern University today they would never know "normal" American lives without having to worry about the problems of the entire world.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 11-- Harold F. Moore, a retired New York City detective lieutenant, who won the Police Department Medal of Honor, died today in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, after a brief illness. His age was 50.
Three hundred and fifty students and eighty educators sailed yesterday for Europe for a summer of work, study and travel.

Amphora, the George D. Widener thoroughbred who has been idle since last summer's meeting at Saratoga, returned to the races yesterday and achieved a wellearned victory. Competing in the featured Sheila Purse, a sevenfurlong affair for fillies, the 3year-old daughter of Bull Lea proved best of a ten-horse field.

Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, with all four of the soloist singers born and trained in the United States, will be the major work performed by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at the Edinburgh Festival. It will be presented on Sept. 2 and repeated at the final concert on Sept. 4.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 11-- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Priestley Greenwood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn, to Harold Croman Buckelew Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Buckelew of South Orange.

BUENOS AIRES, June 11--Several thousand students of the National University of Buenos Aires stayed away from classes today in protest against the failure of the police either to release or to arraign a fellow-student taken from his home twenty-five days ago and of whom nothing had been heard since.

DODGE CITY, Kan., June 11 (AP) --A proposal for a state and federally financed research project on greenbug and mosaic disease damage to wheat was made by 300 farmers and business men in a state-wide metting here today.

Strength in the oils sparked a new recovery in the stock market in slightly more active trading yesterday. The leadership for the petroleum section was supplied by Standard Oil of New Jersey, which climbed more than 4 points. Buying in this issue apparently stemmed from the two-for-one stock split that will be made tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Three of the six public members of the Wage Stabilization Board today stressed that their decisions applied as much to employes organized into independent unions as to those enrolled in affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

CHICAGO, June 11--Except for 1946, when the Office of Price Administration controlled the wholesale price of cattle, Eastern packers are obtaining the largest proportion on record of live animals shipped out of Chicago's stock yards.

WESTPORT, N.Y., June 11-- Harry P. Wareham, executive vice president of the American Hearing Society and a former leader of Community Chest activities, died in his home here this afternoon of a heart ailment. His age was 68.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 11 (U.P.) --The Pacific Coast Conference today gave the green light to televise the post-season Rose Bowl game, and said representatives would discuss "experimental" video games for this fall.

MOSCOW, June 11--Pravda asserted today that, if the United States went ahead with plans for a separate peace treaty with Japan, the pact would "never be recognized by the peace-loving peoples nor by the people of Japan itself."

Canada is one of those blessings that Americans take for granted. There it is--great, friendly, free, a partner in the "cold war" of whom we are so sure that we rarely stop to think about it any more than a New Yorker does about California.

WASHINGTON, June 11--In the Metropolitan Club of Washington there is a luncheon table where anyone is welcome, but to be sure of a chair he must get there early. By 1 o'clock it usually is filled, and the interesting but contentious conversation which is responsible for this is already in spate.

LONDON, June 11--Amid all the conflicts and perplexities of the world scene there is an essential simple fact of which we must never lose sight. The British Commonwealth and Empire and the United States need each other and must live and work together.

THIS has been a funny baseball season, meaning funny peculiar and not funny ha-ha. It has been a campaign of streaks of all descriptions. They have ranged from the fourteen straight by the amazing White Sox to the eleven straight (in reverse) by the not-so-amazing Giants.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Defense Production Administration and the Federal Security Agency announced jointly today that supplies of steel, copper and aluminum for essential school, college, library, hospital and health facility construction have been authorized for delivery in the third quarter under the Controlled Material Plan.

UPLIS TSIKHE, U.S.S.R., May 26--An hour's ride back into the mountains from Premier Stalin's birthplace of Gori and over the precipitous cliff-hung road along the Kura River lies a curious and ancient monument to the days of man's earliest civilization--the city of Uplis Tsikhe, which means in Georgian "God's Fortress."
The only book published today is "The Secret Army," by T. BorKomorowski, which Macmillan is selling for $4. It is an account of the Polish Home Army from 1939 to 1944.

IT was rainy that summer of 1939 in the Adirondacks. The guests of Miss Schmidt's boarding house were continually scurrying for shelter, either to the inadequate protection of the pergola or back to the shabby old house which had once been such a splendid monument to nineteenth-century plutocracy.

ROME, Tuesday, June 12-- Italy's democratic forces surged ahead early this morning in a running battle against the pro-Soviet parties on the basis of 28 per cent of the returns for provincial and municipal elections in thirty provinces.
WASHINGTON, June 11--President Truman charged today that House amendments to the Interior Department appropriation bill would cripple an expanded public power program needed for defense production.

In a fashion spectacle that was notable for luxury, Maximilian showed his fur collection for the fall and winter yesterday in the roof restaurant of the St. Regis Hotel. There were many style notes, though none blatant. Good taste as well as skill made this a show of quality.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Commuters between points in New Jersey will pay the same fares as their fellow commuters who cross the state line, if the Interstate Commerce Commission follows the recommendations made today by one of its examiners.

Some sort of fiber or material, which is unlimited in supply, resilient by nature and inexpensive, is needed by the Marine Corps for clothing insulating material. This was reported yesterday by BrigGen.

The State Crime Commission in an unexpected move obtained yesterday a court order for the minutes of the Third September (1943) New York County grand jury dealing with the influence exerted by Frank Costello in getting the Democratic nomination for Supreme Court Justice for Thomas A. Aurelio.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was easier again yesterday and closing prices were 12 to 34 points net lower than on last Friday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 11-- Several weeks of intensive negotiations, in which a representative of the Mizrachi Organization of America attempted the role of mediator, have failed to reconcile the four parties of Israel's Orthodox bloc.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 11--Non-Communist agitation against German rearmament received a severe check when the Government recently rejected a request from Pastor Martin Niemoeller for a national plebiscite on the issue of German defense contribution.
Lord Wilmot, former British Minister of Supply, denied yesterday that there was a split in Anglo-American relations.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11-- Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, widow of the former President of the nation and of Princeton University, laid the cornerstone today of a building that will house the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs on the campus here.

A week-end tragedy in the choppy waters of Long Island Sound resulted in the death of eleven persons when a fishing boat struck a submerged object Sunday afternoon and sank off Plum Island, near Orient Point, L.I.

William B. Devoe of 300 East Fifty-seventh Street and South Egremont, Mass., a retired New York lawyer who had been a legal adviser to shipping interests here, died on Sunday in Albany, after a two-week illness. He was 66 years old.
TOKYO, Tuesday, June 12--United Nations troops, in one of their most important victories since the Chinese intervened in the Korean war last year, rolled into Chorwon and Kumhwa ...
DETROIT, June 11 (AP)--A 17year-old schoolboy shortstop, Ted Kazanski, signed a contract with the Philadelphia Phillies today for a reported bonus of more than $80,000.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., yesterday asked unionized employes of the Consolidated Edison Company not to supply power for subways in case of a transit strike July 1.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam won his seventh-round game with Robert Byrne in the Wertheim Memorial tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. The former world champion from the Netherlands then had a score of 5--2 against 5--1 for Samuel ...

WASHINGTON, June 11--Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer recommended today that the United States pull out of Korea, go into full mobilization and break off relations with the Soviet Union as the center of the free world's danger.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 11-- King Leopold has decided to abdicate July 16 and Prince Baudouin, the acting head of state, will be proclaimed King of Belgium the next day.

PARIS, June 11--Alexandre Parodi, secretary general of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, agreed today with President Truman's special representative, John Foster Dulles, on the main issues of the Japanese peace treaty but made reparations claims that contrasted with Mr. Dulles' desire for a "treaty of reconciliation."

The Red Cross and the City's Civil Defense organization combined their efforts last night to increase the blood bank for the armed forces and to encourage enrollment in Civil Defense units during a rally at the Eastern Parkway Skating Rink, 1435 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

"Alice in Wonderland," the Ansco color adaptation of the Lewis Carroll classic featuring actors and puppets and produced in France and England by Lou Bunin in association with J. Arthur Rank, will have its American premiere at the Mayfair and Sixtieth Street TransLux Theatres, on Thursday, July 26, according to Souvaine Selective Pictures, the distributors.
Retailers were warned yesterday not to use "misleading" advertisements in an effort to sell more television sets and other electrical appliances.
WASHINGTON, June 11--Ambassador Warren R. Austin pledged today that the United Nations forces in Korea would fight on until the Communist aggressor "has had enough."

LONDON, June 11--Japanese bonds, which had been in demand recently on hopes of an early peace treaty with Japan, were sharply depressed on the stock market here today on a statement by John Foster Dulles, dispelling this optimism. Most of the Japanese issues lost up to 3 points.
As a precautionary measure against some manifestations of polio, the Department of Health will suspend immunization against diphtheria and whooping cough from June 15 until Oct. 1 at ...
Prices of rugs and carpets, which have been climbing steadily since mid-1949, started turning downward yesterday.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 11 (AP)--Gov. Fuller Warren today replaced all members of the State Racing Commission, including Chairman Leo Edwards, who is president of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)-- Bolivian Ambassador Ricardo Martinez Vargas denied today that Bolivia is a part of any international tin cartel.

The peoples of the free world must "constantly strive to find areas for agreement" with the Soviet Union, Percy C. spender, Australian Ambassador to the United States, said here yesterday in his first official statement in that capacity.

NINHBINH, Indo-China, June 11 --The smell of death still hovers around the crumbled French post of Yencuha where fallen Vietminh soldiers lie half submerged in the rich green rice paddies and a company of Moroccan troops is now rebuilding the drab fort brick by brick.

The City of New York has borrowed $24,000,000 from local banks on tax anticipation notes maturing over a year at interest of 1 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph said yesterday. Of the total $4,000,000 will become due on Aug. 1, $2,000,00 on Oct. 3, $2,000,000 on Jan. 9, 1952, and $16,000,000 on June 12, 1952.

Directors of the Dayton Rubber Company increased the quarterly dividend rate on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 45 cents a share, payable July 25. In the two previous quarters 30 cents each was distributed, prior to which 15 cents was paid.

New issues of stock totaling more than $21,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings are new common shares of chemical and public utility companies and of an Oklahoma bank. All of the transactions are underwritten by investment bankers. The offerings are as follows:

The third week of the local price "war" opened yesterday with crowds approaching the record numbers that harassed sales clerks in participating stores in the furious opening days. Price cuts also were reminiscent of the beginning of the "war," at least in men's summer suits.

The Council of the Living Theatre, founded to rekindle interest in the commercial theatre and to revitalize American theatre-going habits, announced yesterday the allocation of $25,000 for a scheme designed to stimulate business on the road.

For the first time in years, insofar as an important heavyweight bout is concerned, the International Boxing Club will start the sale of general admission tickets early tomorrow morning for the fifteen-round heavyweight battle between Joe Louis and Lee Savold tomorrow night in the Polo Grounds.

Directors of Canadian Pacific Railway Company announced yesterday a dividend of 75 cents on the common stock, payable on Aug. 1. The first declaration for 1951, 25 cents results from railway earnings and 50 cents from other sources.

Louis J. Glickman, operator, has resold the former Dun Bradstreet property at 326-34 Broadway, southeast corner of Worth Street, to the Mailing Equipment Corporation. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker and the attorneys were Margolin, Feldman Blinkoff for the seller and Alexander Kopp for the buyer.
BUFFALO, June 11--The tendency of many Protestants to regard churchgoing as little more than an optional feature of worship was sharply condemned here tonight by a leading Baptist clergyman.

The American destroyers Nicholson and Woodworth were turned over to the Navy of the Republic of Italy here yesterday afternoon at Navy Pier 26, at Beach Street. The Nicholson (DD 442) will be renamed the Aviere (Airman) and the Woodworth (DD 460) will be called the Artigliere (Artilleryman).
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11--Vassar College conferred Bachelor of Arts degrees upon a class of 309 young women this morning at the school's eightyseventh commencement program.

WASHINGTON, June 11--St. Alban's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Margaret Ann Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Golden Carter of Washington, to David Monroe Marsh, son of Mrs. Harold Newman Marsh also of Washington and the late Mr. Mash.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Democratic and Republican lines appeared to break further today as the Senate spent a third day debating economy cuts in the $2,528,000,000 Labor Department-Federal Security Agency appropriation bill. This is the first regular money measure before the Senate this year.
TRENTON, June 11--Three defense lawyers stressed an alibi defense and the element of reasonable doubt in the first-degree murder case against six Trenton Negroes as the case neared its end today.

LISBON, Portugal, June 11-- More than 500 delegates from twenty-seven countries met here today to seek means of safeguarding their prosperity and standards of living despite the huge expense of essential rearmament programs for defense.

Beltsville white turkeys, the specially-developed "apartment-size" birds weighing from five to ten pounds, are now, for the first time since they appeared on the market, lower in cost than regular turkeys.
Estimated requirements for leather footwear for the Army and the Air Force for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will come to 1,000,000 pairs a month, the Department of Defense announced yesterday.

An emergency meeting of officials of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., from thirty-two ports to consider the breakdown in negotiations between the union and Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping operators will be held here tomorrow.

FLORENCE, Italy, June 11-- Emil Ghilels led off tonight with the first of eleven programs that are to be presented by a delegation of Russian musicians and dancers at the annual music festival here. Playing in the Teatro Communale, the pianist scored a triumph as the audience stood and shouted "Bis," and made him play encore after encore.

The National Broadcasting Company's local television station, WNBT, became the first outlet yesterday to begin regular broadcasts from the new 222-foot transmitting tower atop the Empire State Building.

In an effort to forestall the destructive effect of the Kem amendment on our entire foreign policy, President Truman is reportedly planning to stretch to the limit the one loophole afforded by that mischievous piece of legislation.
New York was hailed yesterday by the National Safety Council for "so effectively providing leadership in the field of safety for municipal employes.

WASHINGTON, June 11--A Department of Agriculture spokesman said today that so far as feed supply and animal numbers were concerned, there was nothing in the present situation that should indicate an impending meat famine.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 11--Miss Anne McKinne Heitkamp, daughter of Mrs. James Bishop Stout of New York and Frederick B. Heitkamp of Westfield, N.J., was married here this afternoon to Arthur Dale Wolf, son of Mrs. Dale Wolf of Norwood, Ohio, and the late Mr. Wolf, in the Fairchild Chapel of Oberlin College.
ALBANY, June 11 (AP)--A billion dollars of defense plant expansion is planned or under way in New York State, the Department of Commerce said today.

MILAN, Italy, May 25 (By Air Mail)--The degree and nature of the evolution of European decorative arts is shown convincingly and exhaustively in the current Triennial Exhibition, the second since the end of the war and the ninth since its inception.

Six hundred mothers and children crowded into the special events center at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn yesterday for a fashion show of maternity clothes and advice on wardrobes, beauty preparations and well-adjusted children.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11-- Admiral Raymond A. Spruance, retired, said today that his personal approval of a NationalistCommunist coalition could not be read into the MacArthur-Wedemeyer-Spruance "China recommendations," recently made public by Secretary Acheson.

ST. LOUIS, June 11--Arthur C. Fatt, executive vice president of the Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., outlined here today advertising's task as the increase of productivity in the United States by 4 per cent annually, instead of the 3 per cent generally set as the goal.

WASHINGTON, June 11--H. Graham Morison, Assistant Attorney General, declared today that he was trying to weed out defense agencies' business task forces that operate "under a cloak of Government authority but without Government check."

TEHERAN, Iran, June 11--Basil R. Jackson, deputy chairman and top negotiator of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, said on his arrival here today that his mission was intent on finding in talks with the Iranian Government a compromise solution to the oil controversy.

WASHINGTON, June 11--A 20 per cent withholding tax on dividends, interest and royalties, collectible at the sources and expected to bring in about $423,000,000 a year that otherwise might escape the Treasury, was approved finally by the House Ways and Means Committee today.
CHICAGO, June 11 (UP)--Thieves rode off today with the $75,000 spent by cheering Chicago White Sox fans for hot dogs, soda pop, peanuts and other refreshments over the week-end.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11-- Hundreds of human beings of all ages born with cleft palate, cleft lip, or both, have been restored to normal in appearance and speech through the cooperative efforts of the surgeon dentist, psychiatrist and speech specialist.
Prices of futures in the commodities markets here were mixed yesterday. Wool, vegetable oils and cocoa drifted moderately lower. Sugar and coffee climbed a little.

Alexander Summer of Newark, N.J., president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, has been named a vice president of the new international federation of real estate managers and brokers which was formed early this month in Paris.
LONDON, June 11--Members of the House of Commons showed considerable anxiety about Britain's security arrangements today, as the search for two missing Foreign Office officials continued.

Action by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange on the proposed referendum on Saturday closings is likely on Thursday, when out-of-town governors will be in New York for a "policy meeting."

GENEVA, June 11--A picture of a Russia so involved in the gigantic tasks of economic development that it could not possibly be preparing for war was drawn today for the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe by Amaszasp A. Arutiunian, the Soviet delegate.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Defense Board for Meat has recommended buying meat for American troops in the Far East and Europe from sources outside the United States until greater supplies of beef become available within this country.
ABOARD S.S. CONSTITUTION AT SEA, June 11--An attractive young matron of Brookline, Mass., held the distinction today of being the first "stowaway" on the new luxury liner Constitution.

A minor modification of the new rule barring over-size trucks from the Garment Center after 8 A.M. was obtained yesterday by the trucking industry. However, after thinking it over, industry officials decided it was a hollow concession and said they planned court action to prevent the city from carrying out the regulation.

TAEGU, Korea, June 10--The law first laid down by the Japanese barring Korean women from wearing traditional long silk skirts has been resurrected in the "beconscious-of-the-war" campaign that will begin next week in a street-by-street roundup of men and women seen wearing "excessively luxurious raiment."

PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, June 12 (AP)--Hymen Schlesinger, an attorney, was arrested and jailed without bond last night on a sedition charge preferred by Matthew Cvetic, former Federal Bureau of Investigation undercover agent.

Only 257 feet along the foul line from home plate to the right field stands, the Polo Grounds presented an inviting target to Ted Williams, Boston's slugger extraordinary, in an exhibition game against the Giants last night. Most of the 5,586 fans, who turned out for the benefit of the National Amputation Foundation, did so apparently because of greater interest in Williams than in the outcome of the ball game.

Sales of Remington Rand, Inc., reached a record of $187,486,771 and earnings before taxes also made a new mark of $29,266,628 in the fiscal year ended with last March, James H. Rand, president and board chairman, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP)--William C. Foster, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration, predicted today that the National Security Council would make certain exceptions this month to the new law banning United States economic aid to nations selling war-potential goods to Iron Curtain lands.

Senator Warren G. Magnuson said yesterday that he was convinced after recent talks with Japanese officials that all problems affecting the restoration of the Japanese merchant marine and its effect on the fleets of other nations could be worked out without great difficulty.

CHICAGO, June 11--Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, urged today that price controls be permitted to expire June 30, warning that if they were re-enacted it would be "exceedingly difficult ever to return to a free choice system."
President Truman yesterday made four Federal judicial appointments affecting the New York area, at least two of which were of possible political and popular significance.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation announced yesterday the sale of its security holdings in the ACF-Brill Motors Corporation to a group headed by Charles Allen Jr. and Allen Co., New York investment banking firm.

BRAWLEY, Calif., June 11 (AP) --Imperial Valley's striking farm workers demand the ouster of the United States Ambassador to Mexico, William O'Dwyer, and assert that the United States and Mexican Governments are strikebreaking.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12-- Princeton University today notified the University of Pennsylvania that it would not sign a football contract for their scheduled game of Oct. 13 at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, unless Penn includes a clause supporting the National Collegiate Athletic Association television plan.

PARIS, June 12--Edouard Daladier, who was the Premier who represented France at Munich, predicted tonight in a broadcast to the French people that an alliance of parties championing free enterprise and calling itself the "Fourth Force" would elect 200 Deputies in next Sunday's elections and thereby become the greatest power in the new Chamber.

Joe Louis will know tonight whether he is to pursue his campaign to become the first boxer ever to regain the world heavyweight title.

Action on the Korean front yesterday centered in the east-central sector, where enemy delaying units continued to resist strongly the advance of United Nations ground forces. Friendly elements repulsed several probing attacks in this sector during the period.

CHICAGO, June 13--Wheat prices were reactionary today following the big recovery of yesterday, but declines were not extensive. CHICAGO, June 14 (UP)--Farmers and cattle feeders hurled boos and catcalls at Michael V. DiSalle today, but the Government price chief stubbornly defended his price rollback and said the cattle market had "returned to normal."

Jerome Robbins' ballet, "The Cage," had its premiere with the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center, with Nora Kaye in its chief role. In spite of the fact that it lasts for less than fifteen minutes, it is easily the most important work of the season.
Hundred-tablet bottles of Bayer aspirin sold for 4 cents yesterday at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn. Macy's, Gimbels and other department stores engaged in the price war offered two bottles for 9 cents.
A new turbojet plane that will help the Air Force put increased range into its fighter fleet was announced yesterday at Farmingdale, L.I., by the Republic Aviation Corporation.
LISBON, Portugal, June 14--The police of thirty-six countries, who concluded a five-day meeting here today, plan to intensify their war on narcotics smuggling by air.

"I am going to talk to you," said President Truman in last night's radio address, "about a real down-to-earth problem that affects the daily life of every American. * * * That is the problem of inflation and high prices." From these introductory sentences Mr. Tru
This was the slogan of the Fianna Fail party in the Irish elections, and it was fulfilled when a close vote the Dail restored Eamon de Valera to the place he occupied for sixteen years.
GENEVA, June 14--Competition is the key to the American workers' high standard of living, a United States employers' spokesman told the International Labor Organization conference here today.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., June 14-- Lawrence May, a retired engineer and designer of oil burners, died on Sunday at Brunswick General Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 67. He lived at 325 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York.

New local laws that will make major changes in the retirement and pension systems affecting policemen, firemen, street cleaners and health department employes were signed yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri at City Hall.

The ease with which addicts who have the money can buy narcotics along the Coney Island boardwalk, in Broadway dance halls and restaurants, Bronx candy stores and all sorts of places in this city was revealed yesterday at the state inquiry.
Two more in the recent series of jewel robberies in East Side hotels came to light yesterday.
Directors of the Childs Company elected a new president and other officers at a meeting yesterday and took no action on the 31 cents preferred dividend due on June 30.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, June 14--The Fifth Holland Festival opened tonight with a concert in the Medieval Hall of Knights before an invited audience of 600 persons including representatives of the Royal Court, high government officers, and the diplomatic corps.

Shareholders of the Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings voted last ngiht to convert the savings association into a Federal charter type of operation under supervision of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

The over-all responsibility of the schools is to educate young persons who will be aware of their American heritage and imbued with democratic ideals, Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Commissioner of Education, declared yesterday in his preliminary annual report.

BUFFALO, June 14--Dr. Benjamin E. Mays, prominent Negro educator and clergyman, told the American Baptist Convention tonight that Protestant churches throughout the country should "take a daring step" and throw their doors "wide open" to Negro worshippers.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14-- Benjamin G. Browdy, president of the Zionist Organization of America, charged tonight that Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion and other Israeli Government officials were attempting to weaken the structure of the world Zionist movement.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP)-- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of New York, proposed a new and lasting United States foreign policy today based on total disarmament--including atomic bombs--and a world economic development plan.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP)-- A Federal Communications Commission examiner recommended today that the commission drop its "slanted news" proceedings against radio stations in Los Angeles, Detroit and Cleveland.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 14 --Frederick H. Hurdman of this city, senior partner of Hurdman Cranstoun, certified public accountants of New York, died today in White Plains Hospital.

The jury has now returned its verdict in the case of the six Negroes on trial for the murder of a Trenton shopkeeper in 1948. Two of the defendants were found guilty with a recommendation of mercy, and four were acquitted.
OMAHA, June 14 (AP)--Tennessee ousted Princeton from the National Collegiate A.A. baseball championships today by taking a 3-2 victory on the six-hit pitching of right-hander Billy Bowman.

Loans for defense purposes were a major influence in the increase of New York bank loans to business last week, reversing the downtrend of the three previous weeks and pushing outstanding commercial loans $35,000,000 higher.
Excerpts from the recorded confessions of narcotics addicts, as played back at the state inquiry yesterday follow:

A. Edward Masters' French-bred Titien II, a winner on the flat and a record-cracker over the hurdles, tried racing over the big jumps for the first time at Belmont Park yesterday and made a $7,750 success of it. That's how much the 5-year-old horse earned in winning the $11,375 Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap.
The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday by unanimous vote the spending of $80,000 to buy, without public letting, 1,500 parking meters to be installed in five test areas in the city.

MARIETTA, Ohio, June 14-- The coaches who will send out the twenty-eight crews in the forty-ninth annual regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association here Saturday picked the University of Washington again as their varsity favorite today and made known their dissatisfaction with the racing conditions on the Ohio River.

The fact that frankfurters, now about 69 cents a pound, are just a little less than half the price of other beef cuts, such as porterhouse or sirloin steak, is undoubtedly the strongest point in favor of the once-lonely "hot dog."
ASCOT, England, June 14 (AP)-- French-bred and owned Pan II breezed home by three lengths today to win the coveted Ascot Gold Cup and 11,162 ($31,253).

In four or five days Thomas Paiva Jr., 2 years old, who on May 1 fell fifteen stories from his parents' apartment at 20 Catherine Slip in the Alfred E. Smith housing development, will be able to leave Bellevue Hospital and go home.

NEW ORLEANS, June 14(AP)-- The mightiest atomic explosion yet seen by Congressional observers vaporized the steel tower on which the bomb was mounted and blasted everything except a few charred palm tree stumps from an Eniwetok Atoll island.

PARIS, June 14--Former Premier Edouard Hdrriot, winding up the vigorous campaign he has conducted despite his age and physical disabilities, made a last appeal in Lyon today to preserve the French Republic in the elections next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- Announced United States casualties in Korea reached 70,317 today, an increase of 1,965 since last week.

The American Legion yesterday canceled a circus planned for next Sunday in Poughkeepsie for the benefit of disabled soldiers and promptly fell into a dispute with Governor Dewey's office over whether he had ordered police action to prevent the show.

The Office of Naval Research is developing a system of appraisal of the country's needs for expanded reserves of qualified professional research personnel in the fields of science, engineering and industry.

In the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Ann Hotz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schutler Hotz of 223 East Sixty-second Street, was married to William Irvin Waterhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Waterhouse of Newtown, Conn.

A new collection of fabrics, many enlivened with the hot colors and amusing patterns usually associated with Mexican designs, are now on view at the House of T. Fabrics, 72 East Fifty-sixth Street. The shop carries the designs created by D.D. and Leslie Tillett for drapery and upnoistery materials.

The flag whose raising atop Mount Suribachi helped to inspire the United States Marines fighting for Iwo Jima will go on display under armed guard today, as 1,000 veterans of the Fifth Marine Division open a two-day convention in the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, June 14--United States, British and French economic experts have recommended to their governments an unparalled tri-power program of economic assistance to Yugoslavia, it was announced today by the Foreign Office.
Since last January the State Department, with John Foster Dulles as its roving Ambassador, has been working on the problem of a peace treaty with Japan. Mr. Duller has roamed to good purpose.
Expanding cargo activity in Port Newark has made a new construction program necessary, according to Joseph M. Byrne, Jr., vice chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

Club owners of the National and American Leagues, convening in separate sessions at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, "reached a decision" on the severance contract submitted to them by A.B. (Happy) Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 14-- The marriage of Miss Lorinda Payson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson of New York, Manhasset and Portland, Me., to Vincent William de Roulet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry de Roulet of Los Angeles, took place here this afternoon at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church or Northern Boulevard.

Brooklyn College conferred 2,039 degrees on the third largest graduating class in its history last night at its twenty-sixth commencement exercises. Rain forced the ceremonies from the campus quadrangle into Roosevelt Hall, the gymnasium.
To housewives about to set out for week-end shopping, city Commissoner of Markets Anthony Masciarelli said yesterday that in meats, pork loins and fresh and smoked hams were the best selections.

LISBON, Portugal, June 14-- Business and industrial leaders of the Western powers, meeting here, took up today the vital question of the world supplies of raw materials and the economic effects of the vast rearmament programs.

With July 17 set as the date for the first big sale of the newly perfected public housing bond backed by the Public Housing Administration, the bond departments of the big banks and the municipal finance specialists of investment houses are at work clearing decks for the first public bidding and distribution.

The five-story building 1235-1237 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, containing eight stores and fiftyfive apartments, has been purchased by the R.B.R. Holding Corporation from a syndicate represented by Green Selzer, attorneys.

ROME, June 14--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany arrived in Rome by air late this afternoon for a four-day official visit. He is one of the few heads of foreign governments who have come to Rome after the war in their official capacities, and his reception was warm.

The General Tire Rubber Company disclosed here yesterday the "secret" of its synthetic rubber development which, it claims, permits output of 32 per cent more tires at a 31 per cent lower rubber cost and uses one-third or more of low-cost petroleum oil as one of the manufacturing materials.

CINCINNATI, June 14--Against a club that has not defeated him since the 1948 season, Larry Jansen was not at his pitching best today, but the Giants right-hander had sufficient support to go all the way for an 11-6 victory over the Reds.
The Coast Guard announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to take over part of the old marine hospital on Ellis Island to house its expanding port security force.

BUENOS AIRES, June 14--Student leaders of the National University called off today their protest strike in the face of the reported reappearance and arrest of a missing student in whose behalf the strike had been called and of reprisals taken and threatened against any more absenteeism from classes.

The stock market's course shifted yesterday to the higher side because of a renewal of demand for the oil issues. Standard Oil of New Jersey, which in the two preceding sessions had set the pattern for the list, pushed forward with more than usual vigor and encouraged bidding in a number of other petroleum stocks.
TOKYO, Friday, June 15 (AP)-- General Headquarters communique 915, for the twenty-four hours ended 6 A.M., Friday (4 P.M., Thursday, Eastern daylight time):

Graft that for years had been paid to Fire Department inspectors by fuel-oil equipment installers in individual and haphazard fashion was put on a business-like basis by former First Deputy Fire Commissioner James J. Moran so that it could be channeled into his own pocket, according to testimony in General Sessions yesterday.

Pile-driving ceremonies this morning wilt start construction of the new $10,000,000 South Street Elevated Highway, final link in the peripheral express highway system around west, south and east Manhattan.
Flag Day, commemorating the 174th anniversary of the adoption of the flag by Congress, was celebrated here yesterday with public displays of the flag and ceremonies by patriotic societies.

Judge Harold R. Medina, just nominated for promotion to the United States Court of Appeals, told lawyers yesterday in the Government's anti-trust suit against investment banking firms that delay in the adjudication of the suit would be "unfair" to his colleagues in the Appellate Court.

A COLLEGE president invariably is a man who is known only to fellow-educators end rarely to the public at large. In many respects he is like a baseball umpire. The more efficient and accurate he is the less he is noticed by the spectators. But whenever he boots one, that's when the catcalls ring out loud and clear from the stands.
ST. LOUIS, June 14--Gil Hodges' twentieth homer of the year, an electrifying shot in the ninth inning with Duke Snider on base, gave the Dodgers a spectacular 2-1 triumph over the Cardinals today.

PARIS, June 14--Despite the fact that the tactical airpower of Western Europe at the disposition of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower is inadequate, Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, United States Air Chief of Staff, asserted today that the force available "would give a very good account of itself" in the event of a Soviet attack.
Overcast skies and intermittent rain failed yesterday to dampen the Port of New York's reception for the new Argentine luxury liner Rio Tunuyan.

City College conferred 3,187 bachelor's and master's degrees at its 105th commencement last night in Lewisohn Stadium. This year's class was somewhat smaller than classes of the last two years because of shrinkage in the enrollment of war veterans.

The marriage of Miss Kathleen Berryman McMahon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Timothy McMahon of Manhasset, L.I., to William Whitesides Warner, son of Mrs. Leonora H. Warner of 10 East Sixty-second Street, took place yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in East Eightyninth Street.

OTTAWA, June 14 (Canadian Press)--Production Minister C.D. Howe said today it is important that the free press in countries threatened by communism get supplies of newsprint. The result may mean slightly less newsprint for North American users.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 14--A dock worker who surrendered to the Hudson County prosecutor's office last Monday was formally charged today with the murder last May 21 of Uunzio (Wally) Aluotto, another longshoreman, who was fatally wounded in the headquarters here of Local 867, international Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

PARIS, June 14--Moscow has issued a series of new orders to the Greek Communist party to make underground preparations for a future renewal of civil war in that country and to build up the party's forces for "decisive struggles." Such struggles, Moscow holds, are "inevitably" approaching as a result of current political crises in Greece.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- An underwater explosion, believed caused by a Communist mine, Tipped the United States destroyer Walke in Korean waters last Tuesday, killing twenty-six men and injuring seven others.
OTTAWA, June 14 (Canadian Press)-- Canada today increased the price of wheat by six cents a bushel, effective immediately on domestic sales and on Aug. 1 on sales to foreign countries.

DUBLIN, June 14--A representative repertory of Irish drama will be presented at leading American universities by a company that Ronald Ibbs will send to the United States at the end of this month. Mr. Ibbs, whose productions have won high reputation, is completing arrangements for the tour.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 14-- Maxwell C. Maxwell, retired executive of the Yale and Towne Manufacturing Company and former works manager of the Stamford division, died last night at his farm in Cambridge, Md. He was special assistant to the firm's president when he retired in 1949. His age was 75.

Mrs. David M. Green, a grayhaired, bespectacled woman of medium height, who teaches dress designing at the Prospect Heights High School, Classon Avenue and Union Street, Brooklyn, came home last Friday night after a shopping tour "in a fit of indignation."

ROME, June 14--Thecreation of "an association without limits" bettween Western Europe, the United States and Canada if the international situation should deteriorate any further was suggested today by Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza in a speech at a Foreign Press Association luncheon in Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP)-- Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilizer, said today that amendments to the Defense Production Act suggested by the Ford Motor Company, would "cut the heart out of any fair and sound stabilization program."
A whole "family" of atomic bombs is now a part of the American atomic arsenal.
ZURICH, June 14--Never, has any annual report of the Bank for International Settlements of Basle been awaited so eagerly as that issued last Monday covering the year ended March 31, 1951.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June I4 --New York City is so supercharged, the American Physical Society learned here today, that 80 per cent of its lightning travels up. In other communities lightning comes down.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)--A "complete revision" of defense lending policy was promised today by Edwin T. Gibson, acting Defense Production Administrator, in disclosing that a proposed $7,800,000 loan to the Hazleton Steel and Tubing Corporation would be withheld.

TOKYO, Friday, June 15--Enemy resistance stiffened yesterday where United Nations troops pushed out from the captured "iron triangle" area in central Korea, driving toward the Communist base at Kumsong, on one of the main roads to the Sea of Japan.
BERLIN, June 14--Deterioration of the East German economy was verified today by a spokesman for the Office of the United States High Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, June 14--There is still vague talk here about getting together with the Russians in a meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers in Washington next month but the primary need is to get the Americans, the British and French together, at home and with each other.
A movement is being organized among tenants of London terrace Gardens in the Chelsea area to withhold rent on July 1 in an effort to force a court review of the rents being paid by 970 tenants.

Robert B. Blaikie, Tammany leader of the Seventh Assembly District, but otherwise known as a political independent, was disclosed yesterday to have been one of several persons who suggested to the Liberal party that that group nominate Rudolph Halley, former chief counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, for President of the City Council.
BIRMINGHAM, Mich., June 14 --For the first time since 1934, the golfing experts today failed to break par in the initial round of the United. States open championship.
The Cerebral Palsy Society of New York opened a three-day drive to raise $750,000 "tag day style" on a city-wide scale yesterday with a mid-morning ceremony on the steps of the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Traffic congestion in New York streets and, curiously enough, Chicago bookmakers were among outstanding accident causes cited today at the President's Highway Safety Conference here.
Through the portals of the driving school at the New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn pass some of the safest drivers at the controls of the nation's trucks, tanks and other vehicles.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)-- Two Senators proposed today the use of government lending and taxing powers to curb the concentration of new industries in congested areas.

Passenger car tolls on the six facilities of the Port of New York Authority will be cut 20 per cent for "regular users other than commuters" effective Sept. 1, and bus and truck tariffs will... be lowered 10 per cent under a new schedule announced yesterday.

THERE are still a few hardy fishermen left, and two of them called yesterday to report that weather was no obstacle to a real angler, and in addition to producing good fishing it usually offered more solitude than the bright, sunny day provided.

Michael Newman, operator who bought the two-story taxpayer on lot 20 by 80 feet at 804 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Sixty-second Street from the William Waldorf Astor Estate last year, has resold it to William Rosenblatt for cash over a mortgage of $85,000.

Stewart Camden Pratt of 770 Park Avenue and Culpeper, Va., retired vice president of the National City Bank of New York and City Bank Farmers Trust Company, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, after a brief illness. His age was 65.

HAIPHONG, Indo-China, June 13--A picture of deteriorating guerrilla resistance in Kweichow and Yunnan Provinces was drawn here today by the remnant of the Nationalist troops who recently crossed the China-Tongking border and found sanctuary in the French-controlled areas of Indo-China.

CHICAGO, June 14--Warehouses throughout the country generally are filled to 95 to 100 per cent capacity, largely with home appliances, Curtice B. Robertson of Oklahoma City, president of Associated Warehouses, Inc., said today in an interview.

WASHINGTON, June 14--After six days of wrangling over economy cuts, the Senate passed and sent to conference today an appropriation bill carrying $2,527,844,386 to run the Labor Department, the Federal Security Agency and associated bureaus through the fiscal year starting July 1.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., June 14 --Vice Admiral Newton Alexander McCully, U.S.N., retired, died yesterday in a hospital here after a long illness. He would have been 84 years old next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 14--By the time the former Secretary of Defense, Louis A. Johnson, finishes his testimony before the Senate inquiry on the dismissal of General MacArthur the public may get a balanced view on at least one controversial issue.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged in the Senate today that there existed a conspiracy, with which he associated Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, and General of the Army George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, to weaken the United States for its conquest by the Soviet Union.
Upsets caused by oversights under time pressure marked the ninth round of the Wertheim Memorial tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.

In his Texas speeches General MacArthur has called upon the United States to display anew the courage, vision and forthrightness that have animated this nation in the past. In doing so, he struck a welcome blow against the counsels of "discouragement ...

Rained out of the Polo Grounds for the second successive night, the fifteen-round heavyweight battle between Joe Louis and Lee Savold yesterday was shifted to Madison Square Garden, where it will be conducted tonight without interference from the weather.

ALBANY, June 14--Governor Dewey charged today that Federal hydro-electric projects "financed with our money in other sections of the country" were "helping to put New York and New England out of business."

HAIFA, Israel, June 14--A slick new automobile rolled off the ramp today in the presence of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion to inaugurate the plant of KaiserFraser of Israel, Ltd.--a symbol of the Near East industrial center Israel's leaders hope to make of this country.

WASHINGTON, June 14--The flow of strategic materials from West Germany to Communist areas has dwindled appreciably during the last few months because of heavy and constant pressure applied to the Bonn Government, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, told a Senate subcommittee today.
In an intensified drive resulting from the current state investigation detectives of the Police Head quarter's narcotics squad conducted a series of raids last night in East Harlem.

The Board of Education charged yesterday that the "good intentions" of Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein's investigation of drug addiction among school children were being "vitiated by his apparently mistaken notion of who the enemy is."

HANOVER, N.H., June 14-- Mrs. John French, former president of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association, died tonight in the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital here at the age of 82. She had broken a hip at her home in Woodstock, Vt., two days ago.

WASHINGTON, June 14--The House Ways and Means Committee, in an unexpected revision of its omnibus tax-increase bill, approved broad exemptions today in a provision to impose a 20 per cent withholding tax on dividends, interest and royalties.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a

Thirty-five men, most of them said to have come from Italy and Spain, were rounded up on the Hoboken, N.J., waterfront last night as suspects of being shipjumping aliens. It was the second big raid of its kind there this week.

Tracked down in his Connecticut retreat, Maurice Evans confirmed a report yesterday that he is purchasing a three-year option on "The Teahouse of the August Moon," Vern Sneider's recently published book dealing with the American occupation of Okinawa.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14--Dr. I.S. Ravdin, chief surgeon of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and Hospital in Philadelphia called upon American surgeons today to clean house of certain practices by a small segment of surgical practitioners which, he said, "threatens our great heritage."

TEHERAN, Iran, June 14--A conference of representatives of the Iranian Government and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company opened at the Finance Ministry here tonight in an atmosphere of complete uncertainty as to the prospect for a settlement in the BritishIranian oil controversy.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 14-- Dr. Richard L. Meiling, chairman of the Armed Forces Medical Policy Council in the Office of the Secretary of Defense, declared today that the Armed Forces "will require approximately 13,000 physicians continually on active duty for a period of tension expected to last about ten years."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 14-- Miss Allen Gregg was introduced to society tonight at a large supper dance given jointly by her mother, Mrs. Will Reeves Gregg of 1 East Sixty-sixth Street and Grelen, Orange, Va., and her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. George Garland Allen of New York and Scarsdale, in Spottiswoode, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Allen in Scarsdale.
WASHINGTON, June 14--President Truman told the nation tonight that price, wage and rent controls would be needed for at least two more years even if the fighting in Korea were to end soon.

CHICAGO, June 14--The late announcement that August wheat allocations for export would be made this afternoon, together with apprehension in regard to rainy conditions in the Southwest, where harvesting is being delayed, gave wheat prices a late rally to well above yesterday's close.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 14--The Socialist Reich party, West Germany's most successful neo-Nazi organization, is about to amalgamate with Bavaria's most important party of the radical Right. This is the Bavarian Economic Reconstruction party, headed by Alfred Loritz, whose followers call him "the blond Fuehrer."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 14-- Adding a three-overpar 78 to her first two rounds of 75, 82 for a total of 235, Miss Patricia O'Sullivan of Orange, Conn., carried off the Women's Eastern Golf Association's 54-hole medal play championship over the Montclair Club course today.

Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, declared yesterday that the party was going to "fight" to keep its Politburo out of jail and to "protect" its members and organizations.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 14--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur charged tonight that there was a campaign under way in the United States to "pervert the truth," create fear and confuse the American People.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP)-- Six men, armed, masked and threatening to kill, escaped today with $24,000 seized in an electric company building in suburban Bellwood after firing at a guard. Police answered the alarm but a long freight train at a crossing delayed the arrival of their squad car for five minutes. Five of the gunmen carried pistols and the sixth a machine gun.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 15 (UP) --Thirty orphans from the Methodist Children's Home will have cake, ice cream, airplanes and fathers in Air Force blue this Sunday. Airmen at near-by Lockbourne Air Force Base plan to "adopt" the children for Father's Day. The youngsters will get to "fly" the Link trainers and play in real airplanes.
A new playroom on the fifth floor of Metropolitan Hospital, Welfare Island, was formally opened yesterday by Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri.

HONG KONG, June 15--Back from eight months of shattering combat in Korea, a steadily increasing number of the depleted units of Gen. Lin Piao's famous 400,000-man Fourth Field Army are returning to their old stations in Kwantung.
Cedric W. Lutz has been appointed director of purchases for Gulf Oil Corporation, effective on July 1. He is now assistant to the vice president in the Houston (Tex.) production division.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 (AP)--The Cardinals trounced the Phils, 10--2, before 9,320 fans tonight. Harry (Peanuts) Lowrey, Billy Johnson and Stan Musial led the attack.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 15--The fate of the Iran oil industry was hanging in balance today while the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company delegation, here for talks with the Iranian Government, pondered its answer to yesterday's Iranian ultimatum.

MADRID, June 15 (AP)--Madrid police announced today the arrest of two men charged with stealing 70,000 pesetas ($6,405 at the official exchange rate) from Lieut. Col. Robert B. Simpson, a United States Army attache of the embassy here. The two arrested men were seriously wounded while trying to escape, the police said.

The Brooklyn Museum's outstanding series of period rooms that reflect in such authentic detail life in the seventeenth, eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, will be added to in the fall with a Victorian twosome that teriors up to the Eighteen Eighties.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (UP)--A well-known restaurant here today announced a 10 per cent reduction in the price of every beef dish. Charles E. Rohr, owner of the restaurant, said "the reduction is due to the lowering of our food costs as a result of the dollars-and-cents ceiling prices the Office of Price Stabilization has placed on beef."

HANOI, Indo-China, June 15French and Vietnamese authorities took special steps today to thwart the purchasing activities of Ho Chi Minh's infiltrating guerrilla agents in the rice-rich Red River delta.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 15--Janacek's "Jenufa," an opera that is about as uncharacteristic of the Netherlands as a mountain landscape, was the first major production tonight of the 1951 Holland Festival.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has granted $33,450 to the National Health Organization for Public Health Nursing to enable that organization to continue its joint orthopedic nursing advisory service to nurses, nursing, schools and public health nursing agencies.

CULVER CITY, Calif., June 17 (UP)--Lau Wen Gnau, a Chinese, today won the Western Hemisphere marathon, running twentysix miles in 2 hours 54 minutes 10.4 seconds. WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)-- Joseph M. Friedman, widely known trial attorney for the Justice Department, died of a heart attack here last night. His death followed by only a few hours the death of Federal Judge T. Alan Goldsborough, before whom Mr. Friedman had tried some of his most famous cases.

TOKYO, Monday, June 18 (AP)-- The Navy said today it had inflicted 8,635 Communist casualties in four months of relentless bombardment of the strategic North Korean rail, highway and port city of Wonsan, on the east coast.

HAVANA, June 17--Two bomb explosions have caused some damage but no injuries. One was at the home of Dr. Antonio Vignier, first judge in the celebrated case against former President Ramon Grau San Martin. The other was at a clothing store.

A certificate of incorporation for the Yarn Dealers Institute, Inc., has been filed, it was announced yesterday. Temporary officers are: Harry Segal of Dabern Textiles, chairman; Michael Trachtenberg of Industrial Manufacturers, Inc., secretary, and Irving A. Tannenbaum of the company bearing his name, treasurer. The association is composed of independent synthetic and natural yarn dealers and jobbers.
CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP)--A critical scrap iron shortage is threatening the nation's booming steel production, Steel Magazine said today.

The New York County Lawyers Association reported yesterday that its committee on Federal legislation had approved an antilynching bill for the first time. The group endorsed a measure by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, because it appeared to have a better constitutional foundation than previous proposals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17-- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, suggested today to members of the senior class that they plan their lives on the premise that the present armed truce between East and West would be terminated by a general settlement, rather than by war.
Only two films, both emanating from Hollywood, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

Gen. James A. Van Fleet, United States Eighth Army commander.
CHICAGO, June 17--Three major developments, which mainly concerned wheat, but indirectly affected all grains, marked the grain trade in the past week.
Mrs. Florita Rogovoy was back in Times Square again yesterday, surrounded this time by red, white and blue bunting and the flags of the United States and Israel.
HANOVER, N. H., June 17-- Dartmouth College's graduating seniors were warned today by the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr against "man's natural error of thinking of himself as the center of the world."

Conant, president of Harvard University, is chairman.
The current basic real estate tax rate of $3.08 for each $100 of assessed valuation, the highest in the city's history, will be continued in the new fiscal year beginning July 1.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 17 (AP) --Eugene Meyer, chairman of the board of The Washington Post, told Stanford University's sixtieth graduating class today that the major problem facing the world was extending progress to undeveloped areas. He spoke at ceremonies for 1,465 graduating seniors and 1,410 candidates for advanced degrees.

There will be a preview performance of the new musical, "Seventeen," at the Broadhurst Theatre on Wednesday night under the sponsorship of Congregation Ezrath Israel, also known as "The Actors' Temple." Tickets are available at the congregation's office, 339 West Forty-seventh Street.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 17-- Miss Patty Berg's long quest for the Weathervane open golf championship ended in success today when she defeated Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, last year's titleholder, in the final half of the thirty-six-hole play-off.

David Schor has been appointed out-of-town sales manager for Department L of the Cohama division of Cohn-Hall-Marx Company. The division handles plain rayon suitings, sportswear and coating fabrics for the women's and men's ready-to-wear trades. Mr. Schor formerly was with the Ameritex division of the company.

Miss Carol Ellis Zimmerman was married yesterday to Norman Hammer, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Joseph Hammer of Brooklyn, in the home of her stepfather and her mother, Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Shamos of 120 East Eighty-ninth Street.

Many cast changes have not affected the merry career of "Kiss Me, Kate" at the Shubert Theatre. The latest batch to join the company tonight are Marc Platt, Bobby Vail and Tony Montell, who will replace Danny Daniels, Jack Diamond and Harry Clark, respectively.

OXFORD, England, June 17 (Reuters)--Prof. Arthur Lehman Goodhart, 60-year-old American, was elected today master of University College, Oxford. He will take up his new duties in August.

Two thousand persons attended yesterday's ceremonies marking the official opening of the international headquarters of the Histadrut, the National Committee for Labor Israel, in the Western Hemisphere.

Alice Richmond, soprano from Union, N. J., won the singing competition that was held Saturday night at Town Hall as the climax of the Music Education League's twenty-eighth season of auditions. As her reward, Miss Richmond will appear as soloist with the Little Orchestra Society on Jan. 6 next year.
At the end of last month the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe released an addendum to the yearly survey it had issued earlier.
