An appalling lack of trained personnel and sociological machinery necessary to the moral reeducation of thousands of youthful first offenders who come before the court each year is stressed today in Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper's annual report on the Court of Special Sessions.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)-- Washington swept a three-game series from Cleveland behind the three-hit pitching of Fred Sanford and Mickey Harris today, beating the Indians, 5--1. Sanford, recently acquired from the Yankees, won his first decision of the year.
SYDNEY, June 17 (AP)--Joseph B. Chifley, former Prime Minister of Australia, who died on June 6, was buried today on a slope facing Bathurst, city of his birth.

How best to adapt the city's vast new school building program to other community needs is discussed by the Public Education Association in the fourth of a series of reports that already have discussed size, design and construction of elementary schools.

In twenty-two day-care centers throughout the city last week, students from the School of Nursing at Adelphi College, Garden City, buttoned on nursery teachers' smocks and set to work finding out what children are like when they're well and healthy.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP)--Stan Musial, first man up in the tenth for the Cardinals, homered to give St. Louis a 5-to-4 triumph over the Phils today. It was Musial's second four-bagger of the contest and enabled the Redbirds to sweep their three-game series with the Phils.

ATLANTA, June 17 (AP)--Josephine Baker, Negro singer, today canceled her Atlanta appearance after three white hotels refused accommodations. Miss Baker was scheduled to appear at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

GENERAL of the Army Omar N. Bradley did not get around to writing his military memoirs as promptly as several dozen of his high-brass comrades in arms. From the time he headed the Veterans Administration authorship for him was a week-end avocation.

In a major effort to relieve traffic congestion the City Planning Commission yesterday proposed two zoning amendments that would require nearly all non-residential buildings in the city's principal commercial and manufacturing districts to provide off-street berths for loading and unloading trucks.
OMAHA, June 17 (AP)--Oklahoma came from behind tonight to defeat Tennessee, 3 to 2, for the National Collegiate A. A. baseball championship.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 17-- John Swenehart, director of advertising and publication relations for the Atlas Powder Company, died here yesterday in the Delaware Hospital after an illness of six weeks. His age was 60.

NORTHFIELD, Minn., June 17 (AP)--Dr. Curvin H. Gingrich, editor of Popular Astronomy magazine and Professor of Mathematics and Astronomy at Carleton College here, died of a heart attack today at the age of 70.

Record production of 3,000,000 pounds of silica gel has been reached by the plant of the Culligan Zeolite Company at San Bernardino, Calif., it is announced by Harold F. Werhane, president. He said that if defense and shipping requirements demand it output will be doubled. The plant produces desiccant for Method II packaging of materiel which can be placed in operation immediately on arrival.

PARIS, June 17--The sixth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will open here tomorrow, with the prospects of sharp controversey over the organization's place in United Nations activities to protect the free world from aggression.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I, June 16-- Students majoring in retailing at Hofstra College will work in Long Island department stores and specialty shops for credits as part of the retailing program for the fall term, it was announced today. Students enrolled in the regular fouryear course will be required to work at least two terms on a parttime basis in a store.

SYOSSET, L. I., June 17--Joseph Bragg's Erin Go Bragh from Brookville captured the jumper championship with 15 points in the one-day V. F. W. horse show at Joseph M. Klein's estate today. The reserve went to Mary McGowan's Little Wonder.
At his Blue Spruce Inn in Roslyn, Carl Werner annually serves more than seventy wedding luncheons or dinners, the majority, of course, in June.
It was a perfect late spring day. The hornpipers and the fiddlers played Irish airs and dancers swirled in Celtic jig and Highland fling.
Several organizational changes affecting its New York management group were announced yesterday by Standard-Vacuum Oil Company.

ROME, June 18--The Italian Government's efforts to bring about closer relations between Italy, France and Germany with a view to strengthening Western European unity advanced another step today at the end of his fourday visit to Rome of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany.

National and local law enforcement officials conceded yesterday that facilities for checking the current narcotics addiction wave "of hurricane force" and rehabilitating its victims were totally inadequate.

Mayor Impellitteri's special transit committee was told yesterday that the municipal transit system would run $38,000,000 "in the red" next year if the panel ordered a forty-hour work week made effective July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 18--The two Senate committees that since May 3 have been investigating President Truman's recall of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur from his Far East command unanimously decided today on a quick termination of their task.

WASHINGTON, June 18--Some of those Republicans who are filling the air with anguished outcries over the blanket suspension of the Kem amendment by the National Security Council are excellent examples of politicians who do not practice what they preach.

WASHINGTON, June 18--The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which has a monopoly on the importation and sale of tin in this country, announced another cut today in the sale price of tin metal to American industry amounting tn five cents a pound.

BERLIN, June 18--Sergei A. Dengin, Berlin representative of the Soviet Control Commission, sent a letter late tonight to the commandants of the three western sectors asserting in effect the right of the Soviet to control all shipments from West Berlin.
A truck containing 13,000 pounds of kosher beef was hi-jacked by three thugs early yesterday in Brooklyn.
TAIPEI, Formosa, June 18 (AP)-- President Chiang Kai-shek insisted tonight on Nationalist China's right to participate in a Japanese peace treaty.
George D. Widener's Tahitian held on long enough to win the Islip at Belmont Park yesterday.
The seven-story apartment house at 1143 Fifth Avenue, near Ninety-sixth Street, has been purchased by a client of Samuel Morganroth, attorney, who plans to convert it largely to professional use.
A narcotics "pusher" awaiting sentence in Federal Court testified yesterday at the departmental trial of two demoted narcotics squad detectives that he had given them money to escape arrest.

MIAMI, June 18 (UP)--Sheriff "Smiling Jimmy" Sullivan, indicted in the Dade County gambling investigation, quit his office today in the face of new Senate Crime Committee investigations into why Gov. Fuller Warren had reinstated him.

SUMMERVILLE, Ga., June 18 (UP)--Pickets overturned an automobile full of women workers at the strike-bound Berryton Mills today. One occupant of the car was killed. Sheriff Ruben Lyons called for the National Guard to quell the disorder.

BUFFALO, June 18--Thomas A. Murray, president of the State Federation of Labor and a friend of the Dewey Administration, attacked the Republican state leadership today for "anti-labor" legislation passed by the last session of the Legislature.
Sealed orders were distributed last night to sixty young men and women, their average age 21, who have gladly accepted the chance to start their careers on salaries of $22 a week.
BIBLIOMANIA, according to the Oxford English Dictionary, is "a rage for collecting and possessing books."

LONDON, June 18--The AngloIranian Oil Company, with the backing of the British Government, will offer Iran 10,000,000 tomorrow as a down payment against future royalties, authoritative informants revealed tonight.
The Urban League of Greater New York reported yesterday it had raised its spring goal of $300,000 to support its program for equal economic opportunity for Negroes.
Summer play togs and party frocks for the small child or young teen are both pretty and practical. An excellent selection of these new fashions for youngsters are now available in stores.

Man's unrelenting fight against the sea--at least that phase of it that turns complexions various shades of green--is being renewed by our armed forces and extended into the air, according to a report, of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.

CHICAGO, June 18--Trade in grain futures was decidedly listless today, with little feature. In wheat the failure of export buying to materialize checked buying, but did not cause any great amount of liquidation.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP)--Armour Co. today reported net income of $2,747,146 for the three months ended April 28, the second quarter of the company's fiscal year. In the like 1950 months net income totaled $3,813,371.
DETROIT, June 18--The Detroit transit strike ended tonight as bus and street car operators voted to return to work without a settlement of their demand for a wage increase of 8 cents an hour.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 19--United Nations troops beat off Communist counter-attacks yesterday in Korea's central triangle as the enemy reinforced and dug in for a stand on his strengthen ing defense lines in the west and center.

United Nations combat patrols continued to push forward into enemy territory in Korea yesterday. In the western and west-central sectors enemy screening forces strongly resisted the advance of friendly patrols with small-arms and automatic-weapons fire.

WASHINGTON, June 18--Jonathan Daniels, North Carolina's Democratic National Committeeman, called on President Truman today and told White House reporters he believed Mr. Truman would seek re-election in 1952.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 18 --Cosimo Tiso and Joe Feinberg of Vernon Hills teamed perfectly today to win the weekly proamateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association with a 7 under par 32, 32--64 over the Hampshire Country Club course.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington of Palm Beach, Fla., and Buckmeadow, Upper St. Regis, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeleine D., to Lewis C. Murdock of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Uriel Atwood Murdock.

Awards and diplomas were presented yesterday to 137 men, women and children graduates of the Institute of Crippled and Disabled at 400 First Avenue. Bruce Barton, president of the institute, made the presentations, with 500 persons attending the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 18--V. Henry Rothschild 2d, New York attorney and finance specialist, was named today as chief legal counsel of the Salary Stabilization Division.

Cheryl Crawford's forthcoming production, "Paint Your Wagon," the musical by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, is assuming form. A New York opening date has been registered with the League of New York Theatres and out-of-town booking arrangements have been concluded.
The three-coast maritime work stoppage that threatens to immobilize most American-flag shipping gained momentum yesterday, with no indication of an early settlement.

The fifteen-story building at 845 West End Avenue, containing ninety-one apartments, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to the Nostra Realty Corporation, represented by Steven Garry, vice president.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-- The Government today approved its first big batch of defense power plant expansion projects for rapid cost write-offs under the tax laws.
The United States Air Force, working jointly with the Royal Canadian Air Force, will conduct air defense exercises this week-end throughout most of the country.

Dr. William J. Fordrung of Hunter College has been suspended on a charge of taking a "sensational and unwholesome" approach in his teaching of sex hygiene, the Board of Higher Education announced last night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP)-- Miss Louise Suggs forged the best round of golf of her Career--a scorching 68--over the Whitemarsh Country Club course today to win medalist honors in the Women's Western Open tournament.

A special detail of seventy traffic policemen swept the Garment Center free of big trucks yesterday, starting rigid enforcement of the amended regulation that bans oversize vans during most of the daytime business hours.

THERE was groaning and moaning all over the National League last week when the power-laden Brooklyn Dodgers pried the power-hitting Andy Pafko loose from the Chicago Cubs. The Brooks need help about as much as Custer needed another Indian.
MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP)-- Harry Matthews of Seattle, top light-heavyweight contender, battered Freddie Beshore and opened enough cuts tonight to win a technical knockout.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)-- The State Department expressed hope today that the outcome of the French national election would mean a stable Government for France.
WASHINGTON, June 18--Dr. Ruell Sloan, pathologist and curator of the Army Medical Museum, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. His age was 42.

CHICAGO, June 18 (UP)--Bob Borkowski's single down the right field line with two out in the ninth inning scored Bruce Edwards from second base to give the Cubs a 5-to-4 victory over the Braves today before 6,546 fans in Wrigley Field.

PARIS, June 18--Perhaps the only surprise of the French elections was that they produced no surprises. The tricky electoral law, designed to favor the center against the extremes of Right and Left, worked.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 18-- Israel's Kibbutz movement, the backbone of the pre-Israel Jewish community in Palestine, is undergoing a period of great uncertainty. A number of crises have left the movement's future in question.

The Garment Salesmen's Guild dress market showing in the New Yorker Hotel has been visited by close to 1,000 buyers in its first two days of a five-day exhibit.

The fishing boat Jack sank about fifteen minutes after hitting what was believed to be a lobster pot buoy in Gardiners Bay, Long lsland Sound, the captain of the boat said yesterday at a Coast Guard board of inquiry into the disaster that took eleven lives on June 10.

WASHINGTON, June 18--The Army announced today that it planned to release by the end of the year more than 100,000 enlisted Reservists who had been called to active duty against their wishes on an individual basis.
Sybil Shearer came on from Chicago last night for her annual dance recital, this time at the Cort Theatre. It was a sad occasion.
LONDON, June 18 (UP)--Twelve Americans won their opening singles matches today in the London lawn tennis championships-- the final tune-up for Wimbledon without loss of a set.
Plans were filed yesterday for a twelve-story "international center" to be erected by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace opposite the United Nations headquarters at a cost of $2,600,000.
As a New York County grand jury handed up a grand larceny indictment against a missing 51year-old jeweler, the police announced yesterday that he had been taken into custody in Buenos Aires.

OMAHA, June 18--Proponents of the St. Lawrence Seaway sought today to weld the Great Lakes and Missouri River Valley states into a powerful bloc in support of the multi-million-dollar project as vital to national defense and to the economic development of "inland America."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 18-- Harvard advanced to seventh place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League standing by trouncing Yale, 13--8, today before a crowd of 4,500, made up for the most part of alumni attending class reunions.

From India comes news of the formation of a new political party in opposition to the Congress party of Prime Minister Nehru, which has ruled the country since taking over from the British nearly four years ago.

CHICAGO, June 18--Encouragement to home furnishers who would rather mix the periods of their furniture than match them was the chief style note at the semi-annual Wholesale Home Furnishings Market, which opened here today.

With the appointment of a new third deputy commissioner for his department, Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan took another step in his drastic reorganization, begun last January, of the divisions of fire prevention and combustibles.

The oil issues provided leadership yesterday for the stock market but failed to impart strength to the rest of the list. Except for the petroleums, other issues drifted to lower levels throughout the greater part of the session.
WASHINGTON, June 18--The Office of Price Stabilization announced today it was changing "pricing rule 4" for retailers to prevent what it called "exceptionally severe squeezes."
The ferocity with which teenage hoodlums have terrorized Central Park with muggings netting a few dollars has suggested a tie-up with narcotics addiction, according...
The proposed two-for-one stock split of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was approved by holders of a majority of 1,130,124 shares outstanding, Robert E. Gross, president, announced yesterday.

Aspirin tablets at a price reduction of more than 93 per cent and men's lightweight suits marked down 40 to 55 per cent from manufacturers' "fixed" prices were the fastest-selling items yesterday in the principal department stores taking part in the city's price war.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 18-- Sid Gilison of the home club, a 6stroke handicap player, shared two parts of a triple deadlock for top honors teamed with the Stuhler brothers, Arthur and Bob, in...
It is good news that the city and Yeshiva University have united their plans to construct a vast hospital and medical center in the Bronx.
A revolutionary power transmission drive was announced here yesterday by R.J. Howison, vice president of the Morse Chain Company division of Borg-Warner Corporation.

Economists of New York University and of Cornell University who addressed the Eastern Federation of Feed Merchants at the Commodore Hotel yesterday said they saw few pitfalls ahead for the nation's economy.

WASHINGTON, June 18--A majority of the Republican members of the House of Representatives indicated today that they would refuse to vote for the new tax bill, which is designed to raise $7,233,000,000 of additional revenue annually.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 18--The first choral program of the 1951 Holland Festival in the Bachzaal here tonight was one to be proud of.

Rudolph Halley, whose work as chief counsel to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee made him widely known as a television personality, got into a debate yesterday on the propriety of television cameras in the courtroom and at Congressional hearings.
The terrain at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, where a Marine Corps "boot camp" has just been added, is not radically unlike that of Parris Island, S.C. But in certain...

GENEVA, June 18--For the first time since it undertook to allocate coal among the European importing countries as an aid in relieving shortages, the coal committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe has failed to reach any agreement on a program for the next quarter.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19-- The Harvard Crimson, undergraduate daily, said in a copyrighted supplement to today's edition that at least thirty-five incidents involving academic freedom had taken place on American college campuses and in American school systems in the last year.

Jerry J. Kelley, classed with Frank Erickson as a "top-flight bookmaker," was sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to a twoyear penitentiary term and fined $9,000 with an alternative of serving 540 additional days.

ST. LOUIS, June 19--Going from one extreme to another, the Giants, who had to play through twelve innings to beat the Cardinals last night, shivered through only eight frames for a 2-1 victory tonight at Sportsman's Park. Rain, which had threatened from the start, finally deluged the field just before the start of the ninth, clinching Larry Jansen's eighth triumph of the year.

The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that, effective July 1, it would increase its television time rates by as much as 30 per cent on larger stations, with lesser increases or none at all on smaller television outlets. Edward D. Madden, vice president ...

WASHINGTON, June 19--Consumer buying and new orders placed by business in May were appreciably below the peak rate of the first quarter of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today in its monthly survey of current business.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The Wage Stabilization Board approved productivity increases of four cents an hour for a large number of white-collar salaried employes today. A productivity increase is one given for a rise in plant output.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, second largest insurance concern in the world, announced yesterday that it is entering the "catastrophe" medical expense insurance field.
Inflation has added $21,000,000,000 to consumers' living costs since January, 1950, Eric Johnston, administrator of the Economic Stabilisation Agency, said last night.
ALBANY, June 19 (AP)--At least two upstate public schools intend to overlook a state ban and hold essentially religious baccalaureate services in school auditoriums.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP)-- The big three of women's golf-- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias, Patty Berg and Louise Suggs-- scored smashing victories today to gain the second round of the women's Western open tournament.
LONDON, June 19--Nearly all markets slumped on the Stock Exchange here today. A continuous fall was halted only in places during the last hour.
Ralph L. Blaike, Carl W. Gram Jr. Murray Martin, in 1192 Park Ave: Miss Millie Rothschild, in 600 W 111th St; Mrs. Mabel E. Pace, in 47 E 87th St--Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, June 19--In a new burst of economy, the Senate voted 37 to 36 today to cut almost $300,000 from President Truman's staff, travel and official entertainment budgets for the fiscal year to start July 1. Then it reduced by $50,000 the $225,000 that Mr. Truman had requested only this morning to meet increased costs of completing the renovation of the White House.

Tall Andre Prost, long an importer of delicacies, especially odd honeys from many parts of the world, came in the other day with a group of new foods from France, Hawaii, Cyprus and the United States zone of Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The House Committee on Un-American Activities opened its investigation into communism in defense-production areas today. The group found its two witnesses to be decidedly uncooperative.

The testimony of a banker before the Federal Communications Commission ten years ago has been distorted by the Department of Justice's use of excerpts from it to support its anti-trust suit against certain investment banking houses, Judge Harold R. Medina said in Federal Court here yesterday.

LONDON, June 19 (AP)--Herbie Flam paced a three-man American contingent into the third round of the London tennis championships today, while Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont, the United States champion, led a parade of five Americans in the women's division. Four other Americans were eliminated in this prep tournament for the all--England championships starting next Monday at Wimbledon.
The Subway Circuit, which has presented summer stage attractions in the New York area for the last thirteen years, will cease operations on July 1 as the result of a management-union dispute.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 19 (Reuters)--Czechoslovakia has informed the United States Embassy here that William N. Oatis, Prague correspondent of the Associated Press. now in custody, will be tried "within a few days."

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP)-- Members of a special Congressional committee who spent ten days touring Europe returned today in general agreement that United States aid programs are paying big dividends and must be continued.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19-- Another of baseball's famous Sister family, Dave, pitched Princeton to the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship today with a five-hit, 6-2 victory over Harvard at Soldiers Field.

EASTBOURNE, England, June 19 (Reuters)--Hamilton Fyfe, dean of British foreign correspondents, author, editor and man of affairs, died here in a nursing home, it was announced today. He was 81 years old.

PARIS, June 19--W. Averell Harriman, President Truman's special foreign affairs assistant, arrived here from Washington by air today for conferences on United States economic and military aid to Europe. He will discuss these matter's with Milton Katz, European Marshall Plan chief; ...
The stock market presented a highly confusing picture yesterday. The course of prices was never clear. The list eased, then firmed and closed mixed, but the emphasis was on the lower side.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- Matt S. Szymczak of Chicago may leave the seven-man Federal Reserve Board, of which he is senior member.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 19-- President Getulio Vargas has won two political victories in Congress despite the fact that his Brazilian Labor party has a small representation in that body.

TRENTON, June 19--Minimum retail price fixing for cigarettes appeared to be at an end in New Jersey today with Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll saying he did not "look with favor" on re-enactment of court-voided control.

CINCINNATI, Wednesday, June 20--The high-flying Dodgers all but had the jolly wits scared out of them early this morning as the Reds, on the verge of going down to a 5-0 shut-out before Don Newcombe, suddenly staged a ninthinning uprising.
WASHINGTON, June 19--The House Rules Committee cleared the $7,233,000,000 tax-increase bill today for consideration under a procedure barring amendments not sponsored by the Ways and Means Committee.

Mary Hagenah, trim and unwearied at 85 years, agreed with Bronx County Court Judge James M. Barrett yesterday that maybe it would be better if she spent some time at the State Prison for Women in Bedford Hills.

The 1951 Art and Industry Award of the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industries was presented last night to Robert L. Huffines Jr., president of Burlington Mills Corporation, for his "distinguished services" to the fashion industries.

A vacant plot 90 by 170 feet on the south side of Woolsey Avenue, 345 feet east of Westfield Place, in Glen Cove, L.I., has been purchased by M. Alvin Rose from Sandor Bernstein. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Crowds hunting for bargains in New York's department stores were smaller yesterday, indicating that the first phase of the price war torched off by a Supreme Court decision easing state fair trade laws was about over.

WASHINGTON, June 19--President Truman signed today the bill to extend selective service until July 1, 1955, lower the draft age to 18 and set up a system of universal military training for all young men for the first time in the nation's history. The universal training feature will go into effect at some unspecified time in the future.
Two more indictments were filed yesterday in General Sessions in connection with the recent college basketball scandal.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19-- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Indian Ambassador, thanked Americans for an emergency grain shipment to her famine-ridden country today as the last of 9,300 tons of wheat were being loaded in this port.

Adjustments have started in what is expected to be a general revision of prices of durable goods. This was disclosed in the industrial supply and equipment trade here yesterday. Changes were about equally divided between increases and decreases. Items offered included some portable electric tools, some bench tools, shop supplies, storage bins, fabricated metal products and other lines.

Miss Delia West Marble, who for many years was a leader in Westchester County civic affairs, died on Sunday in Troy, N.Y., at the age of 83, after a long illness. She had made her home in Germantown, N.Y., for the last ten years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 19-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has announced the acquisition of two new stories for the screen today--"The Millionth Man," by Francis Malm, and "The General Came Home," by Marjorie Holmes.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (UP)-- Willie Jones smashed two home runs tonight, one with the bases loaded to page the Phillies to a fifteen-hit, 9 to 2, victory over the Pirates as Russ Meyer annexed a six-hit triumph, his fifth of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 19--A special Senate subcommittee was urged today to adopt a set of "Ten Commandments for Congressmen" as one means of combating the "greatest problem" of public cynicism toward politics.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 19 (AP)--Louisiana's House of Representatives killed tonight by a vote of 60 to 20 a resolution calling for a legislative investigation of crime and law enforcement in the state.

KANSAS CITY, June 19--St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Cyra Louise Duff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Dunlap Duff, to Frederic Rockwell Gladstone Sanborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rockwell Sanborn of Brooklyn Heights, ...

The welcome that Americans will always gladly extend to distinguished visitors should be especially warm for President Galo Plaza of Ecuador. He is due in Washington today as the state guest of President Truman, but we will have a chance to see him and greet him on Sunday in his native city

GENEVA, June 19--The sequence of events beginning with the price war in New York City department stores and continuing with a nation-wide revival of pricecutting competition has had two important economic repercussions in Europe, both good. This, at least, is the opinion of European financial experts in a very good position to watch Europe's struggle with inflation.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 19--An appeal for the formation of a new Zionist party in America was made today by Rabbi Max D. Davidson, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America at the second day's session of the group's fifty-first annual convention.
LONDON, June 19--Sir George Clerk, British Ambassador in Paris from 1934 until his retirement in, 1937, died yesterday. His age was 76.

The lately organized circulating exhibition of the Museum of Modern Art, entitled "Modern Relief" goes on view today in the Auditorium Gallery of the museum. It will eventually be shown in museums and schools throughout the country. It was assembled by Jane Sabersky.

For six hours and ten minutes the Yankees and the White Sox, fought it out in a double-header at the Stadium yesterday before the largest daytime crowd to see a ball game in the Bronx this year. When their twin bill ended in the gathering dusk, the teams were exactly where they had started the afternoon in relation to the American League leadership.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 19--New York State Presbyterians will be asked this week to approve a report that sees "cause for alarm" in the implications of a countrywide pro-MacArthur demonstration.

Lincoln, Neb., sold yesterday $6,000,000 of new school building bonds due July 1, 1954 to 1971 to a banking group headed by Bankers Trust Company at a bid of 100.059 for 1 s, 2s and 3s, at an interest cost of 1.805 per cent.

PARIS, June 19--Premier Henri Queuille at tomorrow's meeting of his Cabinet, which is considered now resigned, will consult with its members over the steps to be taken between now and the convening of a new National Assembly on July 5 to prepare the way for formation of the next coalition Ministry.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan dismissed today a department official whom he accused of accepting "favors" from a private concern doing business with the Government.
Holding its twentieth commencement exercises yesterday, Yeshiva University conferred 128 degrees and diplomas, the largest number in its history, and bestowed four honorary degrees.

Some 300 athletic coaches of the City High Schools gathered last night at the Herald Tribune Auditorium and voted to suspend discussion on whether or not to continue the strike that has prevented scholastic sports for fifteen months.

THE mountain principality of Katpal, lost somewhere in the fastnesses of the Himalayas between India and Tibet, cannot be found on any map. It is the imaginary setting for Gordon McDonell's exotic romance, "The Clocktower."* But Katpal, although it is only a picturesque variation upon an oriental theme, is a microcosm of a whole world in travail.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday. The July contract closed 47 points higher, but new crop months closed 4 to 19 points lower on active months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19-- John Zeleny, chairman of the Yale Department of Physics for twentyfive years and Professor-Emeritus since 1940, died this morning at his home, 44 Cold Spring Street, after a long illness. His age was 79.

A special meeting of stockholders of United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation to remove the present directors and elect a new board is being urged by Charles Green, who says he has a beneficial interest in 57,300 shares of the company's common stock.

A three-day inspection of the city's watershed areas by a party of sixteen high-ranking city, civil defense and military officials will pave the way for determining the defense needs of the municipal water system. The inspection tour will start tomorrow.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 19--The talks between the Iranian Government and the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company broke down tonight and the chances that they might somehow be salvaged appeared highly remote.
Because nurses have displayed little of the widespread public apathy toward civil defense, New York soon will have nearly 7,000 of them with basic training in "atomic nursing."

The United States Rubber Company announced here yesterday its first production of seven standard varieties of improved synthetic "cold rubber" latex, now available to other manufacturers of rubber goods. The products are being manufactured at the Naugatuck, Conn., chemical division of the company, according to John P. Coe, vice president and generaal manager of the division.
Thomas C. Gibney, a veteran immigration officer, has been appointed chief of the inspection and travel control section of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the Port of New York.

The Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, had a consolidated net income of $14,675,367 for the twelve months ended with last May, compared with $13,305,293 for the previous year's period.

BERLIN, June 19--The commandants of the three Western sectors of Berlin today authorized resumption of negotiations for an interzone trade agreement under circumstances indicating they were as uninformed as German officials as to whether the Soviet intended to assure free transit of West Berlin exports.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19 --Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, asserted here today that organized religion must support the "forces of law, order and freedom" against the aggression of Soviet Russia, which "hasn't the right to impose its domination or its social order" on other nations.
Plans for the construction of a large new terminal for over-theroad trailer trucks serving the garment area were announced yesterday by Eli Bensky, vice president of the Gilbert Carrier Corporation.

The mass deportations of former middle-class Hungarians from Budapest and other cities in recent weeks is only the latest manifestation of a totalitarian technique that has become familiar in the past decade. The Communist rulers of Eastern Europe are driving their "class enemies" out of ...

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19-- Joseph H. Stamler of Newark, counsel for the New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association, predicted today that attempts would be made to repeal New Jersey's Fair Trade Law, under which injunctions have been granted against price-cutting stores.

Coming through with a performance that almost broke the track record, the Al-Jo Stable's Gray Matter won the Great Neck Classified Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The field of six ran a distance of a mile and a furlong and Gray Matter, ridden by Teddy Atkinson, covered the ground in 1:48 1/5 in beating La Montagne's Steel Blue by two lengths.

Joseph H. Cohen Sons, Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of men's clothing, announced yesterday price reductions that would permit retailers to sell fall suits and topcoats $2 to $5 less than originally planned. The move according to Wilfred P. Cohen, an officer of the company, affects millions of dollars of clothing orders already booked and should stimulate retail sales of clothing that have been lagging.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- Attorneys plan to make final arguments Friday morning on the El Paso Natural Gas Company's attempt to force issuance of Federal permits needed to complete its $40,000,000 pipeline in Arizona.

Less than 15 per cent of sales volume and profit of the Allied Stores Corporation is obtained in the New York area, B. Earl Puckett, chairman of the board, told shareholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.
ALBANY, June 19--A claim of the New York Central Railroad to a tax rebate of more than $12,000,000 from the City of New York was disallowed today by Referee James J. McGuiness.
BUFFALO, June 19--Delegates to the convention of the State Federation of Labor demanded today a complete break between their organization and Governor Dewey.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP)--Billy Southworth, one of the National League's most successful managers, has resigned from the Braves, it was announced today. His request to be relieved of a five-year contract that runs through 1952 was granted by President Lou Perini.

The City Council formally set the 1951-52 basic real estate tax rate at $3.08 for each $100 of assessed valuation yesterday, continuing the current highest rate in the city's history and confirming estimates made by Controller Lazarus Joseph.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 (AP) --The clergy of the Southern Baptist ministry was told today the church would not compromise its doctrines by joining ecclesiastical associations.

Medals, honoring the most outstanding of 457 members of the city Fire Department who were commended for bravery last year, year, were bestowed yesterday at were bestowed yesterday noon at Mayor Impellitteri and Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan conducted the ceremonies, while 1,500 persons, including the families of four men who died on duty in the year, looked on.

CHICAGO, June 19--Shortages of raw materials should have no immediate effect on home furnishings, with the exception of floor coverings, a group of suppliers said here today. The abundance of various kinds of merchandise being offered buyers at the semi-annual home furnishings markets here gave color to this prediction.
The authority of the Board of Education to order teachers to resume extracurricular activsties in the schools was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip M. Kleinfeld in Brooklyn.

SOME new exotics are scheduled to enter the game-bird list of this country if plans of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service mature, and another year should see the Oriental sand grouse and francolin introduced in several southwestern states.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19--Britain announced today that all shipments of strategic goods to and from her colonies and dependencies--including Hong Kong and Malaya--would be subject to strict control, to make sure that no war materials got through to Communist China or North Korea.

PARIS, June 19--The twelve Atlantic alliance nations signed today an agreement establishing the legal rights and duties of servicemen when transferred to duty in the territory of a member nation other than their own.

Dr. William J. Fordrung of Hunter College, who was suspended last Friday for taking a "sensational and unwholesome" approach in his teaching of sex hygiene, charged yesterday that he was being victimized by an "academic Gestapo" for teaching "objective morality."
CAPETOWN, South Africa, June 19 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan said today he was "convinced" that South Africa ultimately would become a republic.
BOSTON, June 19 (AP)--Chuck Stobbs gave up only four hits tonight as he pitched the Red Sox to a 9-2 triumph over the Indians.
New issues of public utility bonds amounting to $43,200,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings are as follows:

Establishment of a forty-hour week for 42,000 municipal transit workers on July 1 was considered a virtual impossibility yesterday after Mayor Impellitteri's special transit committee had considered the practicality of immediate action on the shorter work week at an executive session in the Biltmore Hotel.

The political map and mind of France were pretty clearly outlined in the elections. The French coined the saying: "The more it changes the more it is the same thing," and Sunday's vote is proof that the people, despite their complaints about the weakness and unrepresentative character of the ...

WASHINGTON, June 19--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved today an eight-month extension of price, wage and rent controls, but wrote into the bill even more stringent limitations on rollbacks than had been put into the House bill.

Agreement is sadly lacking in the northern world regarding the time of summer's beginning and of its halfway stage. In general, popular almanacs nowadays start the season off with stop-watch precision on the instant of the summer solstice--the sun stand-- ...

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP)-- The Pan American World Airways charged at a hearing today before the Civil Aeronautics Board that W.R. Grace Co. was trying to dominate transportation between points in the Eastern United States and along the west coast of South America.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- Great Lakes ship and dock operators today opposed legislation to give the Labor Department power to enforce safety rules and standards for longshoremen and harbor workers.

A general increase of 10 per cent in bus passenger travel since the opening of the Port of New York Authority bus terminal at Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street was reported yesterday by Robert S. Curtiss, director of the Department of Concessions and Revenues for that organization.

H.J. Baker Brothers, a 100year-old firm dealing in farm fertilizers and feed, has leased the nineteenth floor in the Sinclair Oil Building at 600 Fifth Avenue, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers, who negotiated the lease with Leonard J. Beck, Inc.,

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 19 (AP)--Hungary disclosed today that Archbishop Joseph Grosz would be called to trial Friday on charges that he took over from the imprisoned Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty the leadership of a group aimed at overthrowing the Communist government.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today, for the first time, that an employer is not obligated to bargain, during the life of a contract, over any issue which had been advanced by the union as part of the negotiations leading up to the agreement.
Emil Weigl has been appointed assistant manager of the Hallmark Institute, Inc., a research institute of the plastic industry. He will be in charge of sales and organization.

The unusual study made of public school teachers' pay and hours in White Plains, N.Y., lays to rest some fallacies and raises some questions to which, probably, there will never be an agreed answer. The study was ordered by the Board of Education in this Westchester community and was made by ...

Net income of the Pettibone Mulliken Corporation for the year ended March 31, 1951, amounted to $1,297,698, equal to $11.51 a common share, according to the report released yesterday. This compares with a net income of $515,035 or $4.52 a share for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1950. The corporation manufactures railroad track equipment.

Summoned as a witness before a New York County grand jury investigating tax assessment irregularities, Max Sloman, president of Bing Bing, Inc., realty concern, refused yesterday to sign a waiver of immunity, it was learned at the Criminal Courts Building.

Two more fuel oil equipment installers testified in General Sessions Court yesterday that they had made payments to inspectors in the fuel oil section of the Fire Department under a standard schedule of rates allegedly set up as part of a $500,000-a-year shakedown in their field.

CHICAGO, June 19--Buying and attendance on the second day of the Summer Home Furnishings Market in the Merchandise Marts here continued slow. Furniture manufacturers are expected to make normal market competitive price reductions tomorrow.

CHARLES DILLON STENGEL was sprawled indolently on the Yankee bench before yes yerday's double-header with the leading White Sox. He roused himself, peered intently across the field and then slapped his knee as if he'd just discovered something.

WASHINGTON, June 19--The Department of Defense disclosed tonight that it had started deliv-, eries of military equipment to Yugoslavia. Defense Department funds not specifically appropriated for this purpose had been used, a spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)-- The Senate confirmed late today nominations of sixteen Army officers to general rank and twentysix naval officers to the rank of rear admiral.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP)-- Two Cleveland operators were threatened with contempt prosecution today when they balked at questions of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee about gambling activities in Ohio and northern Kentucky.

Governor Dewey, concerned over a lag in recruiting for volunteer civil-defense work, will seek to dissipate apathy with a fifteen-minute broadcast tonight that will be carried over 137 network and independent stations, starting at 17:30 P.M.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19--The Central Committee of Yugoslav trade unions has taken a decision to transform member unions from mere instruments of the state into organizations that will defend the interests of the working class within the limits permitted by the nature of a socialist society.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP)-- The Defense Department said today it was doing its best to identify missing United States servicemen who might be prisoners of war in Korea and to help their families get in touch with them.

In continuing raids on waterfront areas and rooming houses in New York City and in Newark, N.J. Immigration officers took into custody 175 aliens Monday night and yesterday, it was announced by Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director.

The five-story apartment house for ten families on lot, 20 by 100 feet at 43 East Sixty-seventh Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, has been sold by Alfred Baruch to Orville T. Boley, president of the Lutley Corporation, for investment.

The first pilot strike on any major airline of the nation in more than two and a half years grounded every plane on the coast-to-coast system of United Air Lines yesterday. The line schedules 650 flights a day, handling 8,000 passengers.
A group of ten business men-- all attorneys except one--has set up the Fair Television Practices Committee to rally public opposition to all forms of box-office television.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., June 19-- Blue delphinium and white lilies formed a floral background here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Snows for the marriage of Miss Tania Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Russell of Brook Crossing, Woodstock, to J. Daniel
ROME, June 19--Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, was received this morning with all the honors due to a chief of state in an official audience by ...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 19--Lloyd Ribner and Jerry Cole of Fenway combined to win the British Victory amateur best-ball golf tournament over the Metropolis Country Club course today with a 6 under par 33, 32--65.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 18-- Clinging to her slight lead gained on Sunday night when the fleet of thirty-two yachts left Newport, R.I., on the race to here, John Nicholas Brown's black-hulled yawl Bolero, scratch craft with handicaps reckoned, had passed Winter Quarter lightship, off Chincotogue Beach, late today.

Arguments for and against year-round Saturday closings have been sent members of the New York Stock Exchange in preparation for the impending referendum. Richard M. Crooks, chairman of the board, asked members if they wanted to set trading hours "by the comparatively inflexible
EUGENE, Ore., June 19 (AP)-- Southern California's Trojans led the Pacific Coast Conference to its second straight track victory over the Big Ten tonight, 77 to 54 .

Interesting accessories for a desk can provide a pleasant atmosphere in which to write as well as render a practical service. In the stores today many such items may be found, among them a new version of the student lamp, accessories designed by a member of a noted American poet's family and even a holder in sterling silver for scotch tape.

Most commodities remained weak yesterday but sugar climbed into new high ground as refiners generally followed National Sugar Refining Company's lead in raising the refined price from 8.50 to 8.75 cents a pound.
Furs manipulated as deftly and becomingly as fashions in fabrics held the attention of the press yesterday at the advance fall showing of the Bernham-Stein Furs in its salon at 660 Fifth Avenue.
A proposal for mandatory sentencing of convicted sellers of narcotics and life imprisonment for third offenses was made yesterday by Joseph T. Sharkey, acting president of the City Council.

For some time now major developments in Western Europe have been marking time pending the outcome of the French elections, which had become necessary not only for legal reasons but also to test the prevailing French sentiment and to provide a new basis for the government of one of the key ...

From every conceivable facet, ticket problems have been aired and assayed recently in the hope of harmonizing conflicting elements in an industry constantly plagued by those controversies. United Nations combat patrols continued to probe enemy positions along the Korean front yesterday. ROBERT TYRE JONES is a golfing saint, reverently pictured as though he were sprouting wings and floating angelically over heavenly fairways. But Robert Trent Jones is grumpily visualized as having cloven hooves, a pitchfork and other satanic paraphernalia. Robert Tyre Jones is the immortal Bobby Jones of Grand Slam fame. Robert Trent Jones is a golfing architect who creates infernally clever divot-digging hells.

In its first change of ownership in about 75 years, the paint manufacturing plant at 804 East 141st Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Payson Paint Company to the Radar Paint Company.

Two Air Force enlisted men, wearing leather straps on their wrists and ankles, escaped from Mitchel Air Force Base, L. I, in a stolen ambulance yesterday afternoon soon after being removed from a transport plane to be taken to the Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Queens, for psychiatric observation.

BERLIN, June 24-Amid furious shouts from spectators as well as a shower of soft drink bottles and stones, Sugar Ray Robinson, world middleweight champion, was rushed from the ring this afternoon by German police after having been disqualified supposedly for kidney punches against his German opponent, Gerhard Hecht.

Total sales of credit jewelry chain stores were 10 per cent higher in the first four months of this year than for the corresponding months of last year and singleunit operators' sales were about 13 per cent higher. This was reported yesterday by William Wagner, executive secretary of the National Association of Credit Jewelers.
Evaluating the strengths and weaknesses of the Western Democracies, the A.B.C. radio network will present tonight from 9 to 10 o'clock its ninth major documentary, "The Ramparts We Watch."

With his third home run of the campaign, Gene Woodling yesterday gave the Yankees a 5-3 victory over the Indians before 49,000 onlookers at the Stadium for a sweep of the three-game series. As a result, the second-place Bombers cut the White Sox American League lead to one game.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 24--The country's pulpwood and paper industry, spurted by demands of the national defense program, is now moving into the South with new construction and expansion plans that will cost more than $100,000,000 within the next few years.

CANAAN, N.Y., June 24--Institutions for juvenile delinquents must do more than provide custody and care--they must try to change the behavior of children by providing individual treatment directed at "casual factors."

WASHINGTON, June 24-Hope for even a watered-down extension of price-wage control authority by June 30 all but vanished today as it became known that the Senate and House would not get down to real work on the legislation before Wednesday.

This morning, June 25, is the anniversary of the Communist invasion of the Republic of Korea. The anniversary has been made more than usually significant by a purported peace feeler from the Soviet Union.
The Army will issue invitations today for bids on a wool-nylon blended fabric designed to replace a heavier-weight wool serge used in uniforms for many years.

Secretary General Lie of the United Nations, in a telephone message from Oslo yesterday, urged immediate negotiations for a cease-fire in Korea. Mr. Lie said political questions could be "appropriately discussed in the competent organs of the United Nations" after a truce.'[1:8.]

Riggs, 6--3, 4--6, 6--2, 6--3.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 27-- The marriage of Miss Nancy Josephine Veltre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Veltre of Westfield, to Robert Wakefield Dickson, son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Dickson of New York, took place here this afternoon in the home of the bride's parents.

Mrs. Carrie Warner and her "boys" of Sigma Alpha Mu held a reunion last night after a separation of twenty-nine years. Now 91 years old, the one-time cook and housemother in a fraternity house at Cornell University greeted them with an all-embracing welcomes "How nice to meet my boys again!"

ROME, June 28 (UP)--The death of Admiral Count Luigi Rizzo, Italian naval hero of the first World War, was announced today. He was the only Italian ever to receive two gold medals, greatest military honor in Italy. His age was 64.

BERLIN, June 28--Eastern and Western German delegations quietly resumed today negotiations for a new interzone trade pact, after their talks had collapsed last Monday with every appearance of finality.

Mrs. Sara Baum Epstein, a leader in Zionist and many other activities and the widow of Edward Epstein, a New York merchant, died on Wednesday night in her home, the Bolivar Hotel, after an illness of several months. Her age was 84.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 28-- America's public school teachers are resigning from the profession in "alarming" numbers. More than 125,000 will leave this year--about twice the annual rate in pre-World War II years, with 1940 the standard year.
WASHINGTON, June 28--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended June 23 totaled 832,942 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
SINGAPORE, June 28--Although Singapore continues to enjoy a business boom the city presents a gloomy physical and social picture.

HONG KONG, June 28--The Chinese Communist party is in the process of change from its overwhelmingly peasant origin membership, according to an article by Peng Chen, member of the party's Politburo and Mayor of Peiping. The article was written to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the Chinese party on July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UP)-- A Federal Court jury today convicted Joseph P. Kamp of contempt of Congress just seven minutes after getting his case.
WASHINGTON, June 28--The National Labor Relations Board upheld today an employer who discharged nine employes because they circulated handbills attacking the quality of the employer's product.

RYE, N.Y., June 28--The fortyseventh United States Seniors' Golf Association tournament continued at the Apawamis Club today as the third section of the record field of 392 teed off. Meanwhile, the second group completed two days of activity at the near-by Blind Brook Club in Port Chester.

For week-end and Fourth of July fare shoppers will find for picnic hampers an abundance of fresh fruits and a wide variety of vegetables. Welcome, too, is the news from the City Department of Markets that prices are down on sixteen items from 1 to 10 cents.

News that Brazil would attempt a new valorization program for coffee dominated trading in that commodity on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Dealings were heavy at 69,750 bags and prices rose 80 to 107 points.

TURIN, Italy, July 1 (AP)--Ray (Sugar) Robinson, world middleweight champion, stopped Cyril Delannoit of Belgium in 2:53 of the third round of a scheduled tenround non-title fight today.

Roswell Magill, chairman of the Committee on Federal Tax Policy, expressed--the opinion last week that the revenue bill just passed by the House was "probably the most badly devised tax measure" in the country's history. Mr. Magill, who was Under Secretary of the Treasury in 1937-38, urged that the Senate committee make a completely fresh start in the writing of tax legislation.
The Battle of the Panchos on the Fourth of July will decide the national professional tennis champion for 1951.
LONDON, July 1--Britain's Defence Minister, Emanuel Shinwell, expressed the hope today that the proposed cease-fire in Korea might be the prelude for a diplomatic conference of the Great Powers.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)--The American League today announced its complete player roster for the all-star game in Detroit, July 10.

PITTSBURGH, July 1--Despite hot weather, vacations and a looming crisis in scrap the steel industry was able last week to maintain its operating rate at 103 per cent of capacity, down only half a point from the week before. If there should be any drop in the rate in the weeks to come it was believed here that such a reduction would not be of significant proportions.

Immediate modernization of the Fire Department training system including its Fire College was recommended yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey. In a report to Mayor Impellitteri the committee urged ...
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1--United Nations leaders said today they regarded the Communist agreement to begin Korean peace talks as encouraging.

Roman Catholics praying for victims of the "Communist sickle" should not forget to include prayers for their persecutors, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Governor Dewey flew to San Francisco yesterday on the first leg of a 25,000-mile trip to the Far East and Australasia to view at first hand an area he regards as of prime importance to the security of the free world.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (UP)-- Bobby Feller, who had to talk a coach into letting him stay in the game, pitched the third no-hitter of his career--and became the first pitcher in modern times to do so--as the Indians beat the Tigers, 2--1, today.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report issued a legislative box score today showing that the drive for reorganization, aimed at greater efficiency and economy in government, had bogged down in the Eighty-second Congress.

The rapid growth of pension plans and profit-sharing programs in recent years has had a stabilizing effect on the labor supply, in that they have been conducive to keeping employes more interested in retaining their jobs so as to enjoy these benefits, a recent survey has shown. PRINCETON, N.J., July 1-- This community, which served briefly as the capital of the United States at the close of the Revolutionary War, observed the 175th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence this afternoon with simple ceremonies at the graves of two signers of the document.

PUSAN, Korea, Monday, July 2 --The announcement that the Chinese and North Korean Communists were willing to negotiate a cease-fire reached this city late last night, after a day in which the temporary South Korean capital was marked by tension but no disorder.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 1--The Holland Festival struck a Gallic note tonight with two French operas--one of them a world premiere--and the first performance of a new ballet.
TOKYO, Monday, July 2--War was still a definite reality yesterday to the fighting men in Korea, where sharp local action continued in all sectors.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP)--A weak pop fly by Billy Johnson dropped for a double behind first base to score Stan Musial from second base and give the Cardinals a 5-4 triumph over the Pirates today in twelve innings. The blooper was Johnson's second hit of the afternoon and it came with two out.

It is not recorded whether the automobile trip planned yesterday by Carmelo Hernandez of 765 Trinity Avenue, the Bronx, involved life, death, a proposal of marriage, a baseball game or a spin into the country.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 1-- The Rev. Dr. Frank M, Kerr, pastor for fifty-seven years of Christ's First Presbyterian Church here, conducted services this morning for the last time. The retirement of the 84-year-old minister became effective yesterday.

PARIS, July 1--With the trial of The Associated Press correspondent, William N. Oatis, Czechoslovakia's Communist authorities are completing a series of propaganda prosecutions intended to discredit Western representatives, institutions and ideas.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP)-- Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman asked all State Governors today to join in the Federal Government's summer fuel buying program designed to avert spot oil and coal shortages next winter.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Berman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis K. Berman of 885 Park Avenue, to Robert R. Slaughter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Slaughter, also of New York, took place yesterday in the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

Two patterns for mothers-to-be are today's suggestion of Patterns of The Times. Both of these styles can be made of cool summer fabrics if they are needed in the next three months, or in a fall wool or rayon for the months that follow.

In response to interest aroused about "high pressure" charity solicitations, Raymond M. Hilliard, executive director of the Welfare Council of New York, issued general rules yesterday to guide the public in making contributions and to help in exposing fake solicitors.

A statement that four-wheel drive power is broadening the market for this country's automotive exports by making motor car operation possible in little-traveled areas was made last week by Marcel F. DeMuller, president of the export subsidiary of WillysOverland Motors, Inc.

Voluntary hospitals should be reimbursed by the city for ward bed care in an amount comparable to the cost in its own institutions, Howard S. Cullman, president of Beekman-Downtown Hospital said yesterday.

The approval last week by the House Armed Services Committee of a bill expanding the Marine Corps and adding its commandant to the Joint Chiefs of Staff represents well-deserved praise for the Marine Corps. But nevertheless, it has some disquieting overtones.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The Truman Administration will set about regrouping its battered forces on Capitol Hill this week in an attempt to get through the House a stronger defense production bill than was approved in the Senate.

An optimistic picture of future trade between Portugal and the United States was presented here yesterday by Dr. Francisco Luis Tavares, chairman of the board of the Portuguese Line. He said that his company recently had purchased two new ships and planned to expand both its United States and European services in the next two weeks.

RICHMOND, Va., July 1--Douglas M. Creech, a 43-year-old business man from Charlotte, N.C., was practically unbeatable today on the James River, winning five of six heats in regular outboard hydroplane events in Richmond's new Red, White and Blue regatta.

TOKYO, Monday, July 2--The Chinese and North Korean Communists accepted late last night the United Nations' proposal for a meeting to discuss a cease-fire in the Korean war, but named conditions differing from those broadcast to their high command by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, leader of the allied armed forces.

The National Maritime Union, C.I.O., has issued a call to its 50,000 members for the union's eighth biennial national convention, which will open here at the Manhattan Center on Oct. 22. Delegates and officials attending the meeting are expected to total nearly 1,000.

A statement that inefficient use of this country's facilities for production of synthetic rubber cost the consuming public an additional $500,000,000 in the year ended on May 1 is made by P.W. Litchfield, chairman of the board of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, in a statement released for publication today.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 1-- About 2,500,000 Finns about the age of 21 go to the polls tomorrow and Tuesday to elect their unicameral Diet of 200 members for the next three years.
PHIL RIZZUTO came bouncing up the dugout steps at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, glanced at the line-up card on the wall and whistled in wonderment.
WASHINGTON, July 1--The cease-fire phase of the Korean peace negotiations has gone better than officials here had hoped.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)-- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, indicated today that he felt the House used a "meat-axe" approach to some extent in voting to increase taxes $7,200,000,000. Senator George is chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee.

PARIS, July 1--One of the deep, underlying causes of the discords and governmental weakness in France will come to the surface at the opening meeting Thursday of the National Assembly with the opening address by the new dean of the Assembly.
PARIS, July 1--Following the moves for a case-fire in Korea, a drop in the price of gold and in hard currencies took place in the Paris market.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., July 1 (AP)--Volunteer workers removed today the bodies of fifty men, women and children killed early yesterday in the crash of a United Air Lines plane.

Mrs. William Rufus Boyd 3d, wife of an adviser to the Government Munitions Board, was found brutally beaten at 8:30 A.M. yesterday in a bedroom of her apartment at 350 East Fifty-seventh Street. High police officials still were investigating last night.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1--Particles of earth from the birthplace of liberty and historic battlefields in each of the thirteen original states were blended ceremonially this afternoon in Independence Square.

One of the most important services of the United States Post Office has been that of acting as a guardian of money in transit by issuing money orders. The system, inaugurated in 1864, has changed little to this day. It is true that the money order system has been effective, if $5,000,000,000 worth of business in one year is any criterion, but it is equally true that the system was in need of some modification.

Debate still continues in this country as to whether freedom of the press is lost when Communists are punished for publicizing the art of violent revolution. In certain other parts of the world, as The Associated Press reported yesterday, no debate is necessary.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)--Ned Garver's two-hit masterpiece gave the Browns a 3-1 victory today after the White Sox had won the opener, 2--1, on Minnie Minoso's eleventh-inning home run. By splitting the double-header, Chicago dropped from the league lead for the first time since May 28.

China does not think in the time terms of the West. There is much of the oriental in the mind and temperament of Stalin, who knows how to bargain and wait to inch back and forth, like the merchants in the Eastern bazaars.

PARIS, July 1--The San Carlo Theatre of Naples began a brief season at the Opera here last night as one of the highlights of "the grand season." The visiting company is presenting two Verdi works--"Joan of Arc" and "The Masked Ball"--in two performances of each. The former was presented last night and the latter tonight.

ABADAN, Iran, July 1--A production cutback of more than 40 per cent was ordered at the Abadan refinery of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company today in a move to postpone a complete shutdown of the giant plant as long as possible.

Against a background of credit restrictions, banks in the last quarter have continued to operate in a "lenders' market" for money. Loan totals, representing this prime commodity in which banks deal, have remained at top levels, at firmer rates, and bank statements to be published this week will show further general improvement in earnings.

The Office of Price stabilization has supplied clarification of a number of provisions in price regulations affecting importers, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., announced yesterday.

ATLANTA, July 1--Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, speaking today before an inter-racial audience of 7,500 persons in this city's Municipal Auditorium, called on the American people to wage a "bold fight" against the "poisons of racial bigotry" if they would successfully lead the free world.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 1--A twin-engined Air Force C-47 transport plane, groping through heavy fog for a landing at Maguire Air Base here, crashed in a pine thicket at 3:30 A.M. today, killing five of the twenty-one persons aboard. The accident occurred a quarter of a mile from the runway the pilot was seeking.
Jean-Pierre Meyer has been appointed manager of the budget sportswear department for Macy's, New York. He succeeds Clayton Zahn, who has resigned.

Those who work so hard for the Beekman-Downtown Hospital, a most necessary institution of its kind in lower Manhattan, are beginning to reach the realization of their dream--a new hospital building adequate to serve the populous area of which it is a part.
The Chinese and the North Korean who signed the message agreeing to a Korean cease-fire conference share an intense devotion to the Communist cause.

BERLIN, July 1--An estimated crowd of 350,000 persons participated today in the reopening of Berlin's popular motor raceway, the Avus, after an interval of nearly fourteen years. Commandants of three Western sectors occupied seats alongside Lord Mayor Reuter for a series of events over a course recently renovated at a cost of 800,000 marks.

The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation made public yesterday its report for 1949-50, listing grants of $8,000,000 to thirty educational and welfare organizations. Since its establishment in 1936 by Alfred P Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, the foundation has laid out $18,000,000 in grants and expenditures.

OAKMONT, Pa., July 1--Despite two stymies that momentarily rattled his composure, Sam Snead defeated Jack Burke Jr., the curly-haired Texan, to gain the semi-final round of the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Oakmont Country Club today.
Weather came to the aid of areas of the nation battling floods and forest fires yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

A slight slackening of activity was noted in the wholesale markets here last week as buyers left town, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, July 1--At a specially convened cabinet meeting in Bonn last Thursday night the West German Government decided to reject absolutely the proposals made by the Swiss Government on April 20.

LONDON, July 1--The financial markets have been plunged into twilight in the last week. Just as twilight confuses vision and objects, the markets have been very confused by the week's international events.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 5-- Two United States diplomats were ordered expelled from Hungary today by the Communist Government.

Twenty million dollars, spread over twelve years and six far-flung areas, doesn't seem like much money in these days. Yet, spent as the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization plans to spend it, this sum can leave its mark on the lives of countless millions of human beings.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5--A complaint was submitted to the United Nations today accusing Hungary of deporting tens of thousands of civilians, mainly Jews, deemed "socially dangerous" by the Communist satellite government.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Republican critics of the Administration's Far East policy, free to remain in that role because our intervention in Korea was not previously submitted for consideration to the minority in Congress, are keeping their eyes closely trained on the armistice discussions at Kaesong ...
CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP)--Two seeded players were out today as competition in both men's and women's singles in the annual TriState tennis tournament advanced to the quarter-finals.
The United States Air Conditioning Corporation has appointed P.C. Bousquet G. Co. and Stolk Bousquet, Caracas, as exclusive representative and distributor of its products in Venezuela.
A tearful Brownie sat among a busload of bustling Girl Scouts waiting to pull out of the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday for four camps operated by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

New borrowing by sales finance companies was the largest single factory in a further expansion of business lending by New York banks last week, bringing the total $14,000,000 higher and marking the fourth successive weekly rise.

WASHINGTON, July 5(AP)--The United States Court of Appeals today upheld a sixty-day suspension of Ralph W. Moore's commodity market trading privileges. He was accused of trying to manipulate the price of lard.

THE holiday that occurred this week gave the fishing fra ternity an extra day for sport. All signs pointed to full use of the midweek respite. Fresh and salt water were out in force with a common objective--to catch fish. The salt water fishermen achieved the objective more readily, as usual.

LONDON, July 5--The stock markets threw off early hesitation today, which was induced by Chancellor of the Exchequer Gaitskell's warning of a widening gap in Britain's foreign trade. By the end of the day most of the losses had been eliminated and the markets closed firm.

Jack Tuero of New Orleans and Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn both had more difficulty than anticipated in winning their quarterfinal matches yesterday in the New York State clay court tennis championship at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.
PARIS, July 5--There are very few chinks in the Iron Curtain, and it is rare that an honest breeze blows through in a westerly direction.

A decrease of more than 3,000 pints in the amount of blood contributed to the Red Cross last month as compared with May was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. C.M. Walson, retired, administrator of the blood program here.

The licensed dog population in this city has taken a decided drop in the last year and appears to be headed for further declines, Sydney H. Coleman, executive secretary of the American Society of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, said yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 (UP)-- A strike of American Federation of Labor service workers spread to ten Minneapolis hospitals today and vital milk and fresh food supplies were cut off when truck drivers refused to cross picket lines.
The Bowery Corps of the Salvation Army, located at 349 on the "Street of Forgotten Men," closed last night after twenty-eight years of dispensing coffee, doughnuts and the Gospel to down-and-outers.

ALBANY, July 5--Delays in obtaining a breakdown of 1950 population data from the Federal Census Bureau appeared today to have blocked any possibility of holding the special legislative session for reapportionment of New York's Congressional districts before the November election.

NEW ORLEANS, July 5 (AP)-- Five towboat crewmen, including the captain, drowned today, apparently trapped in their boat, which overturned in the Mississippi River after crashing with a 10,000-ton tanker, the Morris Hess.

In Korea yesterday United Nations combat patrols received moderate to heavy small arms, mortar and artillery fire in the western sector while along the central and eastern fronts patrols ranging well forward of front lines encountered light resistance from scattered enemy groups.

"Make A Wish" enters its final week at the Winter Garden next Monday night. One of Broadway's costliest musicals, the show will have spanned an engagement of 102 performances. Molnar's comedy. "The Good Fairy," supplied the framework of the plot, freely adapted by Preston Sturges to go with the songs of Hugh Martin.

WASHINGTON, July 5--The Federal Bureau of Investigation called on the public tonight to aid in the capture of eight fugitive Communist leaders who are believed to have gone "underground" to carry on their activities.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, announced today that he would introduce tomorrow a resolution calling for a thorough investigation of lobbying by foreign Governments seeking to influence United States foreign policy.

The Jefferson Building, headquarters of the Brooklyn Democrats for nearly sixty-one years, is to be sold and the district leaders are looking for smaller and move modern quarters with leasing in view.
CHICAGO, July 5--Dr. Ludwig Hektoen, noted pathologist, who had worked on coronary thrombosis and against cancer, died in Michael Reese Hospital tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 5 (AP) --Thirty-nine states and the District of Columbia have tax-paid agencies today for medical care, research and rehabilitation in the fight on alcoholism. The great growth of these agencies has taken place in the last five years.

Eight new short films, to be used in family life and human relations classes for elementary and high school students, were approved last week by the national coordinating council of home economics groups during the annual meeting of the Home Economics Association in Cleveland, Dr. Henrietta Fleck reported yesterday.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (UP)--The University of Pennsylvania's 150-pound crew, the only American entry in the Royal Henley Regatta, easily won its second heat today in the Thames challenge cup competition.

WASHINGTON, July 5--The Salary Stabilization Board issued Regulation No. 1 today incorporating the first ten regulations of the Wage Stabilization Board and setting forth the line of jurisdiction between the two boards.
