The Soviet Union is building air bases on its Siberian Arctic Ocean coast and on its islands north of the coast, Dr. Constantine Krypton, formerly a top Russian economic geographer, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, said today he had tried to resign as chairman of a Senate Elections subcommittee, partly because of delay in issuing a report on the group's inquiry into the 1950 Maryland Senatorial election.

WASHINGTON, July 5--President Truman presented the Medal of Honor today to four infantry heroes of the Korean fighting. He assured them that men like them were the "backbone of our Government" and that because of such men we would "win the cold war and will maintain the peace."

Columbia University announced yesterday that William H. Newman, Professor of Business Administration, has been named as the first Samuel Bronfman Professor in Democratic Business Enterprise in the Graduate School of Business.

The season's largest audience-- and there won't he many larger in the weeks to come--jammed, 19,000 strong, into Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear a concert version of "Fledermaus," said version being the Kanin-Dietz English adaptation done by the Metropolitan Opera last season.

The Senate Crime Investigating Committee will open an investigation of the New Jersey underworld today with a closed hearing at the Traymore Hotel in Atlantic City and will continue tomorrow with another closed hearing in the Federal Building in Newark.

PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland, July 5 (AP)--Max Faulkner, a British Ryder Cup player with a keen putter, beat the chill, drizzling rain home today to take a twostroke lead in the British open golf championship after thirty-six holes that knocked two of four Americans out of the tournament.
Judge Mark W. Norman of Darien, Conn., former probate judge of the Darien district, died here yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 73.

WASHINGTON, July 5--A broad "consumption tax," designed to reach into an estimated $130,000,000,000 of personal income not now under levy, was urged on the Senate Finance Committee today by the National Association of Manufacturers. It got a cool reception from the Senators, however.

Representatives of United States oil companies operating abroad acted yesterday to meet an expected world shortage of petroleum products resulting from the increasing shutdown of the AngloIranian Oil Company in Iran.

BOSTON, July 5--An operating room drama in which a San Francisco housewife's heart was massaged back to life after it had stopped for twelve minutes during surgery was disclosed today by authorities at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital.
Col. Douglas Young of Katonah, N.Y., one of the foremost horseshow judges of this country and Canada, died Tuesday night of a heart attack in Mount Kisco Hospital. He was 69 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (U.P.)-- The Red Sox remained in the thick of the American League pennant fight tonight as they won their third straight game of the series from the seventh-place Athletics, 8--3.

BUENOS AIRES, July 5--Four Buenos Aires Federal policemen, including the head of the special section to investigate Communist activities, were jailed today, charged with having illegally detained and tortured the young university student, Ernest Mario Bravo.

WASHINGTON, July 5(U.P.)-- Appropriate advertising budgets will continue to be legitimate deduction expenses in tax reporting, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told a prominent West Coast advertising executive at the Treasury Department today.

The three-story apartment house at 23-17 Thirty-third Street, Long Island City, Queens, accommodating fifteen families, has been sold by Lillian Stock and Helen C. Kodet to Nicholas Biondo. Henry C. Schreiber was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

In an effort to avert further aggravation of the Iranian oil crisis the International Court of Justice, an agency of the United Nations, has assumed provisional jurisdiction in the case and has proposed provisional measures to keep the oil flowing pending final judgment.

Members of the Government of the Republic of Korea have stated that they do not oppose a cease-fire, as such, but that they will continue to oppose a settlement that involves a return to the partition of the country.
HEWLETT, L.I., July 5--The Women's Cross-Country Golf Association's mixed foursome one-day tournament ended in a tie among three teams for low gross over the Seawane Harbor Club links today.
Fourteen former college basketball players pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to conspiracy charges arising out of the fixing of games played at Madison Square Garden in recent seasons.
TOKYO, Friday, July 6--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey called today for a world peace based on a build-up of strength by free nations and "not a mere peace of surrender or appeasement."
Two more National Football League clubs appealed to the courts yesterday to keep star players from "jumping" to the Canadian Bid Four Union.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 5--First Lieut. Luther G. Roland, F-84 jet pilot from Hummelstown, Pa., who landed with his Norwegian wingman at Prague on June 8, said today he was kept in the same chair for intermittent interrogation from 11:30 that morning until 9:30 P.M. on June 9.

With their heavy siege guns booming a devastating barrage of thirteen blows, the Dodgers last night completed the rout of Leo Durocher's Giants at Ebbets Field by crushing the Polo Grounders, 8 to 4, to score a clean sweep of the three-game series.

Once again a part of Bryant Park has become a music-lover's paradise for lunchtime strollers in the Forty-second Street area. At the stroke of noon yesterday, the New York Public Library opened its fourth series of summer recorded concerts to an audience quite different in some respects from the first one three years ago.

The rise which developed suddenly last week in the free market rate for sterling balances usable only by non-Britishers for investment in sterling securities has brought the "switch pound" here to a discount of less than 15 per cent from the official $2.80 rate for American account sterling.
A major building project now seems assured for New York's old Hippodrome site on the Avenue of the Americas.

Under a literal interpretation of the bill by which Congress temporarily extended the Defense Production Act, transactions by an importer in types of goods being handled for the first time may be free of any price controls at all, foreign trade sources pointed out yesterday.

The National Maritime Union, C.I.O., is winding up its negotiations with about forty tanker companies and preparing to start similar talks with collier organizations early next week. The union has been asking for the application of the terms of the settlement reached with dry cargo steamship lines about ten days ago.

While general compliance with National Production Authority regulations has been good, the agency will crack down on companies that wilfully violate rules on the Controlled Materials Plan and defenserated orders, according to Robert H. Winn, assistant general counsel of the authority.

BERLIN, July 5 (UP)--An East German excursion boat, overcrowded with 150 German orphans and school children bound for a Communist-sponsored outing, exploded and burned today in Berlin's Spree River with a loss of between fifty and seventy lives.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 5-- Trade union gains in "human solidarity" and realization of democratic ideals must be translated from the workshop level to the community level if the free world is to prevail, Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, declared today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 5-- Miss Julie La Zier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. La Zier, was married here in the Central Presbyterian Church this afternoon to William Morgan Noyes, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Morgan Phelps Noyes, also of Montclair.

PARIS, July. 5--Mingled protests and applause greeted an appeal addressed today by the dean of the National Assembly, Eugene Pebellier, 85, to its opening session for a reconciliation of the factions that divided France during the last war and since then.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 5 --Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies introduced in the House of Representatives tonight a bill to amend the Commonwealth Constitution to give the Government the power to re-enact the law for dissolution of the Communist party.

TOKYO, Friday, July 6--Arrangements for a preliminary meeting Sunday to negotiate an armistice in Korea moved rapidly toward completion today as the Communists and United Nations leaders, in a new exchange of radio messages, agreed upon mutual safe-conduct for the negotiators and to establish a neutral zone around the city of Kaesong, where the talks will be held.

Thousands of rush-hour travelers were delayed yesterday when an empty I.R.T. train proceeding north on the middle, or "lay-up," track of the White Plains Avenue line plowed into another train parked on a sharp curve just north of the Simpson Street station in the Bronx. The tracks are elevated at this point.
LONDON, July 5--Foreign Secretary Herbert Morrison declared today that conditions for British oil company employes in Iran were "becoming intolerable."
LONDON, July 5--Lord Inverchapel, former British ambassador to the United States, died today in a hospital at Greenock, Scotland. His age was 69.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5-- A new independent motion-picture company, NPM, Inc., has been organized here by William and Edward Nassour, Will Price and L.B. (Doc) Merman to make films exclusively in Technicolor.

CHICAGO, July 5--Wheat prices finished lower after an irregular movement, uncertainty regarding Korean truce developments checking the demand. There still is a disposition on the part of many traders to stand by until after the first heavy run of winter wheat.

The stars of the current summer have their accustomed peaceful look, seemingly unmindful of the troubled earth they shine down on. White Vega, brightest of them, is high in the northeast in the evening and will have climbed to the overhead point by 1 A.M., summer time.
If you use the telephone book as a file for the family valuables, doodle distinctively on the cover, the New York Telephone Company suggested yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Net profits, after taxes, of manufacturing corporations, declined 8 per cent in the first quarter of this year compared with the preceding quarter despite a record volume of sales, the Securties and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

TODAY, 11 A.M.: "Pinocchio," Park Department marionette theatre production currently touring Staten Island playgrounds, Markham Houses, West Brighton. At 2:30 P.M., Todt Hill Housing Playground, Castleton Corners. Monday and Tuesday performances will conclude the Staten Island tour. The theatre will begin its round of Queens playgrounds on Wednesday. Call REgent 4-1000 for future locations.

WASHINGTON, July 5--With President Truman ruling out compromise, the Administration set out today to outdo the private lobbies in a nation-wide campaign to get the stronger economic controls it wanted in the new defense production bill.
GENEVA, July 5--Western Europe is quietly but firmly advancing toward a real integration of its transportation systems.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 5-- Fred Oman, caddy from the St. Andrews Club of Hastings, shot a one-over-par 38, 34--72 to win medal honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual junior championship at the Siwanoy C.C. today.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 5-- Frederick W. Rubien of 90 Aldershot Lane, former secretary of the American Olympic Committee and long a leader in the promotion of amateur athletics, died today in Manhasset Medical Center, after an illness of two weeks. His age was 80.

Net profit of Raytheon Manufacturing Company for the year ended on May 31 was estimated to be in excess of $2,000,000, according to Charles F. Adams Jr., president. This compares with $935,413 or 49c a common share in the previous fiscal year.

An $85,000 study of the Police Department, authorized by the city last April 12 to be made by the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey, has been blocked for nearly three months by the research consultant's objection to "contract conditions not to our liking."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5--Assuming that the Korean armistice negotiations do not encounter unexpected difficulties, the United Nations General Assembly is expected to meet about Aug. 1 to approve the armistice terms.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 5 --The four top-rated players all won their quarter-final matches in straight sets as play was resumed at the New Rochelle Tennis Club today in the women's New York State championship tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5--A growing censorship in the public schools, some of it voluntary and some imposed by pressure groups, has made "insidious inroads" into the teaching profession, the National Education Association warned today.
The New York City delegation in Congress was urged yesterday to suport a measure setting up a Small Defense Plants Corporation.

Commodities generally sold off yesterday as talk of Korean peace blended with outside factors.
DETROIT, July 5 (U.P.)--Freddie Hutchinson pitched the Tigers to a five-hit 8-to-0 victory over the White Sox today for his seventh triumph of the season.

The city's bread supply took a sharp dip yesterday as independent bakers found it increasingly difficult to get their bread to market. In the fourth day of the strike of 4,000 drivers against sixteen large bakeries no break appeared in the deadlock over a five-day work week, and the supply was expected to be even tighter today.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 5--"Flat rejection." Such was the comment of one Cabinet Minister after taking cognizance of the recommendations made by the International Court of Justice at the Hague.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices for active months were 29 to 38 points lower than on Tuesday.

Near-by growing areas now are close to peak production on many fruits and vegetables. For shoppers this means plentiful supplies from which to choose for the weekend market basket. Particularly abundant are such delectables as blueberries, peaches, celery, onions and both Italian and golden squash.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)-- President Truman named today a Republican Governor, Luther W. Youngdahl of Minnesota, to a Federal District judgeship in the District of Columbia.

The stock market staged its most impressive rally of the year yesterday, with gains up to 8 points, lifting the composite rate 3.36 points. It was the third straight day of recovery after last week's slump, although the extent of the advance failed to find reflection in the turnover.

One of the largest office leases of the year in the Grand Central zone has just been consummated in the Chrysler Building East, thirty-two-story commercial structure nearing completion adjoining the Chrysler Building.

Frederick Vanderbilt Field was sentenced to ninety days in jail yesterday for contempt of court. He then was paroled in custody of counsel until 11:30 A.M. today pending efforts to get a stay of execution on appeal.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)-- Representative Charles E. Bennett, Democrat of Florida, a campaigner for better morals in government, asserted today that persons trying to land Federal contracts had offered him substantial cash to help them meet "the right people."

TORONTO, July 6 (Canadian Press)--Toronto Daily Star, Ltd., and its affiliate, Toronto Star Realty, Ltd., had net revenue of $1,189,633 for the year ended last Sept. 30, compared with $532,961 in the preceding year.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 6--A delegation representing unions, factory councils and the Social Democratic party today reiterated the concern of these groups at local extreme right-wing activities to the Minister of the Interior of Lower Saxony.

NEW ORLEANS, July 6 (AP)-- Manager Dixie Walker drew a ninety-day suspension and a $100 fine today for causing forfeiture of a Southern Association baseball game between his Atlanta Crackers and the Mobile team June 29.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)-- Large areas of the country will be exempted from a proposed order restricting the use of natural gas, it was announced tonight.

The New York City Housing Authority filed plans yesterday for a $31,400,000 low-rental housing project for the lower East Side but said actual construction must await action by Congress on a disputed housing measure.

WASHINGTON, July 10--America's ability to thrive, or even to survive, will depend largely on its willingness to help free peoples build a way of life worth defending, Congress was told today by William C. Foster, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

ROME, July 10--Accusations in the Italian press that the Allied Military Government in Trieste was working against Italian claims over the Free Territory drew a categorical denial today from an A.M.G. spokesman.

The National Labor Relations Board failed yesterday in its first jurisdictional fight with the State Labor Relations Board.
An inspector for the Department of Housing and Building and a former inspector for the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity were charged, in indict-...
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP)-- Dr. Ruth Bleier, 27-year-old Baltimore physician, swore today that the Communist-line Maryland Committee for Peace had no members.

Business on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the slimmest since October, 1949. However, a moderate run-up in some of the steels and rails provided the list with sufficient force to reverse the downward trend of the previous day and set the composite rate higher by 0.47 point.
MILWAUKEE, July 11 (UP)-- Sixteen amateur golfers advanced today to the fifth round of the National Public Links golf tournament.
The Communist propaganda successes in the early stages of the Korean cease-fire negotiations should serve as a warning of future enemy intentions.

New issues of bonds and stocks valued at more than $22,500,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings, which represent securities of public utility, railroad and industrial companies, are as follows:

ALBANY, July 11--The Court of Appeals reserved decision today on whether Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz has jurisdiction to conduct proceedings involving charges of neglect of duty by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtaugh. No decision is expected until October.
LONDON, July 11--The population of the United Kingdom was placed at 50,368,455 in a report published today on the census taken last April 8. The figure covers all of the British Isles except Ireland.
LONDON, July 11--An indignant note from the British Government protesting the detention of a British freighter by a corvette of the Egyptian Navy was handed to the Egyptian Government today.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11-- Back from Wimbledon, Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., made his first appearance in defense of the Clifford Hemphill Challenge Bowl today in the Spring Lake invitation tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.
Mayor Impellitteri greeted the Shriners yesterday morning at the Commodore Hotel in their first business meeting of the seventyseventh annual convention of the order.

Where eggs are concerned, cheaper by the dozen may not be the rule. Agricultural economists of Cornell University remind consumers that the price a pound of eggs is more important to their pocketbooks than the price a dozen.

DETROIT, July 11--The 1951 All-Star game finally out of his hair, Casey Stengel, who dropped his second straight mid-summer classic to the National League yesterday, returned today to his major headache, that of revitalizing his world champion Yankees for the second-half struggle to retain their laurels in the American League.

CHICAGO, July 11--Bad weather was again the dominant note today in the grain futures markets. Strength in wheat at Kansas City was a big factor in stimulating buying elsewhere, the upturn at the Southwest market tending to confirm reports of discouraging harvest conditions.
WASHINGTON, July 11(AP)-- Following is the text of today's communication from Premier Mohammed Mossadegh of Iran to President Truman:

Immigration and Naturalization Service agents seized forty-two aliens yesterday in the Newark area and along the New York waterfront, to bring to 178 the number of persons arrested in the last three days on suspicion of having entered the country illegally.

The introduction last year of the new sewer rentals charged to all city water-users has assured the financing and speedy progress of the city's anti-pollution program without interference with other city projects, Mayor Impellitteri told an outdoor crowd of 500 persons on Staten Island yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11--Warning of hardships to widows, orphans and aged persons, spokesmen for life insurance companies urged the Senate Finance Committee today to kill a plan approved by the House of Representatives to impose a 20 per cent withholding tax on dividends and interest.

WASHINGTON, July 11-- Charging six of the nation's largest publishing houses with "unlawful practices," the Federal Trade Commission moved today for the first time against an alleged "unfair" competitive advantage given book clubs over retail book stores.

The police dog patrol of Flatbush, Brooklyn, has passed out of existence again, and it looks as if this time its demise would be final. A week ago Capt. James Haughie of the Parkville precinct received the permission of the commissioner for the dissolution of the patrol, on the grounds of obsoleteness, he said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 11--The Administration recommended to Congress today a stand-by bill to enable the Government to relieve the damage costs in a possible atomic attack.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 11-- Dr. Donald F. Gibson, dapper 49year-old physician, appeared today before a Fairfield County grand jury and began relating his version of the circumstances surrounding the death last July 26 of Elizabeth M. Ayres, 74-year-old spinster, who willed him her entire estate, estimated at $65,000 to $100,000.

WASHINGTON, July 11--President Truman held a "hush-hush" meeting with ten labor leaders at Blair House last night and they exchanged views on the prospect for Congressional enactment of a Defense Production Act that would satisfy both the Administration and labor.

VALDOSTA, Ga., July 11 (AP)-- Korean peace moves have had a "drastic and unrealistic effect" on naval stores prices despite low stocks and anticipated heavy demand, turpentine tradesmen were told today by their leader. He advised them to place all their rosin in the Government loan as a means of helping this market.

The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives has voted to reduce this year's budget of the State Department by about one-fifth. Some of this represents the elimination of small luxuries. This seems reasonable enough; all of us are being asked, in the present circumstances, to make similar economies.

A veteran of many difficult negotiations with Communists in Berlin, Col. Lawrence Wilkinson, New York State Civil Defense Director, expressed hope yesterday that civil defense workers would not be lulled into a false sense of security by the present Korean cease-fire negotiations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11--The Soviet Union has filed two sharp official complaints with the United States accusing AmericanHungarian pickets of "hooligan acts" outside the Russian delegation's headquarters at 680 Park Avenue.

The truce talks in the "United Nations House" in Kaesong, designed to bring about an "honorable truce" in Korea, are still in their initial stages and still deal in the main with the agenda of the meeting rather than with the substance of the issue.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 11--Miss Peggy Mackie of Inwood, the medalist, led the way into the semi-finals of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's twenty-first annual tournament, with a victory over Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley by 2 and 1 today at the North Hempstead Country Club.

The use of fabric and color to create fresh-looking backgrounds for traditional furniture is demonstrated in five room settings that will go on view today at Stern's. The rooms were planned by Miss Rebecca Petrickin of the store's decorating department.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 12-- Saber jets of the United States Air Force shot down three Soviet-built MIG jets above the Manchurian border town of Sinuiju yesterday as Communist pilots, scrapping previous hit-run tactics, collided with United Nations fliers in the longest battle yet fought by jets.

Somewhere in a cranberry bog, or sequestered on a lonely hilltop, an illicit whisky distillery is at work. But one of these days, a lowflying United States Coast Guard plane will spot the hideout, and will cooperate with a patrol car to raid the moonshine distillery.

Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff yesterday denied a temporary injunction to Walt Disney Productions and R.K.O. Radio Pictures preventing the showing of Lou Bunin's puppet and live-action version of "Alice in Wonderland."

WASHINGTON, July 11--The Navy announced today how it plans to release from active duty 60,000 enlisted reservists during the next eleven months. At the same time, it announced the call-up during the Fall and Winter of 3,000 more petty officers.

THE pleasures of reading other people's mail are timeless. That seems to be true, at any rate, when it comes to the duly published correspondence of the eminent. And that trend in perpetual motion may also apply to others, for all I know.

THE New York State Conservation Department has is ued its periodic report on fish and game violations. It covers the month of May and lists 467 miscreants caught throughout the state. They parted with $8,827 in fines, which is a little higher than thirty more offenders paid for the same month in 1950.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The International Materials Conference announced today the conclusion of a world agreement on the allocation of crude sulphur supplies. Today's agreement is the third concluded by the conference, which is seeking to establish the equitable division of scarce raw materials...

GENEVA, July 11--A shipment of medical supplies for prisoners of war and civilians in North Korea sent by the International Committee of the Red Cross last October by way of the Hungarian Red Cross is on its way back to Geneva.

The State of California borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday in the public market to finance veterans' benefits at an interest cost of 1.89 per cent for obligations maturing on Aug. 1, 1953, to Aug. 1, 1972. The bonds were sold at sealed bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association at a bid which designated interest coupons of 4 per cent, 1 per cent and 1 per cent.

ROME, July 11--Premier Alcide de Gasperi hinted today that Italy might even withdraw from the North Atlantic pact if the United States, Britain and France did not honor the three-power declaration of March, 1948, in which they came...

BONN, Germany, July 11--An agreement between the Western occupation powers and the Federal Republic on the sovereignty of West Germany is regarded by Bonn Government officials and Allied diplomats as basic to German acceptance of rearmament.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11-- The withdrawal of this country from the United Nations "at the earliest reasonable moment" was demanded today by the annual Congress of the Sons of the American Revolution.
WASHINGTON, July 11-- Friends of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower hope to be able to announce his availability for the Republican Presidential nomination around Thanksgiving Day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11 --A former Holy Cross golf captain, Larry Murphy, scored the principal upset in the second round of the New York state amateur golf championship today when he eliminated the United States Walker Cup captain, Willie Turness, 1 up at the twentieth hole at the Knollwood Country Club.
Volodymyr Holubiw, once of Baronovice, Poland, led his wife and three daughters down the gangplank of the Navy transport General Sturgis at 9 A.M. yesterday and was gathered into the arms of America.

LONDON, July 11 (UP)--Promoter Jack Solomons dangled the lure of a crowd of 150,000 and a million-dollar gate before Middleweight Champion Randy Turpin and Ray (Sugar) Robinson today in a bid to prevent their return title bout from going to the United States.
The influence of the European market on accessory designs and their fashion importance for fall was the subject of the Fashion Group luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

FAR HILLS, N.J., July 11-- Citizens here and in neighboring Bedminster Township are up in arms against what they describe as the most irritating element of country life--poison ivy. They plan to begin an all-out "war" against the vine next week.

Officials of the sanitation workers' union that last week staged a "book of rules" slowdown in garbage collection drew plans yesterday for renewed action unless city authorities took steps to negotiate with the union.

LONDON, July 11--Use of sex appeal in advertising was criti cized today at the international advertising conference being held here this week to commemorate the silver jubilee of the Advertising Association of Great Britain.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 11 --The state amateur champion, Billy Dear Jr. of Montclair, began his bid for a sweep of major titles by taking a two-stroke lead today in the first round of the New Jersey Open at the Essex County Country Club course.

Net asset value of the Lehman Corporation on June 30 was $116,973,254, equal to $60.09 a share on the investment concern's outstanding capital stock, Robert Lehman, president, reported in the twentysecond annual report to stockholders, issued yesterday.

The spellbinder from the New York Public Library was late yesterday. Two or three dozen squirming, restless children in the "Mother Goose" playground in Central Park, scene of the library's first outdoor story hour this season for city-bound youngsters, were held in check firmly by their mothers.

WASHINGTON, July 11--At stake in the controversy between Administrator Gray of the Veterans Administration and the chief medical officer, Dr. Paul B. Magnuson, was what a Senate group of inquiry referred to in its report yesterday as "the best medical care available anywhere in the world at any time in the world's history."

PARIS, July 11--President Vincent Auriol was experiencing difficulty tonight in drawing the republican majority produced by the elections into a working coalition. His first day of consultations with political leaders to choose a Premier-designate was fruitless.

Comprehensive plans for the construction of a new medical center in Jerusalem at a cost of $5,500,000 that will embrace medical and nursing schools and a 430bed hospital were announced here yesterday by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, July 11--A Communist's life is not a happy one, the House committee on UnAmerican Activities was told today by a young woman who had spent almost seven years as a rank-and-file member of the party while an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Most commodities showed improvement yesterday. Wool, which rose on Tuesday when other lines fell, did the reverse yesterday, taking moderate losses.

WASHINGTON, July 11--United States officials have made a careful survey in the last few days of the political implications of the Korean armistice negotiations, and most of their conclusions are rather gloomy.

ABOARD PRESS TRAIN, in Korea, July 11--In terse phrases a United States Army officer who attended today's cease-fire talks in Kaesong described the formal atmosphere that pervaded the Korean house in which ten delegates were trying to end the Korean war.

WASHINGTON July 11--Indefinite extension of the Economic Cooperation Administration, with broadened authority to resume functions of the wartime Foreign Economic Administration, was recommended today in a report to President Truman by the agency's Public Advisory Board.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP)-- The Air Force told a closed hearing of the House Armed Services Committee today that it had only eighty-seven atomic bomb carrying B-36 bombers ready to go into action, some committee members said.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active and lower again yesterday, final prices being 130 points, or $6.50 a bale, lower on the old July, and 20 to 36 points, or $1 to $1.80 a bale, lower on the other months.

A Coast Guard "flying cutter" made a landing 480 miles at sea before dawn yesterday and brought back to shore two injured crew members from the military transport Gen. J. H. McCrae, Coast Guard headquarters here announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The House of Representatives rejected today, 134 to 79, an amendment to make the need for dispersal of industry a yardstick in the construction of defense plants built or financed by the Government.

The Communist revolution goes on "devouring its children." In that sense the apparent disgrace of the Premiers in Rumania and Bulgaria--Petru Groza and Vulko Chervenkov--represents a more or less normal historic process.

A heavyweight battle that may carry significance with relation to the world title, is scheduled for tonight in air-cooled Madison Square Garden. Unbeaten Rocky Marciano, Brockton, Mass., slugger, is to tackle the spectacular Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah, in a struggle scheduled for ten rounds.

Effects of the Korean truce discussions on the volume of United States exports will be a temporary decline, it was agreed yesterday at a round-table meeting of the Foreign Credit Inter change Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

The Long Island Railroad has incurred liabilities of upward of $4,000,000 in addition to those covered by $2,000,000 of liability insurance as a result of the Rockville Centre and Richmond Hill wrecks in 1950, William H. Draper Jr., the trustee, reported yesterday.
ABADAN, Iran, July 11--A United States diplomat who has just finished a tour of Near East oil centers has reported mounting pressures throughout the area as a result of the Iranian oil crisis.
PARIS, July 11 (AP)--A touring team of American track and field stars today dominated French rivals for the second straight time in an international meet.
TOKYO, Thursday, July 12(AP)-- General Headquarters communique 942, issued at 10:45 A.M., Thursday (8:45 P.M., Wednesday, Eastern daylight time):

WELLINGTON, N.Z., July 11 (AP)--The Conservative Government tonight said it would dissolve Parliament and stake its life in new national elections on the way it had handled the five-month waterfront strike.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 11--Richard H. Johnson of Palm Springs, Calif., the 1950 national soaring champion, held his lead today in the eighteenth National Soaring Contest, which ends tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The Nationa Production Authority announced today that it was mailing application forms for fourth quarter allocations of steel, copper and aluminum under the Controlled Materials Plan to more than 50,000 manufacturers of mass-produced items using these materials.

WASHINGTON, July 11--The structure of meat price controls is beginning to crumble as Congress debates the removal of slaughter quotas, rollbacks and other features of meat price control regulations, Michael V. DiSalle, Director of Price Stabilization, said today.
Service on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad between Pennsylvania Station here and Newark was halted for five hours and twelve minutes yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 11--Language differences need be no barrier to international understanding, at least among 11-year-old children, according to Dr. Doris Twitchell Allen, University of Cincinnati psychologist.

DUNDEE, Scotland, July 11 (AP) --Shareholders of the Scottishcontrolled Matador Land and Cattle Company adopted resolutions today looking toward the sale of their vast cattle ranch holdings in the Texas Panhandle to an American syndicate.

PARIS, July 11--The European Ministers of the Marshall Plan Council will meet here tomorrow in the first of two-day sessions for survey of the present economic situation and to lay some plans for future work.

Warning of what the may expect to see under the tree next Christmas was given yesterday at the fifth annual preview of Americanmade toys given by the Toy Guidance Council at 1124 Broadway. Reassuring news for parents is that prices will be about the same as last Christmas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11-- Alfred Hayes, the novelist, and Sidney Skolsky, the Hollywood columnist, have sold a movie colony story, "The Way Up," to the Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna producing unit at R.K.O.

EVER since the war, National Leaguers have been insisting that they had done a better job than the American League in restock ing their teams with talent and that they definitely were the league of the future. Repeated rebuffs by the junior circuit in interleague competition failed to dim their optimism. With dogged persistence they kept reciting the old refrain.

MILAN, Italy, July 11--The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions began debate today on a series of resolutions submitted by its economic, social and political committee that will determine the policy to be followed by its members in their fight against communism throughout the world.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 11--Development of an electronic "brain" that will add to the effectiveness of the B-36 intercontinental bomber by reducing pilot fatigue and increasing bombardier accuracy was announced here today.
Oliver Smith, scene designer and co-producer of the current success, "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," has made plans to present on Broadway this fall "In the Summer House," a play by Jane Bowles.
Fifteen indicted Communist leaders were sent back to jail last night after Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan had revoked $176,000 in bail because their bondsmen were "unworthy of trust."

WASHINGTON, July 11--W. Averell Harriman, special assistant to the President, will fly to Teheran within the next forty-eight hours and attempt to assist in settling the Iranian oil dispute, the White House announced late this afternoon.
Experts on child psychology and welfare moved yesterday to save the little red lighthouse under the George Washington Bridge for the city's boys and girls.
In the John Frederics collection, viewed yesterday at his 29 East Forty-eighth Street salon, Fred Frederics and his staff covered themselves with glory.

The nation's steel mills, racing at top speed to meet the requirements of defense mobilization, produced more steel in the first half of 1951 than ever before. Output for June and for the second quarter of this year also set new records.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 11 (AP)-- Northern and central Kansas tonight fought the worst flood since the disastrous overflow of 1903 which paralyzed all of the cities along the Kansas River from its source to Kansas City.

PARIS, July 11--In a speech reflecting an atmosphere of optimism and growing confidence, Dr. Jaime Torres Bodet of Mexico, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, told the final plenary session of its sixth general conference today that Unesco had passed through the initial stages of immaturity and uncertainty to a program offering real benefits to world society.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 12--Citizens of the Republic of South Korea are beginning to show bitter resentment over the terms under which an armistice is expected to be arranged.

BRUSSELS, July 11--A week's discussions among 1,500 delegates who gathered here for the ninth triennial session of the International Management Congress ended today with an appeal by Albert de Smaele for the free exchange of people and goods in the interests of peace.

WASHINGTON, July 11--Dr. Henry F. Grady, whose replacement as Ambassador to Iran has been reported as imminent, satirized today an editorial suggestion that Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas ought to be sent out to mediate the Iranian oil dispute.

PEACE CAMP, in Korea, Thursday, July 12--The Korean ceasefire talks at Kaesong were temporarily broken off by the United Nations delegation this noon after a truck in which twenty allied correspondents were riding to the negotiation town had been halted by the Communists.
LONDON, July 11--Reuters News Agency, one of the world's stoutest bulwarks of freedom and impartiality in the reporting of news, celebrated its 100th anniversary in London tonight.

ALBANY, July 11--The Court of Appeals ruled tonight that the three-month-old State Crime Commission was a legal organ of the state government with the power to subpoena witnesses. Two of the seven judges dissented.

In the Coaching Club American Oaks last month Walter M. Jeffords' Kiss Me Kate was the beaten favorite and Herman B. Delman's How was the winner. There was a reversal of the roles in the $28,425 Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

Thomas Barger Gregory of Pittsburgh, one of the early developers of the petroleum and gas industries in this country, died yesterday in the West Penn Hospital, Pittsburgh, according to word received here last night. He was born in Philadelphia ninety years ago.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 11-- Congestion on the thirty miles of the Albany Post Road in Westchester County is expected to become so acute when the New York-Buffalo Thruway feeds more vehicles onto it here that an immediate start on the development of a new "traffic backbone" for Hudson Valley communities is advocated.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11-- Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A.F.L., gave notice today that his membership would refuse to support a strike of Harry Bridges' unaffiliated International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union against the Oliver J. Olson Company, operator of a fleet of lumber-carrying steam schooners on the West Coast.

ALBANY, July 11--The State Court of Appeals, in a six-toone decision, upheld today the constitutionality of the New York City released-time program under which children may be excused from public school for an hour's religious instruction each week.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 12 --Native rubber production here may soon suffice for the country's total needs, according to the newspaper La Republica. Of 167,000 pounds of raw rubber used in the first six months of this year, 118,000 was grown locally.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, July 12 (AP)--George Fazio, 36-year-old professional from Pine Valley, N.J., shot a record-smashing 63 today to take the opening round of the Western open golf tournament.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12 (UP) --Uncle Miltie, who was hailed as the horse to beat in the Kentucky Derby before he went sore last spring, returner to racing today and defeated a field of older horses at Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON, July 12--President Truman signed a bill today authorizing importation of Mexican farm laborers. He will send a message on the bill to Congress tomorrow.
VICKSBURG, Miss., July 12 (AP) --A jury of twelve white men today acquitted a 27-year-old white farmer charged with raping a 31year-old unmarried Negro woman.

ATHENS, July 12 (AP)--United States Ambassador John E. Peurifoy today urged 100,000 striking Greek civil servants and employes of semi-public organizations to return to their jobs, a union spokesman said.

Undaunted by a midnight shower, the red-fezzed Shriners who seem to have taken over New York during their seventy-seventh annual convention this week, held another huge, spectacular parade last night.

JERSEY CITY, July 12--Rush hour traffic on the Pulaski Skyway was snarled for an hour tonight after a 32-year-old motorist was crushed to death when his automobile skidded into a Public Service Corporation bus.
CHICAGO, July 12--Members of the Air Line Pilots Association, A.F.L., were calling today for the ouster of David L. Behncke, 54year-old president of the union since it was founded twenty years ago.

CINCINNATI, July 12--Elmont V. Bankhardt, president and treasurer of Bankhardt's Luggage Shop here, died today at his home in Fort Thomas, Ky., at the age of 67. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Porter Bankhardt; three daughters, two sisters and seven grandchildren.

E.A. Murray has been appointed manager of the compressor division, Buffalo, of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation, Harrison, N.J., succeeding Herman H. Miller, who will retire in December. Mr. Miller will assist Mr. Murray until the end of the year.

Personnel at Mitchel Air Force Base, L.I., contributed more than half of all the blood donated to the Red Cross Wednesday in the New York area, it was reported yesterday. The total amount received was 652 pints and Mitchel gave 348.

Genancoke of the Rokeby Stable, aided if not abetted by the veteran Larky Day, won the $10,000 added Hitchcock at Aqueduct yesterday. The ninth running of the fixture named in memory of Tommy Hitchcock was an entertaining one, over the steeplechase course...

CHICAGO, July 12--Bishop Bernard J. Sheil of Chicago, national director of the Catholic Youth Organization, received the B'nai B'rith award for "Service to Humanity" at the annual convention here of District Lodge 6 of the Jewish fraternal order.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP)--Gus Zermal struck out six times during the night, but he also hammered a grand slam home run to help the Athletics to a 13--0 shutout over the Browns tonight in the second game of a twi-night doubleheader.

Salvatore Tarto Sollazzo, the master fixer who won heavy wagers on basketball contests in which he bribed local college players to fix the score, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to all but two counts of a thirty-count indictment charging bribery and conspiracy.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP)-- A $650,000 loan to a Peruvian tungsten mining firm has been announced by the Export-Import Bank in a move to build up United States stockpiles.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., July 14-- This village's historic Old Whalers Church, whose steeple in the early Eighteen Hundreds was a beacon for returning Sag Harbor mariners on the last lap of voyages from distant waters, will be reopened and rededicated on Sunday evening, July 22. The church had been condemned since last November's storm damaged its interior.

Dr. Ernest M. Doblin, a United Nations economist, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, 147-51 Charter Road, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 47.

IT is just before Christmas and 16-year-old Holden Caulfield has been kicked out of exclusive Pencey Prep, a boys' school in Pennsylvania. Considering everything, this reflects more credit on Holden than on Pencey. Life at Pencey is dreary, regimented, artificial and, of course, expensive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15-- Gene Evans, who attracted attention as the tough, cynical sergeant in "Steel Helmet," has drawn a top role as a bearded dogface in "Fixed Bayonets," which Samuel Fuller has written and will direct for Twentieth Century-Fox. Fuller also, wrote and directed "Steel Helmet".

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP)-- The largest cities in the United States spent much more per pupil for their public schools than the lesser ones during the 1949-50 school year, according to a report issued today by the United States Office of Education.

The New York City Housing Authority reported to Mayor Impellitteri yesterday that the first units in projects developed under the United States Housing Act of 1949 would be ready for occupancy by the end of this year. Two other projects will begin admitting tenants next spring.
MONTEREY, Calif., July 15-- The Presidio of Monterey, founded as a military post in 1770, is today the campus of a remarkable institution, the Army's language school.

The National Bureau of Casualty Underwriters announced an upward revision of bodily injury liability rates yesterday in owners, landlords and tenants classifications in fourteen states and the Territory of Alaska.

CHICAGO, July 15 (UP)--Sam Zoldak, a veteran of eight major league years at 29, shut out the White Sox with one hit today for a 5-to-0 triumph as the Athletics swept a double-header from second-place Chicago before 26,793 fans.
TEHACHAPI, Calif., July 15 (AP) --Madge Meredith, actress, got a thirtieth birthday present from California today--her release from prison.

WASHINGTON, July 15--The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives sought today to hold party membership in line as the hour neared for the start of record voting on the defense production bill.

CHICAGO, July 15--Substantial gains were registered in cereal futures at Chicago last week. Buying by mills against liberal flour sales was a big influence in starting general support in wheat.

For seven and one-half hours yesterday a team of brain surgeons at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital performed a rare and difficult operation. They removed from a man's head the six-and-one-halfinch blade of a hunting knife that had become imbedded there in a street fight.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 15 (AP)--A decline in textile orders is forcing several large mills here to shut down for one and two week periods and is causing shortened work-weeks at other plants in the area.

GENEVA, July 15--It is a "most serious misapprehension" to believe that the world refugee problem will have been solved when the International Refugee Organization closes its doors, Dr. G.J. ATLANTA, Ga., July 15--A total of 19,138 low-rent public housing units have been completed or are now in the process of construction in six Southeastern states, it was announced today by the Atlanta field office of the Public Housing Administration.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15-- The nation's costliest flood gushed for 400 miles along the Kansas and Missouri Rivers today, strangling this great gateway city to the Southwest for the fourth straight day.

After twenty days at Aqueduct, the horses--and the horse-players --shift their base of operations today to the Jamaica track. There'll be three weeks of racing at the Metropolitan Jockey Club's course prior to the opening at Saratoga Springs on Aug. 6.

Henry Payson, operator, has sold the nine-story apartment house on plot 83 by 100 feet at 111-115 East Eighty-ninth Street to an investing client of Serge Jarvis, attorney, in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 15--Secretary of State Dean Acheson is of the belief that Korea is not the place for a showdown between communism and the West, and that the United States must neither force such a showdown nor permit its opponents to force one.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP)-- The Cardinals split a doubleheader with the Phillies today, taking the opener, 7--4, with the help of four home runs, and dropping the second, 6--4, as Jim Konstanty tossed splendid relief ball to protect a slim margin.

WASHINGTON, July 15--Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, left the capital today for a week's tour of Europe. His itinerary will include Spain, where he is scheduled to discuss "matters of mutual interest" with military officials, a Navy Department announcement said.

TOKYO, Monday, July 16--The Chinese Communists struck out yesterday with ten quick jabs at United Nations forces consolidating their advances south of Kumsong, on the east-central sector of Korea's battlefront, but the whole series of light enemy attacks were turned back.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 15-- Victer Seixas of Philadelphia scored his most notable tournament success in recent years today.

ADVANCE BASE, in Korea, July 15--Choi Ki Duk, a South Korean correspondent, returned to Kaesong this afternoon for the first time since last December. He found it much more peaceful and somewhat shabbier than when United Nations forces were retreating through the city.

LONDON, July 15--While stock exchange business here reflects the public's preoccupation with the holidays, the markets have experienced in the last week a revival of confidence and strength that few appear to have anticipated and which many consider as having a rather flimsy basis.
